 3549
 3550def c3d_hessian_objectness_params(
 3551    hessian_objectness: str,
 3552) -> C3dHessianObjectnessParameters:
 3553    """
 3554    Build parameters.
 3555    
 3556    Args:
 3557        hessian_objectness: -hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness\
 3558            filter\
 3559            \
 3560            Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`\
 3561            \
 3562            Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used\
 3563            to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the\
 3564            image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK\
 3565            class][HTOMIF].\
 3566            \
 3567            Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of\
 3568            features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for\
 3569            pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point\
 3570            values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical\
 3571            units. Typically, just one scale is used.\
 3572            \
 3573            # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm\
 3574            c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5\
 3575            \
 3576            [HTOMIF]\
 3577            http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html.
 3578    Returns:
 3579        Parameter dictionary
 3580    """
 3581    params = {
 3582        "__STYXTYPE__": "hessian_objectness",
 3583        "hessian_objectness": hessian_objectness,
 3584    }
 3585    return params
 3586
 3587
 3588def c3d_hessian_objectness_cargs(
 3589    params: C3dHessianObjectnessParameters,
 3590    execution: Execution,
 3591) -> list[str]:
 3592    """
 3593    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 3594    
 3595    Args:
 3596        params: The parameters.
 3597        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 3598    Returns:
 3599        Command-line arguments.
 3600    """
 3601    cargs = []
 3602    cargs.extend([
 3603        "-hessobj",
 3604        params.get("hessian_objectness")
 3605    ])
 3606    return cargs
 3607

 3648def c3d_info_params(
 3649    info: str,
 3650) -> C3dInfoParameters:
 3651    """
 3652    Build parameters.
 3653    
 3654    Args:
 3655        info: -info: Display brief image information\
 3656            \
 3657            Syntax: `-info`\
 3658            \
 3659            Prints brief information about the last image on the stack. Does\
 3660            not affect the stack.\
 3661            \
 3662            c3d image.hdr -info\
 3663            \
 3664            Use with the **-foreach** command to get information on multiple\
 3665            images\
 3666            \
 3667            c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor.
 3668    Returns:
 3669        Parameter dictionary
 3670    """
 3671    params = {
 3672        "__STYXTYPE__": "info",
 3673        "info": info,
 3674    }
 3675    return params
 3676

 3688    Returns:
 3689        Command-line arguments.
 3690    """

 3693        "-info",

 3695    ])
 3696    return cargs

 3744
 3745def c3d_insert_params(
 3746    insert: str,
 3747) -> C3dInsertParameters:
 3748    """
 3749    Build parameters.
 3750    
 3751    Args:
 3752        insert: -insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack\
 3753            \
 3754            Syntax: `-insert var pos`\
 3755            \
 3756            This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the\
 3757            image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting\
 3758            from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of\
 3759            the stack (same as **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed\
 3760            at the next-to-end position, and so on.
 3761    Returns:
 3762        Parameter dictionary
 3763    """
 3764    params = {
 3765        "__STYXTYPE__": "insert",
 3766        "insert": insert,
 3767    }
 3768    return params
 3769
 3770
 3771def c3d_insert_cargs(
 3772    params: C3dInsertParameters,
 3773    execution: Execution,
 3774) -> list[str]:
 3775    """
 3776    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 3777    
 3778    Args:
 3779        params: The parameters.
 3780        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 3781    Returns:
 3782        Command-line arguments.
 3783    """
 3784    cargs = []
 3785    cargs.extend([
 3786        "-insert",
 3787        params.get("insert")
 3788    ])
 3789    return cargs
 3790
 3791
 3792def c3d_interpolation_params(
 3793    interpolation: str,
 3794) -> C3dInterpolationParameters:
 3795    """
 3796    Build parameters.
 3797    
 3798    Args:
 3799        interpolation: -interpolation: Set interpolation mode\
 3800            \
 3801            Syntax: `-interpolation\
 3802            <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]`\
 3803            \
 3804            Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other\
 3805            commands. Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as\
 3806            the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g,\
 3807            1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first\
 3808            smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it\
 3809            with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less\
 3810            aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with\
 3811            small sigmas (a few voxels across).\
 3812            \
 3813            Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3\
 3814            for *Cubic*. For example:\
 3815            \
 3816            c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii.
 3817    Returns:
 3818        Parameter dictionary
 3819    """
 3820    params = {
 3821        "__STYXTYPE__": "interpolation",
 3822        "interpolation": interpolation,
 3823    }
 3824    return params
 3825
 3826
 3827def c3d_interpolation_cargs(
 3828    params: C3dInterpolationParameters,
 3829    execution: Execution,
 3830) -> list[str]:
 3831    """
 3832    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 3833    
 3834    Args:
 3835        params: The parameters.
 3836        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 3837    Returns:
 3838        Command-line arguments.
 3839    """
 3840    cargs = []
 3841    cargs.extend([
 3842        "-interpolation",
 3843        params.get("interpolation")
 3844    ])
 3845    return cargs

 3926def c3d_label_statistics_params(
 3927    label_statistics: str,
 3928) -> C3dLabelStatisticsParameters:
 3929    """
 3930    Build parameters.
 3931    
 3932    Args:
 3933        label_statistics: -lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation\
 3934            volumes and intensity statistics\
 3935            \
 3936            Syntax: `-lstat`\
 3937            \
 3938            Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this\
 3939            command computes the statistics for every label in the latter,\
 3940            including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance,\
 3941            if image *mri.nii* is a medical image and *seg.nii* is a multilabel\
 3942            segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following\
 3943            command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of\
 3944            *mri.nii* for each of the labels\
 3945            \
 3946            c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat\
 3947            \
 3948            The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity\
 3949            and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from\
 3950            a multi-label image, use **-dup** command as follows:\
 3951            \
 3952            c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat.
 3953    Returns:
 3954        Parameter dictionary
 3955    """
 3956    params = {
 3957        "__STYXTYPE__": "label_statistics",
 3958        "label_statistics": label_statistics,
 3959    }
 3960    return params
 3961
 3962
 3963def c3d_label_statistics_cargs(
 3964    params: C3dLabelStatisticsParameters,
 3965    execution: Execution,
 3966) -> list[str]:
 3967    """
 3968    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 3969    
 3970    Args:
 3971        params: The parameters.
 3972        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 3973    Returns:
 3974        Command-line arguments.
 3975    """
 3976    cargs = []
 3977    cargs.extend([
 3978        "-label-statistics",
 3979        params.get("label_statistics")
 3980    ])
 3981    return cargs

 4022
 4023def c3d_laplacian_params(
 4024    laplacian: str,
 4025) -> C3dLaplacianParameters:
 4026    """
 4027    Build parameters.
 4028    
 4029    Args:
 4030        laplacian: -laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter\
 4031            \
 4032            Syntax: `-laplacian`\
 4033            \
 4034            Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of\
 4035            intensity. Typically, used with the **-smooth** option to obtain\
 4036            the equivalent of convolving the image with the *Laplacian of the\
 4037            Gaussian (LoG)* kernel:\
 4038            \
 4039            c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img.
 4040    Returns:
 4041        Parameter dictionary
 4042    """
 4043    params = {
 4044        "__STYXTYPE__": "laplacian",
 4045        "laplacian": laplacian,
 4046    }
 4047    return params
 4048

 4051    params: C3dLaplacianParameters,
 4052    execution: Execution,
 4053) -> list[str]:
 4054    """
 4055    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 4056    
 4057    Args:
 4058        params: The parameters.
 4059        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4060    Returns:
 4061        Command-line arguments.
 4062    """
 4063    cargs = []
 4064    cargs.extend([
 4065        "-laplacian",
 4066        params.get("laplacian")
 4067    ])
 4068    return cargs
 4069
 4070
 4071def c3d_levelset_params(
 4072    levelset: str,
 4073) -> C3dLevelsetParameters:
 4074    """
 4075    Build parameters.
 4076    
 4077    Args:
 4078        levelset: -levelset: Level set segmentation\
 4079            \
 4080            Syntax: `-levelset n_iter `\
 4081            \
 4082            Perform level set segmentation for *n\\_iter* iterations, like in\
 4083            ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the\
 4084            initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the\
 4085            speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1.\
 4086            Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted\
 4087            \
 4088            | | Speed Image | Initialization Image | Output Image |\
 4089            | -- | ------------- | -------------------- | ------------ |\
 4090            | +1 | Foreground | Outside | Outside |\
 4091            | -1 | Background | Inside | Inside |\
 4092            \
 4093            Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization\
 4094            given:\
 4095            \
 4096            c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o\
 4097            seg.img\
 4098            \
 4099            Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image,\
 4100            where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The\
 4101            image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the\
 4102            initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside).\
 4103            \
 4104            c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz \\\
 4105            -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 \\\
 4106            -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz\
 4107            \
 4108            Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for\
 4109            cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive\
 4110            inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside\
 4111            the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose\
 4112            0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the\
 4113            smoothed binary object\
 4114            \
 4115            c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 \\\
 4116            -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img \\\
 4117            -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img.
 4118    Returns:
 4119        Parameter dictionary
 4120    """
 4121    params = {
 4122        "__STYXTYPE__": "levelset",
 4123        "levelset": levelset,
 4124    }
 4125    return params
 4126
 4127
 4128def c3d_levelset_cargs(
 4129    params: C3dLevelsetParameters,
 4130    execution: Execution,
 4131) -> list[str]:
 4132    """
 4133    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 4134    
 4135    Args:
 4136        params: The parameters.
 4137        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4138    Returns:
 4139        Command-line arguments.
 4140    """
 4141    cargs = []
 4142    cargs.extend([
 4143        "-levelset",
 4144        params.get("levelset")
 4145    ])
 4146    return cargs
 4147
 4148
 4149def c3d_levelset_curvature_params(
 4150    levelset_curvature: str,
 4151) -> C3dLevelsetCurvatureParameters:
 4152    """
 4153    Build parameters.
 4154    
 4155    Args:
 4156        levelset_curvature: No description found.
 4157    Returns:
 4158        Parameter dictionary
 4159    """
 4160    params = {
 4161        "__STYXTYPE__": "levelset_curvature",
 4162        "levelset_curvature": levelset_curvature,
 4163    }
 4164    return params
 4165
 4166

 4354def c3d_match_bounding_box_params(
 4355    match_bounding_box: str,
 4356) -> C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters:
 4357    """
 4358    Build parameters.
 4359    
 4360    Args:
 4361        match_bounding_box: -mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of\
 4362            one image to another\
 4363            \
 4364            Syntax: `-mbb`\
 4365            \
 4366            Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the\
 4367            header of the target image so that the two images occupy the same\
 4368            physical space. The direction cosines of the target image are set\
 4369            to match the reference image. This command is related to\
 4370            '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size.\
 4371            \
 4372            c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii.
 4373    Returns:
 4374        Parameter dictionary
 4375    """
 4376    params = {
 4377        "__STYXTYPE__": "match_bounding_box",
 4378        "match_bounding_box": match_bounding_box,
 4379    }
 4380    return params
 4381
 4382
 4383def c3d_match_bounding_box_cargs(
 4384    params: C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters,
 4385    execution: Execution,
 4386) -> list[str]:
 4387    """
 4388    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 4389    
 4390    Args:
 4391        params: The parameters.
 4392        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4393    Returns:
 4394        Command-line arguments.
 4395    """
 4396    cargs = []
 4397    cargs.extend([
 4398        "-match-bounding-box",
 4399        params.get("match_bounding_box")
 4400    ])
 4401    return cargs

 4404def c3d_maximum_params(

 4406) -> C3dMaximumParameters:
 4407    """
 4408    Build parameters.
 4409    
 4410    Args:
 4411        maximum: -max: Voxel-wise maximum of two images\
 4412            \
 4413            Syntax: `-max`\
 4414            \
 4415            Computes the voxel-wise maximum of two images. Can be used with the\
 4416            **-accum** command to compute maximum of all images.\
 4417            \
 4418            c3d i1.nii i2.nii -max -o max12.nii\
 4419            c3d i1.nii i2.nii i3.nii i4.nii -accum -max -endaccum -o\
 4420            max1234.nii.
 4421    Returns:
 4422        Parameter dictionary
 4423    """
 4424    params = {
 4425        "__STYXTYPE__": "maximum",
 4426        "maximum": maximum,
 4427    }
 4428    return params

 4452def c3d_multicomponent_split_params(
 4453    multicomponent_split: str,
 4454) -> C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters:
 4455    """
 4456    Build parameters.
 4457    
 4458    Args:
 4459        multicomponent_split: -mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of\
 4460            multi-component images on read\
 4461            \
 4462            Syntax: `-mcs`\
 4463            \
 4464            Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a\
 4465            multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined\
 4466            into a single image. Setting the **-mcs** flag changes this\
 4467            behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See\
 4468            the section below on multi-component image support.\
 4469            \
 4470            $ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor\
 4471            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1\
 4472            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66\
 4473            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29\
 4474            \
 4475            $ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor\
 4476            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198.
 4477    Returns:
 4478        Parameter dictionary
 4479    """
 4480    params = {
 4481        "__STYXTYPE__": "multicomponent_split",
 4482        "multicomponent_split": multicomponent_split,
 4483    }
 4484    return params
 4485
 4486
 4487def c3d_multicomponent_split_cargs(
 4488    params: C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters,
 4489    execution: Execution,
 4490) -> list[str]:
 4491    """
 4492    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 4493    
 4494    Args:
 4495        params: The parameters.
 4496        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4497    Returns:
 4498        Command-line arguments.
 4499    """
 4500    cargs = []
 4501    cargs.extend([
 4502        "-mcs",
 4503        params.get("multicomponent_split")
 4504    ])
 4505    return cargs
 4506

 4508def c3d_mean_params(
 4509    mean: str,
 4510) -> C3dMeanParameters:
 4511    """
 4512    Build parameters.
 4513    
 4514    Args:
 4515        mean: -mean: Mean of all images on the stack\
 4516            \
 4517            Syntax: `-mean `\
 4518            \
 4519            Computes the mean of all the images on the stack. All images on the\
 4520            stack are replaced with the mean image.\
 4521            \
 4522            c3d image_*.nii -mean -o mean.nii.
 4523    Returns:
 4524        Parameter dictionary
 4525    """
 4526    params = {
 4527        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean",
 4528        "mean": mean,
 4529    }
 4530    return params

 4554def c3d_median_filter_params(
 4555    median_filter: str,
 4556) -> C3dMedianFilterParameters:
 4557    """
 4558    Build parameters.
 4559    
 4560    Args:
 4561        median_filter: -median, -median-filter: Median filter\
 4562            \
 4563            Syntax: `-median <radius_vector>`\
 4564            \
 4565            Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced\
 4566            by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size\
 4567            specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code\
 4568            will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.\
 4569            \
 4570            c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii.
 4571    Returns:
 4572        Parameter dictionary
 4573    """
 4574    params = {
 4575        "__STYXTYPE__": "median_filter",
 4576        "median_filter": median_filter,
 4577    }
 4578    return params
 4579

 4583    execution: Execution,
 4584) -> list[str]:

 4587    
 4588    Args:
 4589        params: The parameters.
 4590        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4591    Returns:
 4592        Command-line arguments.
 4593    """
 4594    cargs = []
 4595    cargs.extend([
 4596        "-median",
 4597        params.get("median_filter")
 4598    ])

 4650    """
 4651    Build parameters.
 4652    
 4653    Args:
 4654        mean_filter: -mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter\

 4656            Syntax: `-mf <radius_vector>`\
 4657            \
 4658            Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by\
 4659            the mean of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified\
 4660            by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply\
 4661            the mean filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.\
 4662            \
 4663            c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii.
 4664    Returns:
 4665        Parameter dictionary
 4666    """
 4667    params = {
 4668        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean_filter",
 4669        "mean_filter": mean_filter,
 4670    }
 4671    return params

 4906
 4907
 4908def c3d_mean_square_params(
 4909    mean_square: str,
 4910) -> C3dMeanSquareParameters:
 4911    """
 4912    Build parameters.
 4913    
 4914    Args:
 4915        mean_square: -msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric\
 4916            \
 4917            Syntax: `-msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`\
 4918            \
 4919            Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two\
 4920            images on the stack. If an optional *movtransform.mat* file is\
 4921            provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the\
 4922            moving image. If, in addition to *movtransform.mat*, the optional\
 4923            *reftransform.mat* file is also provided -- the moving transform is\
 4924            applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the\
 4925            reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that\
 4926            is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This\
 4927            may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms\
 4928            are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of\
 4929            interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and\
 4930            the transform file format are similar to the **-reslice-matrix**\
 4931            command.\
 4932            \
 4933            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii\
 4934            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq\
 4935            \
 4936            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying\
 4937            transform to mov.nii\
 4938            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat\
 4939            \
 4940            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space\
 4941            after applying transforms to both\
 4942            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat.
 4943    Returns:
 4944        Parameter dictionary
 4945    """
 4946    params = {
 4947        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean_square",
 4948        "mean_square": mean_square,
 4949    }
 4950    return params
 4951
 4952
 4953def c3d_mean_square_cargs(
 4954    params: C3dMeanSquareParameters,
 4955    execution: Execution,
 4956) -> list[str]:
 4957    """
 4958    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 4959    
 4960    Args:
 4961        params: The parameters.
 4962        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 4963    Returns:
 4964        Command-line arguments.
 4965    """
 4966    cargs = []
 4967    cargs.extend([
 4968        "-msq",
 4969        params.get("mean_square")
 4970    ])
 4971    return cargs
 4972
 4973
 4974def c3d_multiply_params(
 4975    multiply: str,
 4976) -> C3dMultiplyParameters:
 4977    """
 4978    Build parameters.
 4979    
 4980    Args:
 4981        multiply: -multiply, -times: Multiply two images\
 4982            \
 4983            Syntax: `-multiply`\
 4984            \
 4985            Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the\
 4986            last two images on the stack.\
 4987            \
 4988            # Compute x = a * b\
 4989            c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img\
 4990            \
 4991            # Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply\
 4992            c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img\
 4993            \
 4994            Combine with the **-dup** command to compute voxelwise square of\
 4995            the image\
 4996            \
 4997            # Compute x = a^2\
 4998            c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img.
 4999    Returns:
 5000        Parameter dictionary
 5001    """
 5002    params = {
 5003        "__STYXTYPE__": "multiply",
 5004        "multiply": multiply,
 5005    }
 5006    return params
 5007
 5008
 5009def c3d_multiply_cargs(
 5010    params: C3dMultiplyParameters,
 5011    execution: Execution,
 5012) -> list[str]:
 5013    """
 5014    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5015    
 5016    Args:
 5017        params: The parameters.
 5018        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5019    Returns:
 5020        Command-line arguments.
 5021    """
 5022    cargs = []
 5023    cargs.extend([
 5024        "-multiply",
 5025        params.get("multiply")
 5026    ])
 5027    return cargs
 5028
 5029
 5030def c3d_normalized_cross_correlation_params(
 5031    normalized_cross_correlation: str,
 5032) -> C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters:
 5033    """
 5034    Build parameters.
 5035    
 5036    Args:
 5037        normalized_cross_correlation: -ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation:\
 5038            Compute normalized cross-correlation image\
 5039            \
 5040            Syntax: `-ncc <radius_vector>`\
 5041            \
 5042            Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that\
 5043            occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image\
 5044            is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the\
 5045            voxel in the two input images. This is different from **-ncor**,\
 5046            which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.
 5047    Returns:
 5048        Parameter dictionary
 5049    """
 5050    params = {
 5051        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalized_cross_correlation",
 5052        "normalized_cross_correlation": normalized_cross_correlation,
 5053    }
 5054    return params
 5055
 5056
 5057def c3d_normalized_cross_correlation_cargs(
 5058    params: C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters,
 5059    execution: Execution,
 5060) -> list[str]:
 5061    """
 5062    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5063    
 5064    Args:
 5065        params: The parameters.
 5066        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5067    Returns:
 5068        Command-line arguments.
 5069    """
 5070    cargs = []
 5071    cargs.extend([
 5072        "-ncc",
 5073        params.get("normalized_cross_correlation")
 5074    ])
 5075    return cargs
 5076
 5077
 5078def c3d_normalized_correlation_params(
 5079    normalized_correlation: str,
 5080) -> C3dNormalizedCorrelationParameters:
 5081    """
 5082    Build parameters.
 5083    
 5084    Args:
 5085        normalized_correlation: -ncor, -normalized-correlation: Compute\
 5086            normalized correlation metric\
 5087            \
 5088            Syntax: `-ncor [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`\
 5089            \
 5090            : Compute the normalized correlation metric between the last two\
 5091            images on the stack. See documentation for **-msq***.
 5092    Returns:
 5093        Parameter dictionary
 5094    """
 5095    params = {
 5096        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalized_correlation",
 5097        "normalized_correlation": normalized_correlation,
 5098    }
 5099    return params
 5100

 5112    Returns:

 5168def c3d_noise_gaussian_params(
 5169    noise_gaussian: str,
 5170) -> C3dNoiseGaussianParameters:
 5171    """
 5172    Build parameters.
 5173    
 5174    Args:
 5175        noise_gaussian: -noise-gaussian, -noise: Apply additive Gaussian noise\
 5176            \
 5177            Syntax: `-noise-gaussian <sigma>`\
 5178            \
 5179            Adds Gaussian noise to an image with zero mean and standard\
 5180            deviation sigma. Please see [Noise simulation article][15] by G.\
 5181            Lehmann for details.\
 5182            \
 5183            c3d image.nii -noise-gaussian 5 -o noisy.nii.
 5184    Returns:
 5185        Parameter dictionary
 5186    """
 5187    params = {
 5188        "__STYXTYPE__": "noise_gaussian",
 5189        "noise_gaussian": noise_gaussian,
 5190    }
 5191    return params
 5192
 5193

 5196    execution: Execution,
 5197) -> list[str]:
 5198    """

 5200    
 5201    Args:
 5202        params: The parameters.
 5203        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5204    Returns:
 5205        Command-line arguments.
 5206    """
 5207    cargs = []
 5208    cargs.extend([
 5209        "-noise-gaussian",
 5210        params.get("noise_gaussian")
 5211    ])
 5212    return cargs

 5226            see [Noise simulation article][15] by G. Lehmann for details.\

 5395
 5396def c3d_normalize_local_window_params(
 5397    normalize_local_window: str,
 5398) -> C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters:
 5399    """
 5400    Build parameters.
 5401    
 5402    Args:
 5403        normalize_local_window: -nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize\
 5404            image intensity using local neighborhood\
 5405            \
 5406            Syntax: `-nlw <radius>`\
 5407            \
 5408            This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each\
 5409            voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the\
 5410            result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood.\
 5411            The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked\
 5412            region. You might also want to multiply by the mask.\
 5413            \
 5414            c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz.
 5415    Returns:
 5416        Parameter dictionary
 5417    """
 5418    params = {
 5419        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalize_local_window",
 5420        "normalize_local_window": normalize_local_window,
 5421    }
 5422    return params
 5423
 5424
 5425def c3d_normalize_local_window_cargs(
 5426    params: C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters,
 5427    execution: Execution,
 5428) -> list[str]:
 5429    """
 5430    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5431    
 5432    Args:
 5433        params: The parameters.
 5434        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5435    Returns:
 5436        Command-line arguments.
 5437    """
 5438    cargs = []
 5439    cargs.extend([
 5440        "-nlw",
 5441        params.get("normalize_local_window")
 5442    ])
 5443    return cargs
 5444

 5484
 5485def c3d_noround_params(
 5486    noround: str,
 5487) -> C3dNoroundParameters:
 5488    """
 5489    Build parameters.
 5490    
 5491    Args:
 5492        noround: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior\
 5493            \
 5494            Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `\
 5495            \
 5496            By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when\
 5497            converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command\
 5498            specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to\
 5499            avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point\
 5500            representation.\
 5501            \
 5502            c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
 5503    Returns:
 5504        Parameter dictionary
 5505    """
 5506    params = {
 5507        "__STYXTYPE__": "noround",
 5508        "noround": noround,
 5509    }
 5510    return params
 5511
 5512
 5513def c3d_noround_cargs(
 5514    params: C3dNoroundParameters,
 5515    execution: Execution,
 5516) -> list[str]:
 5517    """
 5518    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5519    
 5520    Args:
 5521        params: The parameters.
 5522        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5523    Returns:
 5524        Command-line arguments.
 5525    """
 5526    cargs = []
 5527    cargs.extend([
 5528        "-noround",
 5529        params.get("noround")
 5530    ])
 5531    return cargs
 5532
 5533
 5534def c3d_nospm_params(
 5535    nospm: str,
 5536) -> C3dNospmParameters:
 5537    """
 5538    Build parameters.
 5539    
 5540    Args:
 5541        nospm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output\
 5542            \
 5543            Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `\
 5544            \
 5545            These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze\
 5546            (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored\
 5547            by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When\
 5548            saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default\
 5549            is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue\
 5550            altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.\
 5551            \
 5552            c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
 5553    Returns:
 5554        Parameter dictionary
 5555    """
 5556    params = {
 5557        "__STYXTYPE__": "nospm",
 5558        "nospm": nospm,
 5559    }
 5560    return params
 5561
 5562
 5563def c3d_nospm_cargs(
 5564    params: C3dNospmParameters,
 5565    execution: Execution,
 5566) -> list[str]:
 5567    """
 5568    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5569    
 5570    Args:
 5571        params: The parameters.
 5572        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5573    Returns:
 5574        Command-line arguments.
 5575    """
 5576    cargs = []
 5577    cargs.extend([
 5578        "-nospm",
 5579        params.get("nospm")
 5580    ])
 5581    return cargs
 5582
 5583
 5584class C3dOutputOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):
 5585    """
 5586    Output object returned when calling `C3dOutputParameters(...)`.
 5587    """
 5588    root: OutputPathType
 5589    """Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs."""
 5590    output: OutputPathType
 5591    """The output"""
 5592
 5593
 5594def c3d_output_params(
 5595    output: str,
 5596) -> C3dOutputParameters:
 5597    """
 5598    Build parameters.
 5599    
 5600    Args:
 5601        output: -o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file\
 5602            \
 5603            Syntax: `-o filename`\
 5604            \
 5605            Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the **-o**\
 5606            option, **convert3d** will write an image only if it does not\
 5607            exist. The **-o** options protects input images from being\
 5608            accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format:\
 5609            \
 5610            c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii\
 5611            \
 5612            The **-o** option can also be used to save an intermediate image in\
 5613            the stack:\
 5614            \
 5615            c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o\
 5616            final.img.
 5617    Returns:
 5618        Parameter dictionary
 5619    """
 5620    params = {
 5621        "__STYXTYPE__": "output",
 5622        "output": output,
 5623    }
 5624    return params
 5625
 5626
 5627def c3d_output_cargs(
 5628    params: C3dOutputParameters,
 5629    execution: Execution,
 5630) -> list[str]:
 5631    """
 5632    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5633    
 5634    Args:
 5635        params: The parameters.
 5636        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5637    Returns:
 5638        Command-line arguments.
 5639    """
 5640    cargs = []
 5641    cargs.extend([
 5642        "-o",
 5643        params.get("output")
 5644    ])
 5645    return cargs
 5646
 5647
 5648def c3d_output_outputs(
 5649    params: C3dOutputParameters,
 5650    execution: Execution,
 5651) -> C3dOutputOutputs:
 5652    """
 5653    Build outputs object containing output file paths and possibly stdout/stderr.
 5654    
 5655    Args:
 5656        params: The parameters.
 5657        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5658    Returns:
 5659        Outputs object.
 5660    """
 5661    ret = C3dOutputOutputs(
 5662        root=execution.output_file("."),
 5663        output=execution.output_file(params.get("output")),
 5664    )
 5665    return ret
 5666
 5667
 5668def c3d_output_multicomponent_params(
 5669    output_multicomponent: str,
 5670) -> C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters:
 5671    """
 5672    Build parameters.
 5673    
 5674    Args:
 5675        output_multicomponent: -omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple\
 5676            images to single file\
 5677            \
 5678            Syntax: `-omc [number] filename`\
 5679            \
 5680            Write multiple images on the **Convert3d** stack as a single\
 5681            multi-component image file. If the optional number *n* is\
 5682            specified, only the last *n* images on the stack will be used. Not\
 5683            all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the\
 5684            safest bet.\
 5685            \
 5686            c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha\
 5687            \
 5688            For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG\
 5689            files:\
 5690            \
 5691            c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc\
 5692            colorslice.png.
 5693    Returns:
 5694        Parameter dictionary
 5695    """
 5696    params = {
 5697        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multicomponent",
 5698        "output_multicomponent": output_multicomponent,
 5699    }
 5700    return params
 5701
 5702
 5703def c3d_output_multicomponent_cargs(
 5704    params: C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters,
 5705    execution: Execution,
 5706) -> list[str]:
 5707    """
 5708    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5709    
 5710    Args:
 5711        params: The parameters.
 5712        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5713    Returns:
 5714        Command-line arguments.
 5715    """
 5716    cargs = []
 5717    cargs.extend([
 5718        "-omc",
 5719        params.get("output_multicomponent")
 5720    ])
 5721    return cargs
 5722
 5723
 5724def c3d_output_multiple_multicomponent_params(
 5725    output_multiple_multicomponent: str,
 5726) -> C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters:
 5727    """
 5728    Build parameters.
 5729    
 5730    Args:
 5731        output_multiple_multicomponent: -oomc: Output multiple multi-component\
 5732            images to multiple files\
 5733            \
 5734            Syntax: `-oomc n_comp image_list` or `-oomc n_comp image_spec`\
 5735            \
 5736            Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple\
 5737            multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the\
 5738            **-omc** and **-oo** commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp'\
 5739            images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack\
 5740            will be written to a separate multi-component image.\
 5741            \
 5742            ### Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control\
 5743            \
 5744            These commands are used to manipulate the **convert3d** stack. The\
 5745            stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified\
 5746            on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the\
 5747            stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack,\
 5748            apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the\
 5749            stack. Certain commands like **-levelset** and **-reslice-matrix**\
 5750            take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace\
 5751            them with a single output. Some other commands, like **-mean** and\
 5752            **-vote** take all images on the stack and replace them with a\
 5753            single output.\
 5754            \
 5755            Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order\
 5756            of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the\
 5757            same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow\
 5758            control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving\
 5759            intermediate images to the disk.
 5760    Returns:
 5761        Parameter dictionary
 5762    """
 5763    params = {
 5764        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multiple_multicomponent",
 5765        "output_multiple_multicomponent": output_multiple_multicomponent,
 5766    }
 5767    return params
 5768
 5769
 5770def c3d_output_multiple_multicomponent_cargs(
 5771    params: C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters,
 5772    execution: Execution,
 5773) -> list[str]:
 5774    """
 5775    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5776    
 5777    Args:
 5778        params: The parameters.
 5779        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5780    Returns:
 5781        Command-line arguments.
 5782    """
 5783    cargs = []
 5784    cargs.extend([
 5785        "-oomc",
 5786        params.get("output_multiple_multicomponent")
 5787    ])
 5788    return cargs
 5789
 5790
 5791def c3d_orient_params(
 5792    orient: str,
 5793) -> C3dOrientParameters:
 5794    """
 5795    Build parameters.
 5796    
 5797    Args:
 5798        orient: -orient: Change image orientation\
 5799            \
 5800            Syntax: `-orient CODE`\
 5801            \
 5802            Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical\
 5803            orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel\
 5804            coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system\
 5805            (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of\
 5806            voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of\
 5807            voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of\
 5808            the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to\
 5809            (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to\
 5810            (S)uperior.\
 5811            \
 5812            The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters\
 5813            RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction\
 5814            corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code\
 5815            RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to\
 5816            Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.\
 5817            \
 5818            c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img\
 5819            c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img\
 5820            \
 5821            This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu\
 5822            option in ITK-SNAP.
 5823    Returns:
 5824        Parameter dictionary
 5825    """
 5826    params = {
 5827        "__STYXTYPE__": "orient",
 5828        "orient": orient,
 5829    }
 5830    return params
 5831
 5832
 5833def c3d_orient_cargs(
 5834    params: C3dOrientParameters,
 5835    execution: Execution,
 5836) -> list[str]:
 5837    """
 5838    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5839    
 5840    Args:
 5841        params: The parameters.
 5842        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5843    Returns:
 5844        Command-line arguments.
 5845    """
 5846    cargs = []
 5847    cargs.extend([
 5848        "-orient",
 5849        params.get("orient")
 5850    ])
 5851    return cargs
 5852
 5853
 5854def c3d_output_multiple_params(
 5855    output_multiple: str,
 5856) -> C3dOutputMultipleParameters:
 5857    """
 5858    Build parameters.
 5859    
 5860    Args:
 5861        output_multiple: -oo: Output multiple images to multiple files\
 5862            \
 5863            Syntax: `-oo image_list` or `-oo image_spec`\
 5864            \
 5865            Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple files.\
 5866            There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a\
 5867            list of file names, separated by spaces:\
 5868            \
 5869            c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii\
 5870            \
 5871            In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be\
 5872            saved as *labelC.nii*, the image next to the end of the stack will\
 5873            be saved as *labelB.nii* and so on.\
 5874            \
 5875            The second way to use the **-oo** command is to supply a pattern\
 5876            for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack\
 5877            will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the\
 5878            [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command\
 5879            \
 5880            c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii\
 5881            \
 5882            will generate images *label00.nii*, *label01.nii*, *label02.nii*\
 5883            and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest\
 5884            number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have\
 5885            number 00.
 5886    Returns:
 5887        Parameter dictionary
 5888    """
 5889    params = {
 5890        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multiple",
 5891        "output_multiple": output_multiple,
 5892    }
 5893    return params
 5894
 5895
 5896def c3d_output_multiple_cargs(
 5897    params: C3dOutputMultipleParameters,
 5898    execution: Execution,
 5899) -> list[str]:
 5900    """
 5901    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 5902    
 5903    Args:
 5904        params: The parameters.
 5905        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 5906    Returns:
 5907        Command-line arguments.
 5908    """
 5909    cargs = []
 5910    cargs.extend([
 5911        "-oo",
 5912        params.get("output_multiple")
 5913    ])
 5914    return cargs
 5915
 5916
 5917def c3d_orient_1_params(
 5918    orient: str,
 5919) -> C3dOrient1Parameters:
 5920    """
 5921    Build parameters.
 5922    
 5923    Args:
 5924        orient: -orient: Change image orientation\
 5925            \
 5926            Syntax: `-orient CODE`\
 5927            \
 5928            Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical\
 5929            orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel\
 5930            coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system\
 5931            (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of\
 5932            voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of\
 5933            voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of\
 5934            the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to\
 5935            (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to\
 5936            (S)uperior.\
 5937            \
 5938            The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters\
 5939            RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction\
 5940            corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code\
 5941            RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to\
 5942            Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.\
 5943            \
 5944            c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img\
 5945            c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img\
 5946            \
 5947            This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu\
 5948            option in ITK-SNAP.
 5949    Returns:
 5950        Parameter dictionary
 5951    """
 5952    params = {
 5953        "__STYXTYPE__": "orient_1",
 5954        "orient": orient,
 5955    }
 5956    return params
 5957
 5958

 5979
 5980def c3d_origin_params(
 5981    origin: str,
 5982) -> C3dOriginParameters:
 5983    """
 5984    Build parameters.
 5985    
 5986    Args:
 5987        origin: -origin: Set image origin\
 5988            \
 5989            Syntax: `-origin vector `\
 5990            \
 5991            Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in\
 5992            NIfTI coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the\
 5993            image. The origin should be specified in millimeters.\
 5994            \
 5995            c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img.
 5996    Returns:
 5997        Parameter dictionary
 5998    """
 5999    params = {
 6000        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin",
 6001        "origin": origin,
 6002    }
 6003    return params
 6004
 6005
 6006def c3d_origin_cargs(
 6007    params: C3dOriginParameters,
 6008    execution: Execution,
 6009) -> list[str]:
 6010    """
 6011    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6012    
 6013    Args:
 6014        params: The parameters.
 6015        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6016    Returns:
 6017        Command-line arguments.
 6018    """
 6019    cargs = []
 6020    cargs.extend([
 6021        "-origin",
 6022        params.get("origin")
 6023    ])
 6024    return cargs
 6025

 6027def c3d_origin_voxel_params(
 6028    origin_voxel: str,
 6029) -> C3dOriginVoxelParameters:
 6030    """
 6031    Build parameters.
 6032    
 6033    Args:
 6034        origin_voxel: -origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel\
 6035            \
 6036            Syntax: `-origin-voxel vector `\
 6037            \
 6038            Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of\
 6039            the center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector\
 6040            should be specified in voxel units.\
 6041            \
 6042            c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img\
 6043            c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img # image centered\
 6044            around origin.
 6045    Returns:
 6046        Parameter dictionary
 6047    """
 6048    params = {
 6049        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin_voxel",
 6050        "origin_voxel": origin_voxel,
 6051    }
 6052    return params
 6053

 6076def c3d_origin_voxel_coord_params(
 6077    origin_voxel_coord: str,
 6078) -> C3dOriginVoxelCoordParameters:
 6079    """
 6080    Build parameters.
 6081    
 6082    Args:
 6083        origin_voxel_coord: -origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified\
 6084            voxel\
 6085            \
 6086            Syntax: `-origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>`\
 6087            \
 6088            This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed\
 6089            voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the\
 6090            command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of\
 6091            the center voxel of the image, as follows:\
 6092            \
 6093            c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii.
 6094    Returns:
 6095        Parameter dictionary
 6096    """
 6097    params = {
 6098        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin_voxel_coord",
 6099        "origin_voxel_coord": origin_voxel_coord,
 6100    }
 6101    return params
 6102

 6114    Returns:

 6120        params.get("origin_voxel_coord")
 6121    ])
 6122    return cargs

 6124
 6125def c3d_overlap_params(
 6126    overlap: str,
 6127) -> C3dOverlapParameters:
 6128    """
 6129    Build parameters.
 6130    
 6131    Args:
 6132        overlap: -overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images\
 6133            \
 6134            Syntax: `-overlap Z`\
 6135            \
 6136            Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on\
 6137            the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label **Z**, i.e., the\
 6138            number of voxels that are equal to **Z** in both images is computed\
 6139            and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to **Z**\
 6140            in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the\
 6141            region where at least one of the images is equal to **Z** (Jaccard\
 6142            coefficient).\
 6143            \
 6144            The command below computes overlap for label 255.\
 6145            \
 6146            c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255\
 6147            \
 6148            The output of the command is in the following terse format, with\
 6149            the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients,\
 6150            respectively.\
 6151            \
 6152            OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459\
 6153            \
 6154            Use the flag **-verbose** to get full information.\
 6155            \
 6156            Matching voxels in first image: 2383\
 6157            Matching voxels in second image: 2474\
 6158            Size of overlap region: 1807\
 6159            Dice similarity coefficient: 0.744081\
 6160            Intersection / ratio: 0.592459\
 6161            \
 6162            This command does not alter the stack.
 6163    Returns:
 6164        Parameter dictionary
 6165    """
 6166    params = {
 6167        "__STYXTYPE__": "overlap",
 6168        "overlap": overlap,
 6169    }
 6170    return params
 6171
 6172
 6173def c3d_overlap_cargs(
 6174    params: C3dOverlapParameters,
 6175    execution: Execution,
 6176) -> list[str]:
 6177    """
 6178    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6179    
 6180    Args:
 6181        params: The parameters.
 6182        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6183    Returns:
 6184        Command-line arguments.
 6185    """
 6186    cargs = []
 6187    cargs.extend([
 6188        "-overlap",
 6189        params.get("overlap")
 6190    ])
 6191    return cargs
 6192
 6193
 6194def c3d_overlay_label_image_params(
 6195    overlay_label_image: str,
 6196) -> C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters:
 6197    """
 6198    Build parameters.
 6199    
 6200    Args:
 6201        overlay_label_image: -oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation\
 6202            image on grayscale image\
 6203            \
 6204            Syntax: `-oli lookup_table_file opacity`\
 6205            \
 6206            This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image\
 6207            with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue\
 6208            components of a color image. The resulting color image is an\
 6209            overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter\
 6210            (*lookup\\_table*) is a text file with entries in the format\
 6211            \
 6212            label_value red green blue alpha\
 6213            \
 6214            Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values\
 6215            should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image\
 6216            (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and\
 6217            can be generated using the ITK-SNAP `Segmentation->Save Label\
 6218            Descriptions` command. The second parameter (*opacity*) is between\
 6219            0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of\
 6220            this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation\
 6221            data on top of grayscale images.\
 6222            \
 6223            c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli\
 6224            labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz\
 6225            \
 6226            Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the\
 6227            lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous\
 6228            intensity spectrum.\
 6229            \
 6230            Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation\
 6231            result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and\
 6232            segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map\
 6233            intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices\
 6234            through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on\
 6235            the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file.\
 6236            \
 6237            c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0\
 6238            255 -clip 0 255 \\\\\
 6239            -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor\
 6240            \\\\\
 6241            -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png.
 6242    Returns:
 6243        Parameter dictionary
 6244    """
 6245    params = {
 6246        "__STYXTYPE__": "overlay_label_image",
 6247        "overlay_label_image": overlay_label_image,
 6248    }
 6249    return params
 6250
 6251
 6252def c3d_overlay_label_image_cargs(
 6253    params: C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters,
 6254    execution: Execution,
 6255) -> list[str]:
 6256    """
 6257    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6258    
 6259    Args:
 6260        params: The parameters.
 6261        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6262    Returns:
 6263        Command-line arguments.
 6264    """
 6265    cargs = []
 6266    cargs.extend([
 6267        "-overlay-label-image",
 6268        params.get("overlay_label_image")
 6269    ])
 6270    return cargs
 6271
 6272
 6273def c3d_pad_params(
 6274    pad: str,
 6275) -> C3dPadParameters:
 6276    """
 6277    Build parameters.
 6278    
 6279    Args:
 6280        pad: -pad: Pad image with constant value\
 6281            \
 6282            Syntax: `-pad <padlower> <padupper> <value> `\
 6283            \
 6284            Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The\
 6285            *padlower* dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and\
 6286            the *padupper* dimension pads along the upper faces of the image.\
 6287            For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do\
 6288            \
 6289            c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii\
 6290            \
 6291            while\
 6292            \
 6293            c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii\
 6294            \
 6295            adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four\
 6296            slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument\
 6297            changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the\
 6298            output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment\
 6299            between the padded and original images.\
 6300            \
 6301            Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any\
 6302            constant value, eg :\
 6303            \
 6304            c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii\
 6305            \
 6306            Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with\
 6307            the value 1.
 6308    Returns:
 6309        Parameter dictionary
 6310    """
 6311    params = {
 6312        "__STYXTYPE__": "pad",
 6313        "pad": pad,
 6314    }
 6315    return params
 6316
 6317
 6318def c3d_pad_cargs(
 6319    params: C3dPadParameters,
 6320    execution: Execution,
 6321) -> list[str]:
 6322    """
 6323    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6324    
 6325    Args:
 6326        params: The parameters.
 6327        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6328    Returns:
 6329        Command-line arguments.
 6330    """
 6331    cargs = []
 6332    cargs.extend([
 6333        "-pad",
 6334        params.get("pad")
 6335    ])
 6336    return cargs
 6337
 6338
 6339def c3d_pad_to_params(
 6340    pad_to: str,
 6341) -> C3dPadToParameters:
 6342    """
 6343    Build parameters.
 6344    
 6345    Args:
 6346        pad_to: No description found.
 6347    Returns:
 6348        Parameter dictionary
 6349    """
 6350    params = {
 6351        "__STYXTYPE__": "pad_to",
 6352        "pad_to": pad_to,
 6353    }
 6354    return params
 6355
 6356
 6357def c3d_pad_to_cargs(
 6358    params: C3dPadToParameters,
 6359    execution: Execution,
 6360) -> list[str]:
 6361    """
 6362    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6363    
 6364    Args:
 6365        params: The parameters.
 6366        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6367    Returns:
 6368        Command-line arguments.
 6369    """
 6370    cargs = []
 6371    cargs.extend([
 6372        "-padto",
 6373        params.get("pad_to")
 6374    ])
 6375    return cargs
 6376
 6377
 6378def c3d_pca_params(
 6379    pca: str,
 6380) -> C3dPcaParameters:
 6381    """
 6382    Build parameters.
 6383    
 6384    Args:
 6385        pca: -pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels\
 6386            \
 6387            Syntax: `-pca`\
 6388            \
 6389            Similar to the *-centroid* command, computes the centroid and\
 6390            prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For\
 6391            example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will\
 6392            report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in\
 6393            physical NIFTI coordinates.\
 6394            \
 6395            c3d binaryimage.img -pca // centroid of all non-0 voxels\
 6396            c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca // centroid of all voxels\
 6397            with label 5\
 6398            c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor // centroids of all\
 6399            labels (including 0).
 6400    Returns:
 6401        Parameter dictionary
 6402    """
 6403    params = {
 6404        "__STYXTYPE__": "pca",
 6405        "pca": pca,
 6406    }
 6407    return params
 6408
 6409
 6410def c3d_pca_cargs(
 6411    params: C3dPcaParameters,
 6412    execution: Execution,
 6413) -> list[str]:
 6414    """
 6415    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6416    
 6417    Args:
 6418        params: The parameters.
 6419        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6420    Returns:
 6421        Command-line arguments.
 6422    """
 6423    cargs = []
 6424    cargs.extend([
 6425        "-pca",
 6426        params.get("pca")
 6427    ])
 6428    return cargs
 6429
 6430
 6431def c3d_percent_intensity_mode_params(
 6432    percent_intensity_mode: str,
 6433) -> C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters:
 6434    """
 6435    Build parameters.
 6436    
 6437    Args:
 6438        percent_intensity_mode: -pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of\
 6439            % specifier\
 6440            \
 6441            Syntax: `-pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r`\
 6442            \
 6443            This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when\
 6444            specifying intensity values. **Quantile (q)** means that `10%`\
 6445            describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image\
 6446            (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity).\
 6447            **ForegroundQuantile (fq)** is similar, but voxels with background\
 6448            intensity (see **-background** option) are excluded from the\
 6449            percentile computation. **Range (r)** changes the meaning of\
 6450            percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and\
 6451            maximum of the image, and `0.1%` becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX -\
 6452            MIN). The default is **Quantile**.\
 6453            \
 6454            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf\
 6455            1 0\
 6456            Quantile 0.75 maps to 18\
 6457            \
 6458            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose\
 6459            -threshold 75% inf 1 0\
 6460            Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58\
 6461            \
 6462            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1\
 6463            0\
 6464            Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25.
 6465    Returns:
 6466        Parameter dictionary
 6467    """
 6468    params = {
 6469        "__STYXTYPE__": "percent_intensity_mode",
 6470        "percent_intensity_mode": percent_intensity_mode,
 6471    }
 6472    return params
 6473
 6474
 6475def c3d_percent_intensity_mode_cargs(
 6476    params: C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters,
 6477    execution: Execution,
 6478) -> list[str]:
 6479    """
 6480    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6481    
 6482    Args:
 6483        params: The parameters.
 6484        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6485    Returns:
 6486        Command-line arguments.
 6487    """
 6488    cargs = []
 6489    cargs.extend([
 6490        "-percent-intensity-mode",
 6491        params.get("percent_intensity_mode")
 6492    ])
 6493    return cargs
 6494

 6535def c3d_pop_params(
 6536    pop_: str,
 6537) -> C3dPopParameters:
 6538    """
 6539    Build parameters.
 6540    
 6541    Args:
 6542        pop_: -pop: Remove last image from the stack\
 6543            \
 6544            Syntax: `-pop`\
 6545            \
 6546            Removes the last image from the image stack. Images assigned a name\
 6547            with the **-as** command will remain in memory.
 6548    Returns:
 6549        Parameter dictionary
 6550    """
 6551    params = {
 6552        "__STYXTYPE__": "pop",
 6553        "pop": pop_,
 6554    }
 6555    return params
 6556

 6579def c3d_popas_params(
 6580    popas: str,
 6581) -> C3dPopasParameters:
 6582    """
 6583    Build parameters.
 6584    
 6585    Args:
 6586        popas: -popas: Remove last image from the stack and assign to variable\
 6587            \
 6588            Syntax: `-popas var`\
 6589            \
 6590            Removes the last image from the stack, but also assigns it the name\
 6591            'var', keeping the image in memory. Same as calling **-as** *var*\
 6592            followed by **-pop**.
 6593    Returns:
 6594        Parameter dictionary
 6595    """
 6596    params = {
 6597        "__STYXTYPE__": "popas",
 6598        "popas": popas,
 6599    }
 6600    return params
 6601
 6602

 6609    
 6610    Args:
 6611        params: The parameters.
 6612        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6613    Returns:
 6614        Command-line arguments.
 6615    """
 6616    cargs = []
 6617    cargs.extend([
 6618        "-popas",
 6619        params.get("popas")
 6620    ])
 6621    return cargs

 6624def c3d_probe_params(
 6625    probe: str,
 6626) -> C3dProbeParameters:
 6627    """
 6628    Build parameters.
 6629    
 6630    Args:
 6631        probe: -probe: Report image intensity at a voxel\
 6632            \
 6633            Syntax: `-probe <point_spec>`\
 6634            \
 6635            Prints the value of the image at the position specified by the\
 6636            parameter `point_spec`, which may be in physical units or voxel\
 6637            units:\
 6638            \
 6639            c3d img1.img -probe 128x120x160vox\
 6640            c3d img1.img -interpolation NearestNeighbor -probe 60x60x60mm\
 6641            c3d img1.img -probe 50%.
 6642    Returns:
 6643        Parameter dictionary
 6644    """
 6645    params = {
 6646        "__STYXTYPE__": "probe",
 6647        "probe": probe,
 6648    }
 6649    return params
 6650

 6672
 6673def c3d_push_params(
 6674    push: str,
 6675) -> C3dPushParameters:
 6676    """
 6677    Build parameters.
 6678    
 6679    Args:
 6680        push: -push: Place variable at the end of the stack\
 6681            \
 6682            Syntax: `-push var`\
 6683            \
 6684            Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the\
 6685            image stack. Variable names are assigned using the **-as** command.\
 6686            The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use\
 6687            a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For\
 6688            example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary\
 6689            image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image\
 6690            region have value 0, you would use the following command:\
 6691            \
 6692            c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img.
 6693    Returns:
 6694        Parameter dictionary
 6695    """
 6696    params = {
 6697        "__STYXTYPE__": "push",
 6698        "push": push,
 6699    }
 6700    return params
 6701
 6702
 6703def c3d_push_cargs(
 6704    params: C3dPushParameters,
 6705    execution: Execution,
 6706) -> list[str]:
 6707    """
 6708    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6709    
 6710    Args:
 6711        params: The parameters.
 6712        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6713    Returns:
 6714        Command-line arguments.
 6715    """
 6716    cargs = []
 6717    cargs.extend([
 6718        "-push",
 6719        params.get("push")
 6720    ])
 6721    return cargs
 6722
 6723
 6724def c3d_rank_params(
 6725    rank: str,
 6726) -> C3dRankParameters:
 6727    """
 6728    Build parameters.
 6729    
 6730    Args:
 6731        rank: -rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values\
 6732            \
 6733            Syntax: `-rank `\
 6734            \
 6735            This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the\
 6736            stack are used). It also generates N images as the output. For\
 6737            voxel k in image j, it assigns it a label based on its rank among\
 6738            the values of voxel k in all N images. If the voxel has highest\
 6739            intensity in image j, then the j'th output will have value 1.\
 6740            \
 6741            c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img.
 6742    Returns:
 6743        Parameter dictionary
 6744    """
 6745    params = {
 6746        "__STYXTYPE__": "rank",
 6747        "rank": rank,
 6748    }
 6749    return params
 6750
 6751
 6752def c3d_rank_cargs(
 6753    params: C3dRankParameters,
 6754    execution: Execution,
 6755) -> list[str]:
 6756    """
 6757    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6758    
 6759    Args:
 6760        params: The parameters.
 6761        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6762    Returns:
 6763        Command-line arguments.
 6764    """
 6765    cargs = []
 6766    cargs.extend([
 6767        "-rank",
 6768        params.get("rank")
 6769    ])
 6770    return cargs
 6771

 6785            / A, use the command\

 6789        Parameter dictionary
 6790    """
 6791    params = {
 6792        "__STYXTYPE__": "reciprocal",
 6793        "reciprocal": reciprocal,
 6794    }
 6795    return params

 6820    region: str,

 6823    Build parameters.

 6825    Args:

 6829            \
 6830            Extract a rectangular region from the image. The first parameter is\
 6831            the position of the corner of the region, and the second is the\
 6832            size of the region.\
 6833            \
 6834            c3d img1.img -region 20x20x20vox 50x60x70vox -o img2.img\
 6835            c3d img1.img -region 25% 50% -o img3.img.
 6836    Returns:
 6837        Parameter dictionary
 6838    """
 6839    params = {
 6840        "__STYXTYPE__": "region",
 6841        "region": region,
 6842    }
 6843    return params
