 6865
 6866
 6867def c3d_reorder_params(
 6868    reorder: str,
 6869) -> C3dReorderParameters:
 6870    """
 6871    Build parameters.
 6872    
 6873    Args:
 6874        reorder: -reorder: Rearrange images on the stack\
 6875            \
 6876            Syntax: `-reorder k` or `-reorder fraction`\
 6877            \
 6878            Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k\
 6879            positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other\
 6880            words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new\
 6881            order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ...,\
 6882            k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an\
 6883            alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point\
 6884            number (i.e., **-reorder** 0.5), in which case k is obtained by\
 6885            multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the\
 6886            nearest integer.\
 6887            \
 6888            The following three commands are equivalent:\
 6889            \
 6890            c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii\
 6891            -reorder 4 ...\
 6892            c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii\
 6893            -reorder 0.5 ...\
 6894            c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...\
 6895            \
 6896            The **-reorder** command us useful when you specify two sets of\
 6897            images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations\
 6898            on the images. For example\
 6899            \
 6900            c3d weight*.nii gray*.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o\
 6901            wsum.nii\
 6902            \
 6903            is equivalent to the command\
 6904            \
 6905            c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ...\
 6906            -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii.
 6907    Returns:
 6908        Parameter dictionary
 6909    """
 6910    params = {
 6911        "__STYXTYPE__": "reorder",
 6912        "reorder": reorder,
 6913    }
 6914    return params
 6915
 6916
 6917def c3d_reorder_cargs(
 6918    params: C3dReorderParameters,
 6919    execution: Execution,
 6920) -> list[str]:
 6921    """
 6922    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6923    
 6924    Args:
 6925        params: The parameters.
 6926        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6927    Returns:
 6928        Command-line arguments.
 6929    """
 6930    cargs = []
 6931    cargs.extend([
 6932        "-reorder",
 6933        params.get("reorder")
 6934    ])
 6935    return cargs
 6936
 6937
 6938def c3d_retain_labels_params(
 6939    retain_labels: str,
 6940) -> C3dRetainLabelsParameters:
 6941    """
 6942    Build parameters.
 6943    
 6944    Args:
 6945        retain_labels: -retain-labels: Retain labels in a label image\
 6946            \
 6947            Syntax: `-retain-labels I1 I2 ... IN`\
 6948            \
 6949            Assuming that the input is a multi-label segmentation image, this\
 6950            command keeps all labels specifed in the list and replaces the\
 6951            remaining labels with the background value.\
 6952            \
 6953            c3d seg.nii -retain-labels 2 3 4 8 -o subseg.nii.
 6954    Returns:
 6955        Parameter dictionary
 6956    """
 6957    params = {
 6958        "__STYXTYPE__": "retain_labels",
 6959        "retain_labels": retain_labels,
 6960    }
 6961    return params
 6962
 6963
 6964def c3d_retain_labels_cargs(
 6965    params: C3dRetainLabelsParameters,
 6966    execution: Execution,
 6967) -> list[str]:
 6968    """
 6969    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 6970    
 6971    Args:
 6972        params: The parameters.
 6973        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 6974    Returns:
 6975        Command-line arguments.
 6976    """
 6977    cargs = []
 6978    cargs.extend([
 6979        "-retain-labels",
 6980        params.get("retain_labels")
 6981    ])
 6982    return cargs
 6983
 6984
 6985def c3d_rf_apply_params(
 6986    rf_apply: str,
 6987) -> C3dRfApplyParameters:
 6988    """
 6989    Build parameters.
 6990    
 6991    Args:
 6992        rf_apply: -rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier\
 6993            \
 6994            Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`\
 6995            \
 6996            This command applies a classifier trained previously by\
 6997            **-rf-train**. The stack must contain the same number of feature\
 6998            images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack\
 6999            and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the\
 7000            number of classes during training. See examples under **-rf-train**\
 7001            for usage.
 7002    Returns:
 7003        Parameter dictionary
 7004    """
 7005    params = {
 7006        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_apply",
 7007        "rf_apply": rf_apply,
 7008    }
 7009    return params
 7010
 7011
 7012def c3d_rf_apply_cargs(
 7013    params: C3dRfApplyParameters,
 7014    execution: Execution,
 7015) -> list[str]:
 7016    """
 7017    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7018    
 7019    Args:
 7020        params: The parameters.
 7021        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7022    Returns:
 7023        Command-line arguments.
 7024    """
 7025    cargs = []
 7026    cargs.extend([
 7027        "-rf-apply",
 7028        params.get("rf_apply")
 7029    ])
 7030    return cargs
 7031
 7032
 7033def c3d_rf_train_params(
 7034    rf_train: str,
 7035) -> C3dRfTrainParameters:
 7036    """
 7037    Build parameters.
 7038    
 7039    Args:
 7040        rf_train: -rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier\
 7041            \
 7042            Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`\
 7043            \
 7044            This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the\
 7045            [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with\
 7046            modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The\
 7047            stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale\
 7048            images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at\
 7049            least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The\
 7050            classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with\
 7051            label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier\
 7052            is output to a binary file that can later be used by the\
 7053            **-rf-apply** command. Multiple parameters can be specified with\
 7054            the **-rf-param-xxx** options before calling **-rf-train**. The\
 7055            stack is not modified by this command.\
 7056            \
 7057            # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default\
 7058            parameters\
 7059            c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf\
 7060            \
 7061            # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)\
 7062            c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train\
 7063            myforest2.rf\
 7064            \
 7065            # Applying the classifier\
 7066            c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz\
 7067            \
 7068            The commands are meant to replicate the "classification"\
 7069            pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example\
 7070            segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use\
 7071            the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple\
 7072            subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images\
 7073            from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be\
 7074            stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:\
 7075            \
 7076            # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects\
 7077            c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \\\
 7078            seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \\\
 7079            -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \\\
 7080            -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf\
 7081            \
 7082            # Apply using single MRI\
 7083            c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii\
 7084            \
 7085            [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning,\
 7086            45(1), 5-32.\
 7087            [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for\
 7088            computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science &\
 7089            Business Media.
 7090    Returns:
 7091        Parameter dictionary
 7092    """
 7093    params = {
 7094        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_train",
 7095        "rf_train": rf_train,
 7096    }
 7097    return params
 7098
 7099
 7100def c3d_rf_train_cargs(
 7101    params: C3dRfTrainParameters,
 7102    execution: Execution,
 7103) -> list[str]:
 7104    """
 7105    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7106    
 7107    Args:
 7108        params: The parameters.
 7109        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7110    Returns:
 7111        Command-line arguments.
 7112    """
 7113    cargs = []
 7114    cargs.extend([
 7115        "-rf-train",
 7116        params.get("rf_train")
 7117    ])
 7118    return cargs
 7119
 7120
 7121def c3d_rf_param_patch_params(
 7122    rf_param_patch: str,
 7123) -> C3dRfParamPatchParameters:
 7124    """
 7125    Build parameters.
 7126    
 7127    Args:
 7128        rf_param_patch: -rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size\
 7129            \
 7130            Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`\
 7131            \
 7132            Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF\
 7133            classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the\
 7134            intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to\
 7135            non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being\
 7136            used as features, and can improve classification in presence of\
 7137            complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 *\
 7138            radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.\
 7139            \
 7140            # Set patch size to 5x5x5\
 7141            c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf.
 7142    Returns:
 7143        Parameter dictionary
 7144    """
 7145    params = {
 7146        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_patch",
 7147        "rf_param_patch": rf_param_patch,
 7148    }
 7149    return params
 7150
 7151
 7152def c3d_rf_param_patch_cargs(
 7153    params: C3dRfParamPatchParameters,
 7154    execution: Execution,
 7155) -> list[str]:
 7156    """
 7157    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7158    
 7159    Args:
 7160        params: The parameters.
 7161        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7162    Returns:
 7163        Command-line arguments.
 7164    """
 7165    cargs = []
 7166    cargs.extend([
 7167        "-rf-param-patch",
 7168        params.get("rf_param_patch")
 7169    ])
 7170    return cargs
 7171
 7172
 7173def c3d_rf_param_usexyz_params(
 7174    rf_param_usexyz: str,
 7175) -> C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters:
 7176    """
 7177    Build parameters.
 7178    
 7179    Args:
 7180        rf_param_usexyz: -rf-param-usexyz: Random Forest coordinate features\
 7181            \
 7182            Syntax: `-rf-param-usexyz`\
 7183            \
 7184            Use the coordinates of voxels as additional features. This allows\
 7185            some geometric relations between different labels to be learned.\
 7186            Equivalent to the corresponding ITK-SNAP option.
 7187    Returns:
 7188        Parameter dictionary
 7189    """
 7190    params = {
 7191        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_usexyz",
 7192        "rf_param_usexyz": rf_param_usexyz,
 7193    }
 7194    return params
 7195
 7196
 7197def c3d_rf_param_usexyz_cargs(
 7198    params: C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters,
 7199    execution: Execution,
 7200) -> list[str]:
 7201    """
 7202    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7203    
 7204    Args:
 7205        params: The parameters.
 7206        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7207    Returns:
 7208        Command-line arguments.
 7209    """
 7210    cargs = []
 7211    cargs.extend([
 7212        "-rf-param-usexyz",
 7213        params.get("rf_param_usexyz")
 7214    ])
 7215    return cargs
 7216

 7257def c3d_rf_param_ntrees_params(
 7258    rf_param_ntrees: str,
 7259) -> C3dRfParamNtreesParameters:
 7260    """
 7261    Build parameters.
 7262    
 7263    Args:
 7264        rf_param_ntrees: -rf-param-ntrees: Random Forest forest size\
 7265            \
 7266            Syntax: `-rf-param-ntrees <integer>`\
 7267            \
 7268            Sets the number of trees in the forest. Default value is 50. Larger\
 7269            forests are more robust but more time to train and apply.
 7270    Returns:
 7271        Parameter dictionary
 7272    """
 7273    params = {
 7274        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_ntrees",
 7275        "rf_param_ntrees": rf_param_ntrees,
 7276    }
 7277    return params
 7278

 7305    Build parameters.
 7306    
 7307    Args:
 7308        rf_param_treedepth: -rf-param-treedepth: Random Forest tree depth\
 7309            \
 7310            Syntax: `-rf-param-treedepth <integer>`\
 7311            \
 7312            Sets the depth of the trees in the classifier. Default value is 30.\
 7313            Deeper trees can learn on more complex data but require more time.
 7314    Returns:
 7315        Parameter dictionary
 7316    """
 7317    params = {
 7318        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_treedepth",
 7319        "rf_param_treedepth": rf_param_treedepth,
 7320    }

 7389def c3d_replace_params(
 7390    replace: str,
 7391) -> C3dReplaceParameters:
 7392    """
 7393    Build parameters.
 7394    
 7395    Args:
 7396        replace: -replace: Replace intensities in image\
 7397            \
 7398            Syntax: `-replace I1 J1 I2 J2 ... `\
 7399            \
 7400            Replace intensity I1 by J1, I2 by J2 and so on. Allowed values of\
 7401            intensity include **nan**, **inf** and **-inf**.\
 7402            \
 7403            c3d img1.img -replace 1 128 nan 0.0 -o img2.img.
 7404    Returns:
 7405        Parameter dictionary
 7406    """
 7407    params = {
 7408        "__STYXTYPE__": "replace",
 7409        "replace": replace,
 7410    }
 7411    return params
 7412

 7415    params: C3dReplaceParameters,

 7420    
 7421    Args:
 7422        params: The parameters.
 7423        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7424    Returns:
 7425        Command-line arguments.
 7426    """
 7427    cargs = []
 7428    cargs.extend([
 7429        "-replace",
 7430        params.get("replace")
 7431    ])
 7432    return cargs
 7433
 7434
 7435def c3d_resample_params(
 7436    resample: str,
 7437) -> C3dResampleParameters:
 7438    """
 7439    Build parameters.
 7440    
 7441    Args:
 7442        resample: -resample: Resample image to new dimensions\
 7443            \
 7444            Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `\
 7445            \
 7446            Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but\
 7447            changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be\
 7448            specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of\
 7449            voxels in each direction. The **-interpolation** flag affects how\
 7450            sampling is performed.\
 7451            \
 7452            c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img\
 7453            c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img\
 7454            c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img\
 7455            c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample\
 7456            123x142x200 -o img2.img.
 7457    Returns:
 7458        Parameter dictionary
 7459    """
 7460    params = {
 7461        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample",
 7462        "resample": resample,
 7463    }
 7464    return params
 7465
 7466
 7467def c3d_resample_cargs(
 7468    params: C3dResampleParameters,
 7469    execution: Execution,
 7470) -> list[str]:
 7471    """
 7472    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7473    
 7474    Args:
 7475        params: The parameters.
 7476        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7477    Returns:
 7478        Command-line arguments.
 7479    """
 7480    cargs = []
 7481    cargs.extend([
 7482        "-resample",
 7483        params.get("resample")
 7484    ])
 7485    return cargs
 7486
 7487
 7488def c3d_resample_iso_params(
 7489    resample_iso: str,
 7490) -> C3dResampleIsoParameters:
 7491    """
 7492    Build parameters.
 7493    
 7494    Args:
 7495        resample_iso: -resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately)\
 7496            isotropic resolution\
 7497            \
 7498            Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`\
 7499            \
 7500            Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution,\
 7501            either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or\
 7502            largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls\
 7503            **-resample** with appropriately calculated new image dimensions.\
 7504            The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved.\
 7505            Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual\
 7506            voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic.\
 7507            \
 7508            c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img.
 7509    Returns:
 7510        Parameter dictionary
 7511    """
 7512    params = {
 7513        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample_iso",
 7514        "resample_iso": resample_iso,
 7515    }
 7516    return params
 7517
 7518
 7519def c3d_resample_iso_cargs(
 7520    params: C3dResampleIsoParameters,
 7521    execution: Execution,
 7522) -> list[str]:
 7523    """
 7524    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7525    
 7526    Args:
 7527        params: The parameters.
 7528        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7529    Returns:
 7530        Command-line arguments.
 7531    """
 7532    cargs = []
 7533    cargs.extend([
 7534        "-resample-iso",
 7535        params.get("resample_iso")
 7536    ])
 7537    return cargs
 7538
 7539
 7540def c3d_resample_mm_params(
 7541    resample_mm: str,
 7542) -> C3dResampleMmParameters:
 7543    """
 7544    Build parameters.
 7545    
 7546    Args:
 7547        resample_mm: -resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution\
 7548            \
 7549            Syntax: `-resample-mm <voxel_size> `\
 7550            \
 7551            Resamples the image as in **-resample**, but the user specifies the\
 7552            new voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so\
 7553            the bounding box of the image may change. A warning will be\
 7554            generated in that case.\
 7555            \
 7556            c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img.
 7557    Returns:
 7558        Parameter dictionary
 7559    """
 7560    params = {
 7561        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample_mm",
 7562        "resample_mm": resample_mm,
 7563    }
 7564    return params
 7565
 7566
 7567def c3d_resample_mm_cargs(
 7568    params: C3dResampleMmParameters,
 7569    execution: Execution,
 7570) -> list[str]:
 7571    """
 7572    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7573    
 7574    Args:
 7575        params: The parameters.
 7576        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7577    Returns:
 7578        Command-line arguments.
 7579    """
 7580    cargs = []
 7581    cargs.extend([
 7582        "-resample-mm",
 7583        params.get("resample_mm")
 7584    ])
 7585    return cargs

 7670
 7671def c3d_reslice_identity_params(
 7672    reslice_identity: str,
 7673) -> C3dResliceIdentityParameters:
 7674    """
 7675    Build parameters.
 7676    
 7677    Args:
 7678        reslice_identity: -reslice-identity: Resample image using identity\
 7679            transform\
 7680            \
 7681            Syntax: `-reslice-identity `\
 7682            \
 7683            Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity\
 7684            transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same\
 7685            subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space\
 7686            and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For\
 7687            example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate\
 7688            frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1\
 7689            \
 7690            c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii.
 7691    Returns:
 7692        Parameter dictionary
 7693    """
 7694    params = {
 7695        "__STYXTYPE__": "reslice_identity",
 7696        "reslice_identity": reslice_identity,
 7697    }
 7698    return params
 7699
 7700
 7701def c3d_reslice_identity_cargs(
 7702    params: C3dResliceIdentityParameters,
 7703    execution: Execution,
 7704) -> list[str]:
 7705    """
 7706    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7707    
 7708    Args:
 7709        params: The parameters.
 7710        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7711    Returns:
 7712        Command-line arguments.
 7713    """
 7714    cargs = []
 7715    cargs.extend([
 7716        "-reslice-identity",
 7717        params.get("reslice_identity")
 7718    ])
 7719    return cargs
 7720

 7722def c3d_rgb2hsv_params(
 7723    rgb2hsv: str,
 7724) -> C3dRgb2hsvParameters:
 7725    """
 7726    Build parameters.
 7727    
 7728    Args:
 7729        rgb2hsv: -rgb2hsv: Convert RGB image to HSV image\
 7730            \
 7731            Syntax `-rgb2hsv`\
 7732            \
 7733            Takes the last three images on the stack and treats them as red,\
 7734            green, and blue channels. Outputs three images corresponding to\
 7735            hue, saturation, value. To read color images you need the\
 7736            ***-msc*** command.\
 7737            \
 7738            c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png.
 7739    Returns:
 7740        Parameter dictionary
 7741    """
 7742    params = {
 7743        "__STYXTYPE__": "rgb2hsv",
 7744        "rgb2hsv": rgb2hsv,
 7745    }
 7746    return params
 7747
 7748

 7750    params: C3dRgb2hsvParameters,
 7751    execution: Execution,

 7756    Args:

 7758        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.

 7760        Command-line arguments.

 7762    cargs = []
 7763    cargs.extend([
 7764        "-rgb2hsv",
 7765        params.get("rgb2hsv")
 7766    ])
 7767    return cargs
 7768
 7769
 7770def c3d_rms_params(
 7771    rms: str,
 7772) -> C3dRmsParameters:
 7773    """
 7774    Build parameters.
 7775    
 7776    Args:
 7777        rms: -rms: Voxelwise vector norm\
 7778            \
 7779            Syntax: `-rms`\
 7780            \
 7781            Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The\
 7782            command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the\
 7783            squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is\
 7784            very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same\
 7785            size.\
 7786            \
 7787            c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img\
 7788            \
 7789            The equivalent of this command is\
 7790            \
 7791            c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times\
 7792            -endfor \\\
 7793            -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img.
 7794    Returns:
 7795        Parameter dictionary
 7796    """
 7797    params = {
 7798        "__STYXTYPE__": "rms",
 7799        "rms": rms,
 7800    }
 7801    return params
 7802
 7803
 7804def c3d_rms_cargs(
 7805    params: C3dRmsParameters,
 7806    execution: Execution,
 7807) -> list[str]:
 7808    """
 7809    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7810    
 7811    Args:
 7812        params: The parameters.
 7813        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7814    Returns:
 7815        Command-line arguments.
 7816    """
 7817    cargs = []
 7818    cargs.extend([
 7819        "-rms",
 7820        params.get("rms")
 7821    ])
 7822    return cargs
 7823
 7824
 7825def c3d_round_params(
 7826    round_: str,
 7827) -> C3dRoundParameters:
 7828    """
 7829    Build parameters.
 7830    
 7831    Args:
 7832        round_: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior\
 7833            \
 7834            Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `\
 7835            \
 7836            By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when\
 7837            converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command\
 7838            specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to\
 7839            avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point\
 7840            representation.\
 7841            \
 7842            c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
 7843    Returns:
 7844        Parameter dictionary
 7845    """
 7846    params = {
 7847        "__STYXTYPE__": "round",
 7848        "round": round_,
 7849    }
 7850    return params
 7851
 7852
 7853def c3d_round_cargs(
 7854    params: C3dRoundParameters,
 7855    execution: Execution,
 7856) -> list[str]:
 7857    """
 7858    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7859    
 7860    Args:
 7861        params: The parameters.
 7862        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7863    Returns:
 7864        Command-line arguments.
 7865    """
 7866    cargs = []
 7867    cargs.extend([
 7868        "-round",
 7869        params.get("round")
 7870    ])
 7871    return cargs
 7872
 7873
 7874def c3d_scale_params(
 7875    scale: str,
 7876) -> C3dScaleParameters:
 7877    """
 7878    Build parameters.
 7879    
 7880    Args:
 7881        scale: -scale: Scale intensity by constant factor\
 7882            \
 7883            Syntax: `-scale <factor>`\
 7884            \
 7885            Multiplies the intensity of each voxel in the last image on the\
 7886            stack by the given factor.\
 7887            \
 7888            c3d img1.img -scale 0.5 -o img2.img.
 7889    Returns:
 7890        Parameter dictionary
 7891    """
 7892    params = {
 7893        "__STYXTYPE__": "scale",
 7894        "scale": scale,
 7895    }
 7896    return params
 7897

 7908        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7909    Returns:
 7910        Command-line arguments.
 7911    """
 7912    cargs = []
 7913    cargs.extend([
 7914        "-scale",
 7915        params.get("scale")
 7916    ])
 7917    return cargs

 7920def c3d_set_sform_1_params(
 7921    set_sform: str,
 7922) -> C3dSetSform1Parameters:
 7923    """
 7924    Build parameters.
 7925    
 7926    Args:
 7927        set_sform: -set-sform: Set the transform to physical space\
 7928            \
 7929            Syntax: `-set-sform <sform.mat> `\
 7930            \
 7931            Sets the Nifti sform of the last image on the stack to the 4x4\
 7932            matrix provided.
 7933    Returns:
 7934        Parameter dictionary
 7935    """

 7937        "__STYXTYPE__": "set_sform_1",
 7938        "set_sform": set_sform,
 7939    }
 7940    return params
 7941
 7942
 7943def c3d_set_sform_1_cargs(
 7944    params: C3dSetSform1Parameters,
 7945    execution: Execution,
 7946) -> list[str]:
 7947    """
 7948    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 7949    
 7950    Args:
 7951        params: The parameters.
 7952        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 7953    Returns:
 7954        Command-line arguments.
 7955    """
 7956    cargs = []
 7957    cargs.extend([
 7958        "-set-sform",
 7959        params.get("set_sform")
 7960    ])
 7961    return cargs
 7962
 7963
 7964def c3d_sin_params(
 7965    sin: str,
 7966) -> C3dSinParameters:
 7967    """
 7968    Build parameters.
 7969    
 7970    Args:
 7971        sin: -cos: Voxelwise cosine\
 7972            \
 7973            Syntax: `-sin`\
 7974            \
 7975            Replaces the last image on the stack with the cosine trigonometric\
 7976            operation applied to all voxels. Input must be in radians.
 7977    Returns:
 7978        Parameter dictionary
 7979    """
 7980    params = {
 7981        "__STYXTYPE__": "sin",
 7982        "sin": sin,
 7983    }
 7984    return params
 7985

 7993

 7998        Command-line arguments.

 8000    cargs = []
 8001    cargs.extend([
 8002        "-sin",
 8003        params.get("sin")
 8004    ])
 8005    return cargs
 8006
 8007
 8008def c3d_slice_params(
 8009    slice_: str,
 8010) -> C3dSliceParameters:
 8011    """
 8012    Build parameters.
 8013    
 8014    Args:
 8015        slice_: -slice: Extract slices from an image\
 8016            \
 8017            Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`\
 8018            \
 8019            Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position\
 8020            specifier **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of\
 8021            slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a\
 8022            percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice\
 8023            0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a\
 8024            range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on\
 8025            the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can\
 8026            save the slice as a 2D PNG image.\
 8027            \
 8028            c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz\
 8029            c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz\
 8030            c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o\
 8031            myslice.png\
 8032            c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz\
 8033            c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz\
 8034            \
 8035            With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to\
 8036            extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a\
 8037            4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the\
 8038            command\
 8039            \
 8040            c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz.
 8041    Returns:
 8042        Parameter dictionary
 8043    """
 8044    params = {
 8045        "__STYXTYPE__": "slice",
 8046        "slice": slice_,
 8047    }
 8048    return params
 8049
 8050
 8051def c3d_slice_cargs(
 8052    params: C3dSliceParameters,
 8053    execution: Execution,
 8054) -> list[str]:
 8055    """
 8056    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8057    
 8058    Args:
 8059        params: The parameters.
 8060        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8061    Returns:
 8062        Command-line arguments.
 8063    """
 8064    cargs = []
 8065    cargs.extend([
 8066        "-slice",
 8067        params.get("slice")
 8068    ])
 8069    return cargs
 8070
 8071
 8072def c3d_slice_all_params(
 8073    slice_all: str,
 8074) -> C3dSliceAllParameters:
 8075    """
 8076    Build parameters.
 8077    
 8078    Args:
 8079        slice_all: -slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack\
 8080            \
 8081            Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`\
 8082            \
 8083            This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all\
 8084            images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved.\
 8085            This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if\
 8086            you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and\
 8087            save the slices as follows:\
 8088            \
 8089            c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz.
 8090    Returns:
 8091        Parameter dictionary
 8092    """
 8093    params = {
 8094        "__STYXTYPE__": "slice_all",
 8095        "slice_all": slice_all,
 8096    }
 8097    return params
 8098
 8099
 8100def c3d_slice_all_cargs(
 8101    params: C3dSliceAllParameters,
 8102    execution: Execution,
 8103) -> list[str]:
 8104    """
 8105    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8106    
 8107    Args:
 8108        params: The parameters.
 8109        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8110    Returns:
 8111        Command-line arguments.
 8112    """
 8113    cargs = []
 8114    cargs.extend([
 8115        "-slice-all",
 8116        params.get("slice_all")
 8117    ])
 8118    return cargs
 8119

 8126

 8131            \
 8132            Applies the Laplacian sharpening filter from ITK, which accentuates\
 8133            the edges in the image.\
 8134            \

 8136    Returns:
 8137        Parameter dictionary
 8138    """
 8139    params = {
 8140        "__STYXTYPE__": "sharpen",
 8141        "sharpen": sharpen,
 8142    }
 8143    return params

 8211
 8212def c3d_signed_distance_transform_params(
 8213    signed_distance_transform: str,
 8214) -> C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters:
 8215    """
 8216    Build parameters.
 8217    
 8218    Args:
 8219        signed_distance_transform: -sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed\
 8220            distance transform of a binary image\
 8221            \
 8222            Syntax: `-sdt`\
 8223            \
 8224            Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels\
 8225            where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and\
 8226            voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values.\
 8227            The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean\
 8228            distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary\
 8229            image.\
 8230            \
 8231            c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img.
 8232    Returns:
 8233        Parameter dictionary
 8234    """
 8235    params = {
 8236        "__STYXTYPE__": "signed_distance_transform",
 8237        "signed_distance_transform": signed_distance_transform,
 8238    }
 8239    return params
 8240
 8241
 8242def c3d_signed_distance_transform_cargs(
 8243    params: C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters,
 8244    execution: Execution,
 8245) -> list[str]:
 8246    """
 8247    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8248    
 8249    Args:
 8250        params: The parameters.
 8251        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8252    Returns:
 8253        Command-line arguments.
 8254    """
 8255    cargs = []
 8256    cargs.extend([
 8257        "-signed-distance-transform",
 8258        params.get("signed_distance_transform")
 8259    ])
 8260    return cargs
 8261

 8263def c3d_smooth_params(
 8264    smooth: str,
 8265) -> C3dSmoothParameters:
 8266    """
 8267    Build parameters.
 8268    
 8269    Args:
 8270        smooth: -smooth: Gaussian smoothing\
 8271            \
 8272            Syntax: `-smooth <sigma_vector> `\
 8273            \
 8274            Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image. The parameter vector\
 8275            specifies the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see\
 8276            [Vector Format Specification][10] below.\
 8277            \
 8278            c3d img1.img -smooth 2x1x1vox -o out.img.
 8279    Returns:
 8280        Parameter dictionary
 8281    """
 8282    params = {
 8283        "__STYXTYPE__": "smooth",
 8284        "smooth": smooth,
 8285    }
 8286    return params
 8287

 8296    Args:

 8298        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8299    Returns:
 8300        Command-line arguments.
 8301    """
 8302    cargs = []
 8303    cargs.extend([
 8304        "-smooth",
 8305        params.get("smooth")
 8306    ])
 8307    return cargs

 8310def c3d_smooth_fast_params(
 8311    smooth_fast: str,
 8312) -> C3dSmoothFastParameters:
 8313    """
 8314    Build parameters.
 8315    
 8316    Args:
 8317        smooth_fast: -smooth-fast: Fast approximate Gaussian smoothing\
 8318            \
 8319            Syntax: `-smooth-fast <sigma_vector> `\
 8320            \
 8321            Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image using the fast [Deriche\
 8322            recursive smoothing algorithm][15]. The parameter vector specifies\
 8323            the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see [Vector\
 8324            Format Specification][10] below.\
 8325            \
 8326            c3d img1.img -smooth-fast 20x10x10vox -o out.img.
 8327    Returns:
 8328        Parameter dictionary
 8329    """
 8330    params = {
 8331        "__STYXTYPE__": "smooth_fast",
 8332        "smooth_fast": smooth_fast,
 8333    }
 8334    return params
 8335

 8347    Returns:
 8348        Command-line arguments.

 8351    cargs.extend([
 8352        "-smooth-fast",
 8353        params.get("smooth_fast")
 8354    ])

 8358def c3d_spacing_params(
 8359    spacing: str,
 8360) -> C3dSpacingParameters:
 8361    """
 8362    Build parameters.
 8363    
 8364    Args:
 8365        spacing: -spacing: Set voxel spacing\
 8366            \
 8367            Syntax: `-spacing <vector> `\
 8368            \
 8369            Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector\
 8370            with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the\
 8371            image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only\
 8372            changes the header of the image, not its contents.\
 8373            \
 8374            c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img.
 8375    Returns:
 8376        Parameter dictionary
 8377    """
 8378    params = {
 8379        "__STYXTYPE__": "spacing",
 8380        "spacing": spacing,
 8381    }
 8382    return params
 8383
 8384

 8386    params: C3dSpacingParameters,
 8387    execution: Execution,
 8388) -> list[str]:
 8389    """

 8391    
 8392    Args:

 8394        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8395    Returns:
 8396        Command-line arguments.
 8397    """
 8398    cargs = []
 8399    cargs.extend([
 8400        "-spacing",
 8401        params.get("spacing")
 8402    ])
 8403    return cargs
 8404
 8405
 8406def c3d_split_params(
 8407    split: str,
 8408) -> C3dSplitParameters:
 8409    """
 8410    Build parameters.
 8411    
 8412    Args:
 8413        split: -split: Split multi-label image into binary images\
 8414            \
 8415            Syntax: `-split`\
 8416            \
 8417            This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of\
 8418            discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary\
 8419            images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be\
 8420            recombined using the **-merge** command. The labels corresponding\
 8421            to each binary image are remembered by **convert3d** so that when\
 8422            **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The\
 8423            **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image, and\
 8424            selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The\
 8425            example below smooths each label independently, then recombines\
 8426            using **-merge**\
 8427            \
 8428            c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o\
 8429            ml_smooth.nii\
 8430            \
 8431            Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite\
 8432            intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the\
 8433            labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*,\
 8434            for example, using the **-thresh** command.
 8435    Returns:
 8436        Parameter dictionary
 8437    """
 8438    params = {
 8439        "__STYXTYPE__": "split",
 8440        "split": split,
 8441    }
 8442    return params
 8443
 8444
 8445def c3d_split_cargs(
 8446    params: C3dSplitParameters,
 8447    execution: Execution,
 8448) -> list[str]:
 8449    """
 8450    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8451    
 8452    Args:
 8453        params: The parameters.
 8454        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8455    Returns:
 8456        Command-line arguments.
 8457    """
 8458    cargs = []
 8459    cargs.extend([
 8460        "-split",
 8461        params.get("split")
 8462    ])
 8463    return cargs
 8464
 8465

 8474            \
 8475            Syntax: `-sqrt `\
 8476            \
 8477            Computes square root of each voxel in the image.\
 8478            \
 8479            c3d input.img -sqrt -o output.img.
 8480    Returns:
 8481        Parameter dictionary
 8482    """
 8483    params = {
 8484        "__STYXTYPE__": "sqrt",
 8485        "sqrt": sqrt,
 8486    }
 8487    return params

 8507    ])
 8508    return cargs
 8509
 8510
 8511def c3d_staple_params(
 8512    staple: str,
 8513) -> C3dStapleParameters:
 8514    """
 8515    Build parameters.
 8516    
 8517    Args:
 8518        staple: -staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations\
 8519            \
 8520            Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `\
 8521            \
 8522            Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See\
 8523            Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true'\
 8524            segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by\
 8525            different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as\
 8526            inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a\
 8527            different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the\
 8528            label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of\
 8529            interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1\
 8530            corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the\
 8531            hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the\
 8532            *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image\
 8533            with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each\
 8534            voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be\
 8535            thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional\
 8536            outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each\
 8537            rater) are printed out if the **-verbose** command is used before\
 8538            the **-staple** command.\
 8539            \
 8540            c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o\
 8541            probmap.img\
 8542            c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o\
 8543            bin_segm.img.
 8544    Returns:
 8545        Parameter dictionary
 8546    """
 8547    params = {
 8548        "__STYXTYPE__": "staple",
 8549        "staple": staple,
 8550    }
 8551    return params
 8552
 8553
 8554def c3d_staple_cargs(
 8555    params: C3dStapleParameters,
 8556    execution: Execution,
 8557) -> list[str]:
 8558    """
 8559    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8560    
 8561    Args:
 8562        params: The parameters.
 8563        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8564    Returns:
 8565        Command-line arguments.
 8566    """
 8567    cargs = []
 8568    cargs.extend([
 8569        "-staple",
 8570        params.get("staple")
 8571    ])
 8572    return cargs
 8573
 8574
 8575def c3d_structure_tensor_eigenvalues_params(
 8576    structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str,
 8577) -> C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters:
 8578    """
 8579    Build parameters.
 8580    
 8581    Args:
 8582        structure_tensor_eigenvalues: -steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues:\
 8583            Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor\
 8584            \
 8585            Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`\
 8586            \
 8587            Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the\
 8588            eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by\
 8589            value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture\
 8590            features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines\
 8591            the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial\
 8592            derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.\
 8593            \
 8594            c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
 8595    Returns:
 8596        Parameter dictionary
 8597    """
 8598    params = {
 8599        "__STYXTYPE__": "structure_tensor_eigenvalues",
 8600        "structure_tensor_eigenvalues": structure_tensor_eigenvalues,
 8601    }
 8602    return params
 8603
 8604
 8605def c3d_structure_tensor_eigenvalues_cargs(
 8606    params: C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters,
 8607    execution: Execution,
 8608) -> list[str]:
 8609    """
 8610    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8611    
 8612    Args:
 8613        params: The parameters.
 8614        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8615    Returns:
 8616        Command-line arguments.
 8617    """
 8618    cargs = []
 8619    cargs.extend([
 8620        "-steig",
 8621        params.get("structure_tensor_eigenvalues")
 8622    ])
 8623    return cargs
 8624
 8625
 8626def c3d_spm_params(
 8627    spm: str,
 8628) -> C3dSpmParameters:
 8629    """
 8630    Build parameters.
 8631    
 8632    Args:
 8633        spm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output\
 8634            \
 8635            Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `\
 8636            \
 8637            These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze\
 8638            (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored\
 8639            by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When\
 8640            saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default\
 8641            is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue\
 8642            altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.\
 8643            \
 8644            c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
 8645    Returns:
 8646        Parameter dictionary
 8647    """
 8648    params = {
 8649        "__STYXTYPE__": "spm",
 8650        "spm": spm,
 8651    }
 8652    return params
 8653
 8654
 8655def c3d_spm_cargs(
 8656    params: C3dSpmParameters,
 8657    execution: Execution,
 8658) -> list[str]:
 8659    """
 8660    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8661    
 8662    Args:
 8663        params: The parameters.
 8664        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8665    Returns:
 8666        Command-line arguments.
 8667    """
 8668    cargs = []
 8669    cargs.extend([
 8670        "-spm",
 8671        params.get("spm")
 8672    ])
 8673    return cargs

 8730    return params

 8732

 8739    
 8740    Args:
 8741        params: The parameters.
 8742        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8743    Returns:
 8744        Command-line arguments.
 8745    """
 8746    cargs = []
 8747    cargs.extend([
 8748        "-supervoxel",
 8749        params.get("supervoxel")
 8750    ])
 8751    return cargs

 8753
 8754def c3d_stretch_params(
 8755    stretch: str,
 8756) -> C3dStretchParameters:
 8757    """
 8758    Build parameters.
 8759    
 8760    Args:
 8761        stretch: -stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly\
 8762            \
 8763            Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `\
 8764            \
 8765            Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps\
 8766            to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to\
 8767            all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For\
 8768            example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval\
 8769            (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use\
 8770            \
 8771            c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img.
 8772    Returns:
 8773        Parameter dictionary
 8774    """
 8775    params = {
 8776        "__STYXTYPE__": "stretch",
 8777        "stretch": stretch,
 8778    }
 8779    return params
 8780
 8781
 8782def c3d_stretch_cargs(
 8783    params: C3dStretchParameters,
 8784    execution: Execution,
 8785) -> list[str]:
 8786    """
 8787    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8788    
 8789    Args:
 8790        params: The parameters.
 8791        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8792    Returns:
 8793        Command-line arguments.
 8794    """
 8795    cargs = []
 8796    cargs.extend([
 8797        "-stretch",
 8798        params.get("stretch")
 8799    ])
 8800    return cargs
 8801
 8802
 8803def c3d_swapdim_params(
 8804    swapdim: str,
 8805) -> C3dSwapdimParameters:
 8806    """
 8807    Build parameters.
 8808    
 8809    Args:
 8810        swapdim: -swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image\
 8811            \
 8812            Syntax `-swapdim <code>`\
 8813            \
 8814            This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to\
 8815            achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical\
 8816            space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but\
 8817            the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to\
 8818            obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified\
 8819            as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.\
 8820            \
 8821            c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii\
 8822            \
 8823            \
 8824            ### Commands: Image Processing\
 8825            \
 8826            The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images.\
 8827            Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack,\
 8828            binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands\
 8829            are affected by options, which are listed separately.
 8830    Returns:
 8831        Parameter dictionary
 8832    """
 8833    params = {
 8834        "__STYXTYPE__": "swapdim",
 8835        "swapdim": swapdim,
 8836    }
 8837    return params
 8838
 8839
 8840def c3d_swapdim_cargs(
 8841    params: C3dSwapdimParameters,
 8842    execution: Execution,
 8843) -> list[str]:
 8844    """
 8845    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8846    
 8847    Args:
 8848        params: The parameters.
 8849        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8850    Returns:
 8851        Command-line arguments.
 8852    """
 8853    cargs = []
 8854    cargs.extend([
 8855        "-swapdim",
 8856        params.get("swapdim")
 8857    ])
 8858    return cargs
 8859
 8860
 8861def c3d_test_image_params(
 8862    test_image: str,
 8863) -> C3dTestImageParameters:
 8864    """
 8865    Build parameters.
 8866    
 8867    Args:
 8868        test_image: -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition\
 8869            \
 8870            Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value>\
 8871            [tolerance]`\
 8872            \
 8873            These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are\
 8874            primarily meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also\
 8875            be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell).\
 8876            The commands check a certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause\
 8877            the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded\
 8878            or a non-zero return code if the test failed.\
 8879            \
 8880            **-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are\
 8881            identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the\
 8882            images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default\
 8883            value 1e-8.\
 8884            \
 8885            c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image\
 8886            \
 8887            **-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if\
 8888            the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by\
 8889            **vector** is equal to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance\
 8890            value may be specified, the default is 1e-8.\
 8891            \
 8892            c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6.
 8893    Returns:
 8894        Parameter dictionary
 8895    """
 8896    params = {
 8897        "__STYXTYPE__": "test_image",
 8898        "test_image": test_image,
 8899    }
 8900    return params
 8901
 8902
 8903def c3d_test_image_cargs(
 8904    params: C3dTestImageParameters,
 8905    execution: Execution,
 8906) -> list[str]:
 8907    """
 8908    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 8909    
 8910    Args:
 8911        params: The parameters.
 8912        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 8913    Returns:
 8914        Command-line arguments.
 8915    """
 8916    cargs = []
 8917    cargs.extend([
 8918        "-test-image",
 8919        params.get("test_image")
 8920    ])
 8921    return cargs
 8922
 8923
 8924def c3d_test_probe_params(
 8925    test_probe: str,
 8926) -> C3dTestProbeParameters:
 8927    """
 8928    Build parameters.
 8929    
 8930    Args:
 8931        test_probe: -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition\
 8932            \
 8933            Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value>\
 8934            [tolerance]`\
 8935            \
 8936            These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are\
 8937            primarily meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also\
 8938            be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell).\
 8939            The commands check a certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause\
 8940            the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded\
 8941            or a non-zero return code if the test failed.\
 8942            \
 8943            **-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are\
 8944            identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the\
 8945            images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default\
 8946            value 1e-8.\
 8947            \
 8948            c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image\
 8949            \
 8950            **-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if\
 8951            the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by\
 8952            **vector** is equal to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance\
 8953            value may be specified, the default is 1e-8.\
 8954            \
 8955            c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6.
 8956    Returns:
 8957        Parameter dictionary
 8958    """
 8959    params = {
 8960        "__STYXTYPE__": "test_probe",
 8961        "test_probe": test_probe,
 8962    }
 8963    return params
 8964

 8986
 8987def c3d_threshold_params(
 8988    threshold: str,
 8989) -> C3dThresholdParameters:
 8990    """
 8991    Build parameters.
 8992    
 8993    Args:
 8994        threshold: -thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding\
 8995            \
 8996            Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `\
 8997            \
 8998            Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the\
 8999            range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and\
 9000            *u2* are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you\
 9001            can supply values **inf** and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a\
 9002            one-sided threshold. You can also specify *u1* and *u2* as\
 9003            percentiles.\
 9004            c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img\
 9005            c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img\
 9006            c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img.
 9007    Returns:
 9008        Parameter dictionary
 9009    """
 9010    params = {
 9011        "__STYXTYPE__": "threshold",
 9012        "threshold": threshold,
 9013    }
 9014    return params
 9015
 9016
 9017def c3d_threshold_cargs(
 9018    params: C3dThresholdParameters,
 9019    execution: Execution,
 9020) -> list[str]:
 9021    """
 9022    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9023    
 9024    Args:
 9025        params: The parameters.
 9026        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9027    Returns:
 9028        Command-line arguments.
 9029    """
 9030    cargs = []
 9031    cargs.extend([
 9032        "-threshold",
 9033        params.get("threshold")
 9034    ])
 9035    return cargs
 9036
 9037
 9038def c3d_tile_params(
 9039    tile: str,
 9040) -> C3dTileParameters:
 9041    """
 9042    Build parameters.
 9043    
 9044    Args:
 9045        tile: -tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one\
 9046            \
 9047            Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`\
 9048            \
 9049            Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking\
 9050            slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack\
 9051            and produces a single tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can\
 9052            either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile\
 9053            the images, or a layout vector (e.g., **4x4**) which specifies the\
 9054            tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the\
 9055            layout vector determines the value based on the number of images\
 9056            currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of\
 9057            slices, we use\
 9058            \
 9059            c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz\
 9060            \
 9061            And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per\
 9062            row, we would use the **c2d** command as follows:\
 9063            \
 9064            c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png.
 9065    Returns:
 9066        Parameter dictionary
 9067    """
 9068    params = {
 9069        "__STYXTYPE__": "tile",
 9070        "tile": tile,
 9071    }
 9072    return params
 9073
 9074
 9075def c3d_tile_cargs(
 9076    params: C3dTileParameters,
 9077    execution: Execution,
 9078) -> list[str]:
 9079    """
 9080    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9081    
 9082    Args:
 9083        params: The parameters.
 9084        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9085    Returns:
 9086        Command-line arguments.
 9087    """
 9088    cargs = []
 9089    cargs.extend([
 9090        "-tile",
 9091        params.get("tile")
 9092    ])
 9093    return cargs
 9094
 9095
 9096def c3d_trim_params(
 9097    trim: str,
 9098) -> C3dTrimParameters:
 9099    """
 9100    Build parameters.
 9101    
 9102    Args:
 9103        trim: -trim: Trim background region of image\
 9104            \
 9105            Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`\
 9106            \
 9107            Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the\
 9108            image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest\
 9109            rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels\
 9110            in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the\
 9111            size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image.\
 9112            For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel\
 9113            margin of background values on all sides\
 9114            \
 9115            c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img.
 9116    Returns:
 9117        Parameter dictionary
 9118    """
 9119    params = {
 9120        "__STYXTYPE__": "trim",
 9121        "trim": trim,
 9122    }
 9123    return params
 9124
 9125
 9126def c3d_trim_cargs(
 9127    params: C3dTrimParameters,
 9128    execution: Execution,
 9129) -> list[str]:
 9130    """
 9131    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9132    
 9133    Args:
 9134        params: The parameters.
 9135        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9136    Returns:
 9137        Command-line arguments.
 9138    """
 9139    cargs = []
 9140    cargs.extend([
 9141        "-trim",
 9142        params.get("trim")
 9143    ])
 9144    return cargs
 9145
 9146
 9147def c3d_trim_to_size_params(
 9148    trim_to_size: str,
 9149) -> C3dTrimToSizeParameters:
 9150    """
 9151    Build parameters.
 9152    
 9153    Args:
 9154        trim_to_size: -trim-to-size: Trim image to given size\
 9155            \
 9156            Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`\
 9157            \
 9158            Like **-trim**, this command trims the background in an image.\
 9159            However, instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the\
 9160            output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified\
 9161            region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For\
 9162            example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the\
 9163            foreground pixels in your image, call\
 9164            \
 9165            c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img.
 9166    Returns:
 9167        Parameter dictionary
 9168    """
 9169    params = {
 9170        "__STYXTYPE__": "trim_to_size",
 9171        "trim_to_size": trim_to_size,
 9172    }
 9173    return params
 9174
 9175
 9176def c3d_trim_to_size_cargs(
 9177    params: C3dTrimToSizeParameters,
 9178    execution: Execution,
 9179) -> list[str]:
 9180    """
 9181    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9182    
 9183    Args:
 9184        params: The parameters.
 9185        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9186    Returns:
 9187        Command-line arguments.
 9188    """
 9189    cargs = []
 9190    cargs.extend([
 9191        "-trim-to-size",
 9192        params.get("trim_to_size")
 9193    ])
 9194    return cargs

 9197def c3d_type_params(
 9198    type_: str,
 9199) -> C3dTypeParameters:
 9200    """
 9201    Build parameters.
 9202    
 9203    Args:
 9204        type_: -type: Specify pixel type for image output\
 9205            \
 9206            Syntax: `-type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float\
 9207            | double > `\
 9208            \
 9209            Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images\
 9210            are written in floating point (**float**) format. The type does not\
 9211            affect how images are processed, only how they are saved.\
 9212            \
 9213            c3d image1.img -type short image2.img\
 9214            \
 9215            Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG\
 9216            images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.
 9217    Returns:
 9218        Parameter dictionary
 9219    """
 9220    params = {
 9221        "__STYXTYPE__": "type",
 9222        "type": type_,
 9223    }
 9224    return params
 9225

 9234    Args:

 9238        Command-line arguments.

 9241    cargs.extend([
 9242        "-type",

 9244    ])

 9264        Parameter dictionary
 9265    """

 9370
 9371
 9372def c3d_vote_params(
 9373    vote: str,
 9374) -> C3dVoteParameters:
 9375    """
 9376    Build parameters.
 9377    
 9378    Args:
 9379        vote: -vote: Vote among images on the stack\
 9380            \
 9381            Syntax: `-vote `\
 9382            \
 9383            This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each\
 9384            voxel *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image\
 9385            value at *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when\
 9386            combining probability maps into a single label image. If images\
 9387            prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc.\
 9388            over the image domain, the **-vote** command will return the most\
 9389            probable label at each voxel.\
 9390            \
 9391            c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img\
 9392            \
 9393            The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the\
 9394            bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the\
 9395            example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where\
 9396            prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see\
 9397            the related commands **-split** and **-merge**.
 9398    Returns:
 9399        Parameter dictionary
 9400    """
 9401    params = {
 9402        "__STYXTYPE__": "vote",
 9403        "vote": vote,
 9404    }
 9405    return params
 9406
 9407
 9408def c3d_vote_cargs(
 9409    params: C3dVoteParameters,
 9410    execution: Execution,
 9411) -> list[str]:
 9412    """
 9413    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9414    
 9415    Args:
 9416        params: The parameters.
 9417        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9418    Returns:
 9419        Command-line arguments.
 9420    """
 9421    cargs = []
 9422    cargs.extend([
 9423        "-vote",
 9424        params.get("vote")
 9425    ])
 9426    return cargs
 9427
 9428
 9429def c3d_vote_mrf_params(
 9430    vote_mrf: str,
 9431) -> C3dVoteMrfParameters:
 9432    """
 9433    Build parameters.
 9434    
 9435    Args:
 9436        vote_mrf: -vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization\
 9437            \
 9438            Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`\
 9439            \
 9440            This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs\
 9441            regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of\
 9442            regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in\
 9443            the output. It results in more contiguous segments.\
 9444            \
 9445            The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they\
 9446            are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This\
 9447            means that voxel **x** in image **k** holds the probability that\
 9448            voxel **x** has label **k**. Likelihood images must be between 0\
 9449            and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel\
 9450            being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label\
 9451            0 in the output.\
 9452            \
 9453            The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization,\
 9454            consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term\
 9455            encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel\
 9456            **x** the label **k**. The parameter **mode** describes how\
 9457            likelihood images are mapped to the cost.\
 9458            \
 9459            * `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is\
 9460            being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a\
 9461            single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion\
 9462            of segmentations that assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term\
 9463            equals to the error associated to assining the voxel *k* label *x*.\
 9464            This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all\
 9465            labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*. Note that the\
 9466            likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted\
 9467            as missing data for some voxels.\
 9468            \
 9469            * `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is\
 9470            the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign\
 9471            infinite cost when the likelihood is zero.\
 9472            \
 9473            The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total\
 9474            number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region\
 9475            of the image) that have different labels.\
 9476            \
 9477            The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph\
 9478            cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the\
 9479            following papers.\
 9480            \
 9481            1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate\
 9482            Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI,\
 9483            vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001.\
 9484            \
 9485            2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can\
 9486            be Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26,\
 9487            no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.\
 9488            \
 9489            3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison\
 9490            of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*,\
 9491            IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.\
 9492            \
 9493            As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts\
 9494            algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This\
 9495            software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite\
 9496            the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication. If you wish\
 9497            to use this software (or the algorithms described in the\
 9498            aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware\
 9499            that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System\
 9500            and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph\
 9501            cuts*, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.\
 9502            \
 9503            The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a\
 9504            user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped\
 9505            to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization\
 9506            and given 0 label.\
 9507            \
 9508            c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \\\
 9509            -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \\\
 9510            -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii.
 9511    Returns:
 9512        Parameter dictionary
 9513    """
 9514    params = {
 9515        "__STYXTYPE__": "vote_mrf",
 9516        "vote_mrf": vote_mrf,
 9517    }
 9518    return params
 9519
 9520
 9521def c3d_vote_mrf_cargs(
 9522    params: C3dVoteMrfParameters,
 9523    execution: Execution,
 9524) -> list[str]:
 9525    """
 9526    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9527    
 9528    Args:
 9529        params: The parameters.
 9530        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9531    Returns:
 9532        Command-line arguments.
 9533    """
 9534    cargs = []
 9535    cargs.extend([
 9536        "-vote-mrf",
 9537        params.get("vote_mrf")
 9538    ])
 9539    return cargs
 9540

 9586

 9589            \
 9590            Syntax: `-voxel-sum `\
 9591            \
 9592            Print the sum of all voxels in the image.\
 9593            \
 9594            $ c3d image.img -voxel-sum\
 9595            Voxel Sum: 200923123.
 9596    Returns:
 9597        Parameter dictionary
 9598    """
 9599    params = {
 9600        "__STYXTYPE__": "voxel_sum",
 9601        "voxel_sum": voxel_sum,
 9602    }
 9603    return params

 9627def c3d_voxel_integral_params(
 9628    voxel_integral: str,
 9629) -> C3dVoxelIntegralParameters:
 9630    """
 9631    Build parameters.
 9632    
 9633    Args:
 9634        voxel_integral: -voxel-integral: Print volume integral of all voxel\
 9635            intensities\
 9636            \
 9637            Syntax: `-voxel-integral`\
 9638            \
 9639            Like **-voxel-sum**, but multiplies the sum of voxel intensities by\
 9640            voxel volume. This is useful for computing volumes of objects\
 9641            represented by binary images. The result is in 'ml'.\
 9642            \
 9643            $ c3d image.img -voxel-integral\
 9644            Voxel Integral: 2341.
 9645    Returns:
 9646        Parameter dictionary
 9647    """
 9648    params = {
 9649        "__STYXTYPE__": "voxel_integral",
 9650        "voxel_integral": voxel_integral,
 9651    }
 9652    return params

 9675
 9676def c3d_voxelwise_regression_params(
 9677    voxelwise_regression: str,
 9678) -> C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters:
 9679    """
 9680    Build parameters.
 9681    
 9682    Args:
 9683        voxelwise_regression: -voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression\
 9684            between two images\
 9685            \
 9686            Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `\
 9687            \
 9688            Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This\
 9689            command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds\
 9690            parameters b\\_0, b\\_1, ..., b\\_k, such that Y is best\
 9691            approximated by b\\_0 + b\\_1 * X + b\\_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k.\
 9692            Here is an example of linear regression.\
 9693            \
 9694            $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2\
 9695            REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935\
 9696            REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024\
 9697            \
 9698            $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2\
 9699            REGCOEFF[0] = 0\
 9700            REGCOEFF[1] = 1.
 9701    Returns:
 9702        Parameter dictionary
 9703    """
 9704    params = {
 9705        "__STYXTYPE__": "voxelwise_regression",
 9706        "voxelwise_regression": voxelwise_regression,
 9707    }
 9708    return params
 9709
 9710
 9711def c3d_voxelwise_regression_cargs(
 9712    params: C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters,
 9713    execution: Execution,
 9714) -> list[str]:
 9715    """
 9716    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9717    
 9718    Args:
 9719        params: The parameters.
 9720        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9721    Returns:
 9722        Command-line arguments.
 9723    """
 9724    cargs = []
 9725    cargs.extend([
 9726        "-voxelwise-regression",
 9727        params.get("voxelwise_regression")
 9728    ])
 9729    return cargs
