 9809
 9810def c3d_wrap_params(
 9811    wrap: str,
 9812) -> C3dWrapParameters:
 9813    """
 9814    Build parameters.
 9815    
 9816    Args:
 9817        wrap: -wrap: Wrap (rotate) image\
 9818            \
 9819            Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `\
 9820            \
 9821            Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is\
 9822            typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector\
 9823            must have integer components, possibly negative. For example,\
 9824            \
 9825            c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz\
 9826            \
 9827            will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels\
 9828            (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).\
 9829            \
 9830            \
 9831            ### Commands: Options and Parameters\
 9832            \
 9833            Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the\
 9834            command line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the\
 9835            command will have no effect.
 9836    Returns:
 9837        Parameter dictionary
 9838    """
 9839    params = {
 9840        "__STYXTYPE__": "wrap",
 9841        "wrap": wrap,
 9842    }
 9843    return params
 9844
 9845
 9846def c3d_wrap_cargs(
 9847    params: C3dWrapParameters,
 9848    execution: Execution,
 9849) -> list[str]:
 9850    """
 9851    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9852    
 9853    Args:
 9854        params: The parameters.
 9855        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9856    Returns:
 9857        Command-line arguments.
 9858    """
 9859    cargs = []
 9860    cargs.extend([
 9861        "-wrap",
 9862        params.get("wrap")
 9863    ])
 9864    return cargs
 9865
 9866
 9867def c3d_weighted_sum_params(
 9868    weighted_sum: str,
 9869) -> C3dWeightedSumParameters:
 9870    """
 9871    Build parameters.
 9872    
 9873    Args:
 9874        weighted_sum: -wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant\
 9875            weights\
 9876            \
 9877            Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `\
 9878            \
 9879            Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack.\
 9880            \
 9881            c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii\
 9882            \
 9883            This command is particularly useful for combining components in a\
 9884            multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert\
 9885            it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows:\
 9886            \
 9887            c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii.
 9888    Returns:
 9889        Parameter dictionary
 9890    """
 9891    params = {
 9892        "__STYXTYPE__": "weighted_sum",
 9893        "weighted_sum": weighted_sum,
 9894    }
 9895    return params
 9896
 9897
 9898def c3d_weighted_sum_cargs(
 9899    params: C3dWeightedSumParameters,
 9900    execution: Execution,
 9901) -> list[str]:
 9902    """
 9903    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9904    
 9905    Args:
 9906        params: The parameters.
 9907        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9908    Returns:
 9909        Command-line arguments.
 9910    """
 9911    cargs = []
 9912    cargs.extend([
 9913        "-weighted-sum",
 9914        params.get("weighted_sum")
 9915    ])
 9916    return cargs
 9917
 9918
 9919def c3d_weighted_sum_voxelwise_params(
 9920    weighted_sum_voxelwise: str,
 9921) -> C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters:
 9922    """
 9923    Build parameters.
 9924    
 9925    Args:
 9926        weighted_sum_voxelwise: -wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of\
 9927            images with spatially varying weights\
 9928            \
 9929            Syntax: `-wsv `\
 9930            \
 9931            Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The\
 9932            images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack\
 9933            are used.\
 9934            \
 9935            c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii\
 9936            image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz\
 9937            \
 9938            The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:\
 9939            \
 9940            c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz\
 9941            \
 9942            ### Commands: Image Header Manipulation.
 9943    Returns:
 9944        Parameter dictionary
 9945    """
 9946    params = {
 9947        "__STYXTYPE__": "weighted_sum_voxelwise",
 9948        "weighted_sum_voxelwise": weighted_sum_voxelwise,
 9949    }
 9950    return params
 9951
 9952
 9953def c3d_weighted_sum_voxelwise_cargs(
 9954    params: C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters,
 9955    execution: Execution,
 9956) -> list[str]:
 9957    """
 9958    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
 9959    
 9960    Args:
 9961        params: The parameters.
 9962        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
 9963    Returns:
 9964        Command-line arguments.
 9965    """
 9966    cargs = []
 9967    cargs.extend([
 9968        "-weighted-sum-voxelwise",
 9969        params.get("weighted_sum_voxelwise")
 9970    ])
 9971    return cargs
 9972
 9973
 9974class C3dOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):
 9975    """
 9976    Output object returned when calling `c3d_(...)`.
 9977    """
 9978    root: OutputPathType
 9979    """Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs."""
 9980    operations: list[typing.Union[C3dOutputOutputs]]
 9981    """Outputs from `C3dOutputParameters`.This is a list of outputs with the
 9982    same length and order as the inputs."""
 9983
 9984
 9985def c3d_params(
 9986    input_: list[InputPathType],
 9987    operations: list[typing.Union[C3dAccumParameters, C3dAcosParameters, C3dAddParameters, C3dAlignLandmarksParameters, C3dAnisotropicDiffusionParameters, C3dAntialiasParameters, C3dSetParameters, C3dAsinParameters, C3dAtan2Parameters, C3dBackgroundParameters, C3dN4BiasCorrectionParameters, C3dBinarizeParameters, C3dCannyParameters, C3dCeilParameters, C3dCentroidParameters, C3dCentroidMarkParameters, C3dConnectedComponentsParameters, C3dClearParameters, C3dClipParameters, C3dColorMapParameters, C3dCompressParameters, C3dNoCompressParameters, C3dConvParameters, C3dCoordinateMapVoxelParameters, C3dCoordinateMapPhysicalParameters, C3dCopyTransformParameters, C3dCosParameters, C3dCreateParameters, C3dDicomSeriesListParameters, C3dDicomSeriesReadParameters, C3dDilateParameters, C3dDivideParameters, C3dDuplicateParameters, C3dEndaccumParameters, C3dEndforParameters, C3dErodeParameters, C3dErfParameters, C3dExpParameters, C3dExportPatchesParameters, C3dExportPatchesAugParameters, C3dExtrudeSegParameters, C3dFillBackgroundWithNoiseParameters, C3dFftParameters, C3dFlipParameters, C3dFloorParameters, C3dForeachParameters, C3dForeachCompParameters, C3dGlmParameters, C3dGradientParameters, C3dHelpParameters, C3dHolefillParameters, C3dHessianEigenvaluesParameters, C3dHessianObjectnessParameters, C3dHistogramMatchParameters, C3dInfoParameters, C3dInfoFullParameters, C3dInsertParameters, C3dInterpolationParameters, C3dIterationsParameters, C3dLabelOverlapParameters, C3dLabelStatisticsParameters, C3dLandmarksToSpheresParameters, C3dLaplacianParameters, C3dLevelsetParameters, C3dLevelsetCurvatureParameters, C3dLevelsetAdvectionParameters, C3dLogParameters, C3dLog10Parameters, C3dManualParameters, C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters, C3dMaximumParameters, C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters, C3dMeanParameters, C3dMedianFilterParameters, C3dMergeParameters, C3dMeanFilterParameters, C3dMutualInfoParameters, C3dMinimumParameters, C3dMixtureModelParameters, C3dMomentsParameters, C3dMattesMutualInfoParameters, C3dMeanSquareParameters, C3dMultiplyParameters, C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters, C3dNormalizedCorrelationParameters, C3dNormalizedMutualInfoParameters, C3dNoiseGaussianParameters, C3dNoisePoissonParameters, C3dNoiseSpeckleParameters, C3dNoiseSaltPepperParameters, C3dNoMulticomponentSplitParameters, C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters, C3dNormpdfParameters, C3dNoroundParameters, C3dNospmParameters, C3dOutputParameters, C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters, C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters, C3dOrientParameters, C3dOutputMultipleParameters, C3dOrient1Parameters, C3dOriginParameters, C3dOriginVoxelParameters, C3dOriginVoxelCoordParameters, C3dOverlapParameters, C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters, C3dPadParameters, C3dPadToParameters, C3dPcaParameters, C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters, C3dPixelParameters, C3dPopParameters, C3dPopasParameters, C3dProbeParameters, C3dPushParameters, C3dRankParameters, C3dReciprocalParameters, C3dRegionParameters, C3dReorderParameters, C3dRetainLabelsParameters, C3dRfApplyParameters, C3dRfTrainParameters, C3dRfParamPatchParameters, C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNousexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNtreesParameters, C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters, C3dSetSformParameters, C3dReplaceParameters, C3dResampleParameters, C3dResampleIsoParameters, C3dResampleMmParameters, C3dResliceItkParameters, C3dResliceMatrixParameters, C3dResliceIdentityParameters, C3dRgb2hsvParameters, C3dRmsParameters, C3dRoundParameters, C3dScaleParameters, C3dSetSform1Parameters, C3dSinParameters, C3dSliceParameters, C3dSliceAllParameters, C3dSharpenParameters, C3dShiftParameters, C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters, C3dSmoothParameters, C3dSmoothFastParameters, C3dSpacingParameters, C3dSplitParameters, C3dSqrtParameters, C3dStapleParameters, C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters, C3dSpmParameters, C3dSubtractParameters, C3dSupervoxelParameters, C3dStretchParameters, C3dSwapdimParameters, C3dTestImageParameters, C3dTestProbeParameters, C3dThresholdParameters, C3dTileParameters, C3dTrimParameters, C3dTrimToSizeParameters, C3dTypeParameters, C3dVerboseParameters, C3dNoverboseParameters, C3dVersionParameters, C3dVoteParameters, C3dVoteMrfParameters, C3dVoteLabelParameters, C3dVoxelSumParameters, C3dVoxelIntegralParameters, C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters, C3dWarpParameters, C3dWarpLabelParameters, C3dWrapParameters, C3dWeightedSumParameters, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters]],
 9988    output: str,
 9989) -> C3dParameters:
 9990    """
 9991    Build parameters.
 9992    
 9993    Args:
 9994        input_: The input image to process.
 9995        operations: The operations to perform.
 9996        output: The output image.
 9997    Returns:
 9998        Parameter dictionary
 9999    """
10000    params = {
10001        "__STYXTYPE__": "c3d",
10002        "input": input_,
10003        "operations": operations,
10004        "output": output,
10005    }
10006    return params
10007
10008
10009def c3d_cargs(
10010    params: C3dParameters,
10011    execution: Execution,
10012) -> list[str]:
10013    """
10014    Build command-line arguments from parameters.
10015    
10016    Args:
10017        params: The parameters.
10018        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
10019    Returns:
10020        Command-line arguments.
10021    """
10022    cargs = []
10023    cargs.append("c3d")
10024    cargs.append(" ".join([execution.input_file(f) for f in params.get("input")]))
10025    cargs.extend([a for c in [dyn_cargs(s["__STYXTYPE__"])(s, execution) for s in params.get("operations")] for a in c])
10026    cargs.extend([
10027        "-o",
10028        params.get("output")
10029    ])
10030    return cargs
10031
10032
10033def c3d_outputs(
10034    params: C3dParameters,
10035    execution: Execution,
10036) -> C3dOutputs:
10037    """
10038    Build outputs object containing output file paths and possibly stdout/stderr.
10039    
10040    Args:
10041        params: The parameters.
10042        execution: The execution object for resolving input paths.
10043    Returns:
10044        Outputs object.
10045    """
10046    ret = C3dOutputs(
10047        root=execution.output_file("."),
10048        operations=[dyn_outputs(i["__STYXTYPE__"])(i, execution) if dyn_outputs(i["__STYXTYPE__"]) else None for i in params.get("operations")],
10049    )
10050    return ret
10051
10052
10053def c3d_execute(
10054    params: C3dParameters,
10055    execution: Execution,
10056) -> C3dOutputs:
10057    """
10058    C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.
10059    
10060    Author: Convert3D Developers
10061    
10062    URL: http://www.itksnap.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Convert3D.Convert3D
10063    
10064    Args:
10065        params: The parameters.
10066        execution: The execution object.
10067    Returns:
10068        NamedTuple of outputs (described in `C3dOutputs`).
10069    """
10070    cargs = c3d_cargs(params, execution)
10071    ret = c3d_outputs(params, execution)
10072    execution.run(cargs)
10073    return ret
10074
10075
10076def c3d_(
10077    input_: list[InputPathType],
10078    operations: list[typing.Union[C3dAccumParameters, C3dAcosParameters, C3dAddParameters, C3dAlignLandmarksParameters, C3dAnisotropicDiffusionParameters, C3dAntialiasParameters, C3dSetParameters, C3dAsinParameters, C3dAtan2Parameters, C3dBackgroundParameters, C3dN4BiasCorrectionParameters, C3dBinarizeParameters, C3dCannyParameters, C3dCeilParameters, C3dCentroidParameters, C3dCentroidMarkParameters, C3dConnectedComponentsParameters, C3dClearParameters, C3dClipParameters, C3dColorMapParameters, C3dCompressParameters, C3dNoCompressParameters, C3dConvParameters, C3dCoordinateMapVoxelParameters, C3dCoordinateMapPhysicalParameters, C3dCopyTransformParameters, C3dCosParameters, C3dCreateParameters, C3dDicomSeriesListParameters, C3dDicomSeriesReadParameters, C3dDilateParameters, C3dDivideParameters, C3dDuplicateParameters, C3dEndaccumParameters, C3dEndforParameters, C3dErodeParameters, C3dErfParameters, C3dExpParameters, C3dExportPatchesParameters, C3dExportPatchesAugParameters, C3dExtrudeSegParameters, C3dFillBackgroundWithNoiseParameters, C3dFftParameters, C3dFlipParameters, C3dFloorParameters, C3dForeachParameters, C3dForeachCompParameters, C3dGlmParameters, C3dGradientParameters, C3dHelpParameters, C3dHolefillParameters, C3dHessianEigenvaluesParameters, C3dHessianObjectnessParameters, C3dHistogramMatchParameters, C3dInfoParameters, C3dInfoFullParameters, C3dInsertParameters, C3dInterpolationParameters, C3dIterationsParameters, C3dLabelOverlapParameters, C3dLabelStatisticsParameters, C3dLandmarksToSpheresParameters, C3dLaplacianParameters, C3dLevelsetParameters, C3dLevelsetCurvatureParameters, C3dLevelsetAdvectionParameters, C3dLogParameters, C3dLog10Parameters, C3dManualParameters, C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters, C3dMaximumParameters, C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters, C3dMeanParameters, C3dMedianFilterParameters, C3dMergeParameters, C3dMeanFilterParameters, C3dMutualInfoParameters, C3dMinimumParameters, C3dMixtureModelParameters, C3dMomentsParameters, C3dMattesMutualInfoParameters, C3dMeanSquareParameters, C3dMultiplyParameters, C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters, C3dNormalizedCorrelationParameters, C3dNormalizedMutualInfoParameters, C3dNoiseGaussianParameters, C3dNoisePoissonParameters, C3dNoiseSpeckleParameters, C3dNoiseSaltPepperParameters, C3dNoMulticomponentSplitParameters, C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters, C3dNormpdfParameters, C3dNoroundParameters, C3dNospmParameters, C3dOutputParameters, C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters, C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters, C3dOrientParameters, C3dOutputMultipleParameters, C3dOrient1Parameters, C3dOriginParameters, C3dOriginVoxelParameters, C3dOriginVoxelCoordParameters, C3dOverlapParameters, C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters, C3dPadParameters, C3dPadToParameters, C3dPcaParameters, C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters, C3dPixelParameters, C3dPopParameters, C3dPopasParameters, C3dProbeParameters, C3dPushParameters, C3dRankParameters, C3dReciprocalParameters, C3dRegionParameters, C3dReorderParameters, C3dRetainLabelsParameters, C3dRfApplyParameters, C3dRfTrainParameters, C3dRfParamPatchParameters, C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNousexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNtreesParameters, C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters, C3dSetSformParameters, C3dReplaceParameters, C3dResampleParameters, C3dResampleIsoParameters, C3dResampleMmParameters, C3dResliceItkParameters, C3dResliceMatrixParameters, C3dResliceIdentityParameters, C3dRgb2hsvParameters, C3dRmsParameters, C3dRoundParameters, C3dScaleParameters, C3dSetSform1Parameters, C3dSinParameters, C3dSliceParameters, C3dSliceAllParameters, C3dSharpenParameters, C3dShiftParameters, C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters, C3dSmoothParameters, C3dSmoothFastParameters, C3dSpacingParameters, C3dSplitParameters, C3dSqrtParameters, C3dStapleParameters, C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters, C3dSpmParameters, C3dSubtractParameters, C3dSupervoxelParameters, C3dStretchParameters, C3dSwapdimParameters, C3dTestImageParameters, C3dTestProbeParameters, C3dThresholdParameters, C3dTileParameters, C3dTrimParameters, C3dTrimToSizeParameters, C3dTypeParameters, C3dVerboseParameters, C3dNoverboseParameters, C3dVersionParameters, C3dVoteParameters, C3dVoteMrfParameters, C3dVoteLabelParameters, C3dVoxelSumParameters, C3dVoxelIntegralParameters, C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters, C3dWarpParameters, C3dWarpLabelParameters, C3dWrapParameters, C3dWeightedSumParameters, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters]],
10079    output: str,
10080    runner: Runner | None = None,
10081) -> C3dOutputs:
10082    """
10083    C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.
10084    
10085    Author: Convert3D Developers
10086    
10087    URL: http://www.itksnap.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Convert3D.Convert3D
10088    
10089    Args:
10090        input_: The input image to process.
10091        operations: The operations to perform.
10092        output: The output image.
10093        runner: Command runner.
10094    Returns:
10095        NamedTuple of outputs (described in `C3dOutputs`).
10096    """
10097    runner = runner or get_global_runner()
10098    execution = runner.start_execution(C3D_METADATA)
10099    params = c3d_params(input_=input_, operations=operations, output=output)
10100    return c3d_execute(params, execution)
10101

C3D_METADATA = Metadata(id='2fd805b886703d905dbdaa3b379abc89e94dfe54.boutiques', name='c3d', package='c3d', citations=None, container_image_tag='pyushkevich/itksnap:v3.8.2')
class C3dAccumParameters(typing.TypedDict):
accum: str
class C3dAcosParameters(typing.TypedDict):
acos: str
class C3dAddParameters(typing.TypedDict):
add: str
class C3dAlignLandmarksParameters(typing.TypedDict):
align_landmarks: str
class C3dAnisotropicDiffusionParameters(typing.TypedDict):
anisotropic_diffusion: str
class C3dAntialiasParameters(typing.TypedDict):
antialias: str
class C3dAsinParameters(typing.TypedDict):
asin: str
class C3dAtan2Parameters(typing.TypedDict):
atan2: str
class C3dBackgroundParameters(typing.TypedDict):
background: str
class C3dBinarizeParameters(typing.TypedDict):
binarize: str
class C3dCannyParameters(typing.TypedDict):
canny: str
class C3dCeilParameters(typing.TypedDict):
ceil: str
class C3dCentroidMarkParameters(typing.TypedDict):
centroid_mark: str
class C3dCentroidParameters(typing.TypedDict):
centroid: str
class C3dClearParameters(typing.TypedDict):
class C3dClipParameters(typing.TypedDict):
clip: str
class C3dColorMapParameters(typing.TypedDict):
color_map: str
class C3dCompressParameters(typing.TypedDict):
compress: str
class C3dConnectedComponentsParameters(typing.TypedDict):
connected_components: str
class C3dConvParameters(typing.TypedDict):
conv: str
class C3dCoordinateMapPhysicalParameters(typing.TypedDict):
coordinate_map_physical: str
class C3dCoordinateMapVoxelParameters(typing.TypedDict):
coordinate_map_voxel: str
class C3dCopyTransformParameters(typing.TypedDict):
copy_transform: str
class C3dCosParameters(typing.TypedDict):
cos: str
class C3dCreateParameters(typing.TypedDict):
create: str
class C3dDicomSeriesListParameters(typing.TypedDict):
dicom_series_list: str
class C3dDicomSeriesReadParameters(typing.TypedDict):
dicom_series_read: str
class C3dDilateParameters(typing.TypedDict):
dilate: str
class C3dDivideParameters(typing.TypedDict):
divide: str
class C3dDuplicateParameters(typing.TypedDict):
duplicate: str
class C3dEndaccumParameters(typing.TypedDict):
endaccum: str
class C3dEndforParameters(typing.TypedDict):
endfor: str
class C3dErfParameters(typing.TypedDict):
erf: str
class C3dErodeParameters(typing.TypedDict):
erode: str
class C3dExpParameters(typing.TypedDict):
exp: str
class C3dExportPatchesAugParameters(typing.TypedDict):
export_patches_aug: str

5585class C3dOutputOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):
5586    """
5587    Output object returned when calling `C3dOutputParameters(...)`.
5588    """
5589    root: OutputPathType
5590    """Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs."""
5591    output: OutputPathType
5592    """The output"""

Output object returned when calling C3dOutputParameters(...).

C3dOutputOutputs(root: pathlib._local.Path, output: pathlib._local.Path)

Create new instance of C3dOutputOutputs(root, output)

root: pathlib._local.Path

Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs.

output: pathlib._local.Path

The output

class C3dOutputs(typing.NamedTuple): 
9975class C3dOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):
9976    """
9977    Output object returned when calling `c3d_(...)`.
9978    """
9979    root: OutputPathType
9980    """Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs."""
9981    operations: list[typing.Union[C3dOutputOutputs]]
9982    """Outputs from `C3dOutputParameters`.This is a list of outputs with the
9983    same length and order as the inputs."""

Output object returned when calling c3d_(...).

C3dOutputs( root: pathlib._local.Path, operations: list[C3dOutputOutputs])

Create new instance of C3dOutputs(root, operations)

root: pathlib._local.Path

Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs.

operations: list[C3dOutputOutputs]

Outputs from C3dOutputParameters.This is a list of outputs with the same length and order as the inputs.

C3dRfTrainParameters, C3dRfParamPatchParameters, C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNousexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNtreesParameters, C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters, C3dSetSformParameters, C3dReplaceParameters, C3dResampleParameters, C3dResampleIsoParameters, C3dResampleMmParameters, C3dResliceItkParameters, C3dResliceMatrixParameters, C3dResliceIdentityParameters, C3dRgb2hsvParameters, C3dRmsParameters, C3dRoundParameters, C3dScaleParameters, C3dSetSform1Parameters, C3dSinParameters, C3dSliceParameters, C3dSliceAllParameters, C3dSharpenParameters, C3dShiftParameters, C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters, C3dSmoothParameters, C3dSmoothFastParameters, C3dSpacingParameters, C3dSplitParameters, C3dSqrtParameters, C3dStapleParameters, C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters, C3dSpmParameters, C3dSubtractParameters, C3dSupervoxelParameters, C3dStretchParameters, C3dSwapdimParameters, C3dTestImageParameters, C3dTestProbeParameters, C3dThresholdParameters, C3dTileParameters, C3dTrimParameters, C3dTrimToSizeParameters, C3dTypeParameters, C3dVerboseParameters, C3dNoverboseParameters, C3dVersionParameters, C3dVoteParameters, C3dVoteMrfParameters, C3dVoteLabelParameters, C3dVoxelSumParameters, C3dVoxelIntegralParameters, C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters, C3dWarpParameters, C3dWarpLabelParameters, C3dWrapParameters, C3dWeightedSumParameters, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters]],
10080    output: str,
10081    runner: Runner | None = None,
10082) -> C3dOutputs:
10083    """
10084    C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.
10085    
10086    Author: Convert3D Developers
10087    
10088    URL: http://www.itksnap.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Convert3D.Convert3D
10089    
10090    Args:
10091        input_: The input image to process.
10092        operations: The operations to perform.
10093        output: The output image.
10094        runner: Command runner.
10095    Returns:
10096        NamedTuple of outputs (described in `C3dOutputs`).
10097    """
10098    runner = runner or get_global_runner()
10099    execution = runner.start_execution(C3D_METADATA)
10100    params = c3d_params(input_=input_, operations=operations, output=output)
10101    return c3d_execute(params, execution)

C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.

Author: Convert3D Developers

URL: http://www.itksnap.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Convert3D.Convert3D

Arguments:
  • input_: The input image to process.
  • operations: The operations to perform.
  • output: The output image.
  • runner: Command runner.
Returns:

NamedTuple of outputs (described in C3dOutputs).

def c3d__help_params(v__help: str) -> C3dHelpParameters: 
3394def c3d__help_params(
3395    v__help: str,
3396) -> C3dHelpParameters:
3397    """
3398    Build parameters.
3399    
3400    Args:
3401        v__help: -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the\
3402            Hessian matrix\
3403            \
3404            Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`\
3405            \
3406            Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the\
3407            eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by\
3408            value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture\
3409            features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines\
3410            the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial\
3411            derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.\
3412            \
3413            c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
3414    Returns:
3415        Parameter dictionary
3416    """
3417    params = {
3418        "__STYXTYPE__": "_help",
3419        "_help": v__help,
3420    }
3421    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • v__help: -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix Syntax -hesseig <scale> Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units. c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_accum_params(accum: str) -> C3dAccumParameters: 
951def c3d_accum_params(
952    accum: str,
953) -> C3dAccumParameters:
954    """
955    Build parameters.
956    
957    Args:
958        accum: -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images\
959            \
960            Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`\
961            \
962            Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to\
963            all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s)\
964            will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack,\
965            then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on\
966            the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to\
967            add multiple images.\
968            \
969            c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii.
970    Returns:
971        Parameter dictionary
972    """
973    params = {
974        "__STYXTYPE__": "accum",
975        "accum": accum,
976    }
977    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • accum: -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_add_params(add: str) -> C3dAddParameters: 
1040def c3d_add_params(
1041    add: str,
1042) -> C3dAddParameters:
1043    """
1044    Build parameters.
1045    
1046    Args:
1047        add: -add: Voxelwise image addition\
1048            \
1049            Syntax: `-add`\
1050            \
1051            Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the\
1052            end of the stack.\
1053            \
1054            # Add two images: x = a + b\
1055            c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img\
1056            \
1057            # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a +\
1058            (b + c) in the second\
1059            c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img\
1060            c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img\
1061            \
1062            # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b\
1063            c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img.
1064    Returns:
1065        Parameter dictionary
1066    """
1067    params = {
1068        "__STYXTYPE__": "add",
1069        "add": add,
1070    }
1071    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • add: -add: Voxelwise image addition Syntax: -add Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack. # Add two images: x = a + b c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_align_landmarks_params(align_landmarks: str) -> C3dAlignLandmarksParameters: 
1095def c3d_align_landmarks_params(
1096    align_landmarks: str,
1097) -> C3dAlignLandmarksParameters:
1098    """
1099    Build parameters.
1100    
1101    Args:
1102        align_landmarks: -alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark\
1103            matching\
1104            \
1105            Syntax: `-alm dof outfile`\
1106            \
1107            Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark\
1108            images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity\
1109            value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a\
1110            landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in\
1111            ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the\
1112            stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the\
1113            moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a\
1114            number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the\
1115            output matrix file. In this example, we have images **fixed.nii*\
1116            and **moving.nii** with corresponding landmark images. We use\
1117            landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed:\
1118            \
1119            c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat\
1120            c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o\
1121            moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii.
1122    Returns:
1123        Parameter dictionary
1124    """
1125    params = {
1126        "__STYXTYPE__": "align_landmarks",
1127        "align_landmarks": align_landmarks,
1128    }
1129    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • align_landmarks: -alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching Syntax: -alm dof outfile Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the output matrix file. In this example, we have images fixed.nii* and **moving.nii with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed: c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_anisotropic_diffusion_params( anisotropic_diffusion: str) -> C3dAnisotropicDiffusionParameters:

1165            end of the stack.\
1166            \
1167            # Add two images: x = a + b\
1168            c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img\
1169            \
1170            # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a +\
1171            (b + c) in the second\
1172            c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img\
1173            c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img\
1174            \
1175            # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b\
1176            c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img.
1177    Returns:
1178        Parameter dictionary
1179    """

1182        "anisotropic_diffusion": anisotropic_diffusion,
1183    }
1184    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • anisotropic_diffusion: -add: Voxelwise image addition Syntax: -add Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack. # Add two images: x = a + b c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img.

def c3d_atan2_params(atan2: str) -> C3dAtan2Parameters: 
1338def c3d_atan2_params(
1339    atan2: str,
1340) -> C3dAtan2Parameters:
1341    """
1342    Build parameters.
1343    
1344    Args:
1345        atan2: -atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine\
1346            \
1347            Syntax: `-atan2`\
1348            \
1349            Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and\
1350            cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on\
1351            the stack (sine followed by cosine):\
1352            \
1353            c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz.
1354    Returns:
1355        Parameter dictionary
1356    """
1357    params = {
1358        "__STYXTYPE__": "atan2",
1359        "atan2": atan2,
1360    }
1361    return params

  • atan2: -atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine Syntax: -atan2 Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine followed by cosine): c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz.
Returns:

def c3d_background_params(background: str) -> C3dBackgroundParameters:

1386    background: str,
1387) -> C3dBackgroundParameters:
1388    """

1390

1395            \

1398            is 0.
1399    Returns:
1400        Parameter dictionary
1401    """

1403        "__STYXTYPE__": "background",
1404        "background": background,
1405    }

def c3d_binarize_params(binarize: str) -> C3dBinarizeParameters: 
1477def c3d_binarize_params(
1478    binarize: str,
1479) -> C3dBinarizeParameters:
1480    """
1481    Build parameters.
1482    
1483    Args:
1484        binarize: -binarize: Convert image to binary\
1485            \
1486            Syntax: `-binarize`\
1487            \
1488            Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the\
1489            background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option\
1490            **-background**) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The\
1491            **-binarize** command is shorthand for the **-threshold** command.\
1492            \
1493            c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img\
1494            c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img\
1495            c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1 // equivalent to above command.
1496    Returns:
1497        Parameter dictionary
1498    """
1499    params = {
1500        "__STYXTYPE__": "binarize",
1501        "binarize": binarize,
1502    }
1503    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • binarize: -binarize: Convert image to binary Syntax: -binarize Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option -background) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The -binarize command is shorthand for the -threshold command. c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1 // equivalent to above command.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_canny_params(canny: str) -> C3dCannyParameters: 
1527def c3d_canny_params(
1528    canny: str,
1529) -> C3dCannyParameters:
1530    """
1531    Build parameters.
1532    
1533    Args:
1534        canny: -canny: Canny edge detector\
1535            \
1536            Syntax: `-canny <sigma_vector> <t_lower> <t_upper>`\
1537            \
1538            Performs edge detection on the last image on the stack using the\
1539            Canny filter. The parameters are a vector of standard deviations\
1540            defining the scale of the edges detected and lower and upper\
1541            thresholds for edge selection. See documentation on the [ITK Canny\
1542            Filter][14].
1543    Returns:
1544        Parameter dictionary
1545    """
1546    params = {
1547        "__STYXTYPE__": "canny",
1548        "canny": canny,
1549    }
1550    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • canny: -canny: Canny edge detector Syntax: -canny <sigma_vector> <t_lower> <t_upper> Performs edge detection on the last image on the stack using the Canny filter. The parameters are a vector of standard deviations defining the scale of the edges detected and lower and upper thresholds for edge selection. See documentation on the [ITK Canny Filter][14].
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

1584            \
1585            Each image intensity is replaced by the smallest integer larger or\
1586            equal to it\
1587            \
1588            c3d input.img -ceil -o output.img.
1589    Returns:
1590        Parameter dictionary
1591    """

1594        "ceil": ceil,
1595    }
1596    return params

  • ceil: -ceil: Round up image intensities Syntax: -ceil Each image intensity is replaced by the smallest integer larger or equal to it c3d input.img -ceil -o output.img.

def c3d_centroid_mark_params(centroid_mark: str) -> C3dCentroidMarkParameters: 
1672def c3d_centroid_mark_params(
1673    centroid_mark: str,
1674) -> C3dCentroidMarkParameters:
1675    """
1676    Build parameters.
1677    
1678    Args:
1679        centroid_mark: -centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels\
1680            \
1681            Syntax: `-centroid-mark <label>`\
1682            \
1683            Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike\
1684            **-centroid**, this command does not print the centroid location,\
1685            but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity\
1686            **label**. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined\
1687            with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with\
1688            spheres.\
1689            \
1690            c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3\
1691            c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o\
1692            centers.nii.
1693    Returns:
1694        Parameter dictionary
1695    """
1696    params = {
1697        "__STYXTYPE__": "centroid_mark",
1698        "centroid_mark": centroid_mark,
1699    }
1700    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • centroid_mark: -centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels Syntax: -centroid-mark <label> Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike -centroid, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity label. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with spheres. c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3 c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o centers.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_centroid_params(centroid: str) -> C3dCentroidParameters: 
1620def c3d_centroid_params(
1621    centroid: str,
1622) -> C3dCentroidParameters:
1623    """
1624    Build parameters.
1625    
1626    Args:
1627        centroid: -centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels\
1628            \
1629            Syntax: `-centroid`\
1630            \
1631            Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground\
1632            voxels in the image.\
1633            \
1634            c3d binaryimage.img -centroid // centroid of all non-0 voxels\
1635            c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1 // centroid of\
1636            all voxels in range 1000-7000\
1637            c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid // centroid of all\
1638            voxels with label 5\
1639            c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor // centroids\
1640            of all labels (including 0).
1641    Returns:
1642        Parameter dictionary
1643    """
1644    params = {
1645        "__STYXTYPE__": "centroid",
1646        "centroid": centroid,
1647    }
1648    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • centroid: -centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels Syntax: -centroid Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in the image. c3d binaryimage.img -centroid // centroid of all non-0 voxels c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1 // centroid of all voxels in range 1000-7000 c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid // centroid of all voxels with label 5 c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor // centroids of all labels (including 0).
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_clear_params(clear_: str) -> C3dClearParameters: 
1776def c3d_clear_params(
1777    clear_: str,
1778) -> C3dClearParameters:
1779    """
1780    Build parameters.
1781    
1782    Args:
1783        clear_: -clear: Clear the image stack\
1784            \
1785            Syntax: `-clear`\
1786            \
1787            Clears the image stack. Images assigned a name with the **-as**\
1788            command will remain in memory.
1789    Returns:
1790        Parameter dictionary
1791    """
1792    params = {
1793        "__STYXTYPE__": "clear",
1794        "clear": clear_,
1795    }
1796    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • clear_: -clear: Clear the image stack Syntax: -clear Clears the image stack. Images assigned a name with the -as command will remain in memory.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_clip_params(clip: str) -> C3dClipParameters: 
1820def c3d_clip_params(
1821    clip: str,
1822) -> C3dClipParameters:
1823    """
1824    Build parameters.
1825    
1826    Args:
1827        clip: -clip: Clip image intensity to range\
1828            \
1829            Syntax: `-clip iMin iMax`\
1830            \
1831            Clips image intensities, so that the values below *iMin* are\
1832            converted to *iMin* and values greater than *iMax* are converted to\
1833            *iMax*. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images.\
1834            Values *iMin* and *iMax* are intensity specifications (see below).\
1835            \
1836            c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img // Clips below and\
1837            above\
1838            c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img // Clips above only\
1839            c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img // Clips at 95th\
1840            percentile.
1841    Returns:
1842        Parameter dictionary
1843    """
1844    params = {
1845        "__STYXTYPE__": "clip",
1846        "clip": clip,
1847    }
1848    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • clip: -clip: Clip image intensity to range Syntax: -clip iMin iMax Clips image intensities, so that the values below iMin are converted to iMin and values greater than iMax are converted to iMax. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values iMin and iMax are intensity specifications (see below). c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img // Clips below and above c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img // Clips above only c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img // Clips at 95th percentile.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_color_map_params(color_map: str) -> C3dColorMapParameters: 
1872def c3d_color_map_params(
1873    color_map: str,
1874) -> C3dColorMapParameters:
1875    """
1876    Build parameters.
1877    
1878    Args:
1879        color_map: -color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using\
1880            color map\
1881            \
1882            Syntax: `-color-map <ColormapName> [min max]`\
1883            \
1884            Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified\
1885            color map. The output of the command are three images, containing\
1886            the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses\
1887            the range of the input image, e.g., using the **jet** color map,\
1888            the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and\
1889            the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible\
1890            color maps are\
1891            **hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder**.\
1892            The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images.\
1893            The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar\
1894            image.\
1895            \
1896            c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar\
1897            -omc colorslice.png\
1898            \
1899            By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional\
1900            **min** and **max** parameters can be used to set the range of the\
1901            color map.\
1902            \
1903            c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type\
1904            uchar -omc colorslice.png.
1905    Returns:
1906        Parameter dictionary
1907    """
1908    params = {
1909        "__STYXTYPE__": "color_map",
1910        "color_map": color_map,
1911    }
1912    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • color_map: -color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map Syntax: -color-map <ColormapName> [min max] Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map. The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input image, e.g., using the jet color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible color maps are hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder. The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image. c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional min and max parameters can be used to set the range of the color map. c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc colorslice.png.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_compress_params(compress: str) -> C3dCompressParameters: 
1936def c3d_compress_params(
1937    compress: str,
1938) -> C3dCompressParameters:
1939    """
1940    Build parameters.
1941    
1942    Args:
1943        compress: -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some\
1944            image files\
1945            \
1946            Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`\
1947            \
1948            Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For\
1949            some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled\
1950            automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For\
1951            other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to\
1952            enable compression. The following two commands save the image as\
1953            compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:\
1954            \
1955            c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz\
1956            c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha.
1957    Returns:
1958        Parameter dictionary
1959    """
1960    params = {
1961        "__STYXTYPE__": "compress",
1962        "compress": compress,
1963    }
1964    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • compress: -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files Syntax: -compress or -no-compress Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files: c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_connected_components_params( connected_components: str) -> C3dConnectedComponentsParameters: 
1724def c3d_connected_components_params(
1725    connected_components: str,
1726) -> C3dConnectedComponentsParameters:
1727    """
1728    Build parameters.
1729    
1730    Args:
1731        connected_components: -comp, -connected-components: Compute connected\
1732            components\
1733            \
1734            Syntax: `-comp`\
1735            \
1736            Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected\
1737            component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the\
1738            size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the\
1739            largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest\
1740            connected component, combine the call to **-comp** with a call to\
1741            **-threshold**.\
1742            \
1743            c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img\
1744            c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img.
1745    Returns:
1746        Parameter dictionary
1747    """
1748    params = {
1749        "__STYXTYPE__": "connected_components",
1750        "connected_components": connected_components,
1751    }
1752    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • connected_components: -comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components Syntax: -comp Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component, combine the call to -comp with a call to -threshold. c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_conv_params(conv: str) -> C3dConvParameters: 
2040def c3d_conv_params(
2041    conv: str,
2042) -> C3dConvParameters:
2043    """
2044    Build parameters.
2045    
2046    Args:
2047        conv: -conv: Convolution\
2048            \
2049            Syntax `-conv`\
2050            \
2051            Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The\
2052            convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is\
2053            an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more\
2054            details, see ["FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann].\
2055            \
2056            c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii\
2057            \
2058            \
2059            [Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154.
2060    Returns:
2061        Parameter dictionary
2062    """
2063    params = {
2064        "__STYXTYPE__": "conv",
2065        "conv": conv,
2066    }
2067    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • conv: -conv: Convolution Syntax -conv Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see ["FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann]. c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii [Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_coordinate_map_physical_params( coordinate_map_physical: str) -> C3dCoordinateMapPhysicalParameters: 
2148def c3d_coordinate_map_physical_params(
2149    coordinate_map_physical: str,
2150) -> C3dCoordinateMapPhysicalParameters:
2151    """
2152    Build parameters.
2153    
2154    Args:
2155        coordinate_map_physical: -cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel\
2156            coordinate maps (voxel units)\
2157            \
2158            Syntax: `-cmp`\
2159            \
2160            This command is similar to **-cmv** (**-coordinate-map-voxel**),\
2161            but the output will contain the physical coordinates of the voxels,\
2162            in the NIFTI (RAS) coordinate frame.
2163    Returns:
2164        Parameter dictionary
2165    """
2166    params = {
2167        "__STYXTYPE__": "coordinate_map_physical",
2168        "coordinate_map_physical": coordinate_map_physical,
2169    }
2170    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • coordinate_map_physical: -cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units) Syntax: -cmp This command is similar to -cmv (-coordinate-map-voxel), but the output will contain the physical coordinates of the voxels, in the NIFTI (RAS) coordinate frame.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_coordinate_map_voxel_params( coordinate_map_voxel: str) -> C3dCoordinateMapVoxelParameters: 
2091def c3d_coordinate_map_voxel_params(
2092    coordinate_map_voxel: str,
2093) -> C3dCoordinateMapVoxelParameters:
2094    """
2095    Build parameters.
2096    
2097    Args:
2098        coordinate_map_voxel: -cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel\
2099            coordinate maps (voxel units)\
2100            \
2101            Syntax: `-cmv`\
2102            \
2103            For a *N*-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack\
2104            with *N* images. The *k*-th output image at each voxel contains the\
2105            $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units.\
2106            \
2107            c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz\
2108            \
2109            One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a\
2110            left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation\
2111            (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)\
2112            \
2113            c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \\\
2114            -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \\\
2115            -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \\\
2116            -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz.
2117    Returns:
2118        Parameter dictionary
2119    """
2120    params = {
2121        "__STYXTYPE__": "coordinate_map_voxel",
2122        "coordinate_map_voxel": coordinate_map_voxel,
2123    }
2124    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • coordinate_map_voxel: -cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units) Syntax: -cmv For a N-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with N images. The k-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units. c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis) c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \ -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \ -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \ -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_copy_transform_params(copy_transform: str) -> C3dCopyTransformParameters: 
2194def c3d_copy_transform_params(
2195    copy_transform: str,
2196) -> C3dCopyTransformParameters:
2197    """
2198    Build parameters.
2199    
2200    Args:
2201        copy_transform: -copy-transform: Copy header information\
2202            \
2203            Syntax: `-copy-transform`\
2204            \
2205            Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space\
2206            transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first\
2207            image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done\
2208            with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the\
2209            example below, *out.nii* will have the same header as *first.nii*\
2210            and the same intensities as *second.nii*.\
2211            \
2212            c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii.
2213    Returns:
2214        Parameter dictionary
2215    """
2216    params = {
2217        "__STYXTYPE__": "copy_transform",
2218        "copy_transform": copy_transform,
2219    }
2220    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • copy_transform: -copy-transform: Copy header information Syntax: -copy-transform Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the example below, out.nii will have the same header as first.nii and the same intensities as second.nii. c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_cos_params(cos: str) -> C3dCosParameters:

  • cos: No description found.

def c3d_create_params(create: str) -> C3dCreateParameters: 
2283def c3d_create_params(
2284    create: str,
2285) -> C3dCreateParameters:
2286    """
2287    Build parameters.
2288    
2289    Args:
2290        create: -create: Generate blank image\
2291            \
2292            Syntax: `-create dimensions voxel_size`\
2293            \
2294            Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size,\
2295            and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the\
2296            current background value, which is 0 by default but can be\
2297            overwritten with the **-background** command. The origin of the\
2298            image can be changed with the **-origin** command.\
2299            \
2300            c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img\
2301            c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin\
2302            128x128x80mm -o newimage.img.
2303    Returns:
2304        Parameter dictionary
2305    """
2306    params = {
2307        "__STYXTYPE__": "create",
2308        "create": create,
2309    }
2310    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • create: -create: Generate blank image Syntax: -create dimensions voxel_size Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the -background command. The origin of the image can be changed with the -origin command. c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o newimage.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

2344            Syntax: `-dicom-series-list <directory>\
2345            \
2346            Prints out a table of DICOM series ids and corresponding image\
2347            information to standard output.
2348    Returns:
2349        Parameter dictionary
2350    """
2351    params = {
2352        "__STYXTYPE__": "dicom_series_list",
2353        "dicom_series_list": dicom_series_list,
2354    }
2355    return params

def c3d_dicom_series_read_params(dicom_series_read: str) -> C3dDicomSeriesReadParameters: 
2379def c3d_dicom_series_read_params(
2380    dicom_series_read: str,
2381) -> C3dDicomSeriesReadParameters:
2382    """

2384    
2385    Args:
2386        dicom_series_read: -dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series\
2387            \
2388            Syntax: `-dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>`\
2389            \
2390            Imports a specific DICOM image series from a directory containing\
2391            DICOM files. The **directory** parameter may also point to one of\
2392            the DICOM files in the directory.\
2393            The **seried_id** is a string identifier for the series that can be\
2394            obtained by calling **-dicom-series-list**.
2395    Returns:
2396        Parameter dictionary
2397    """
2398    params = {
2399        "__STYXTYPE__": "dicom_series_read",
2400        "dicom_series_read": dicom_series_read,
2401    }
2402    return params

The directory parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files in the directory. The seried_id is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained by calling -dicom-series-list.
Returns:

def c3d_dilate_params(dilate: str) -> C3dDilateParameters: 
2426def c3d_dilate_params(
2427    dilate: str,
2428) -> C3dDilateParameters:
2429    """
2430    Build parameters.
2431    
2432    Args:
2433        dilate: -dilate: Binary dilation\
2434            \
2435            Syntax: `-dilate <label> <radius_vector>`\
2436            \
2437            Applies the dilation [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a\
2438            binary image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the\
2439            object that is to be dilated. The second is the radius of the\
2440            dilation structuring element in 3D.\
2441            \
2442            c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img.
2443    Returns:
2444        Parameter dictionary
2445    """
2446    params = {
2447        "__STYXTYPE__": "dilate",
2448        "dilate": dilate,
2449    }
2450    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • dilate: -dilate: Binary dilation Syntax: -dilate <label> <radius_vector> Applies the dilation [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object that is to be dilated. The second is the radius of the dilation structuring element in 3D. c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_divide_params(divide: str) -> C3dDivideParameters: 
2474def c3d_divide_params(
2475    divide: str,
2476) -> C3dDivideParameters:
2477    """
2478    Build parameters.
2479    
2480    Args:
2481        divide: -divide: Voxelwise image division\
2482            \
2483            Syntax: `-divide`\
2484            \
2485            Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B,\
2486            use the command\
2487            \
2488            c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img\
2489            \
2490            Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B\
2491            contains zeros. You can use **-replace** to get rid of these values\
2492            \
2493            c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o\
2494            C2.img.
2495    Returns:
2496        Parameter dictionary
2497    """
2498    params = {
2499        "__STYXTYPE__": "divide",
2500        "divide": divide,
2501    }
2502    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • divide: -divide: Voxelwise image division Syntax: -divide Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the command c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains zeros. You can use -replace to get rid of these values c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_duplicate_params(duplicate: str) -> C3dDuplicateParameters: 
2526def c3d_duplicate_params(
2527    duplicate: str,
2528) -> C3dDuplicateParameters:
2529    """
2530    Build parameters.
2531    
2532    Args:
2533        duplicate: -dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack\
2534            \
2535            Syntax: `-dup`\
2536            \
2537            Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to\
2538            **-as var -push var**, but shorter. An example is when you want to\
2539            pass an image as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g.,\
2540            computing the square of the image intensity:\
2541            \
2542            c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img\
2543            \
2544            ### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations.
2545    Returns:
2546        Parameter dictionary
2547    """
2548    params = {
2549        "__STYXTYPE__": "duplicate",
2550        "duplicate": duplicate,
2551    }
2552    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • duplicate: -dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack Syntax: -dup Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to -as var -push var, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the image intensity: c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img ### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_endaccum_params(endaccum: str) -> C3dEndaccumParameters: 
2576def c3d_endaccum_params(
2577    endaccum: str,
2578) -> C3dEndaccumParameters:
2579    """
2580    Build parameters.
2581    
2582    Args:
2583        endaccum: -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images\
2584            \
2585            Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`\
2586            \
2587            Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to\
2588            all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s)\
2589            will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack,\
2590            then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on\
2591            the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to\
2592            add multiple images.\
2593            \
2594            c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii.
2595    Returns:
2596        Parameter dictionary
2597    """
2598    params = {
2599        "__STYXTYPE__": "endaccum",
2600        "endaccum": endaccum,
2601    }
2602    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • endaccum: -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_endfor_params(endfor: str) -> C3dEndforParameters: 
2626def c3d_endfor_params(
2627    endfor: str,
2628) -> C3dEndforParameters:
2629    """
2630    Build parameters.
2631    
2632    Args:
2633        endfor: -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack\
2634            \
2635            Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`\
2636            \
2637            This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and\
2638            **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use\
2639            of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For\
2640            example,\
2641            \
2642            c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii.
2643    Returns:
2644        Parameter dictionary
2645    """
2646    params = {
2647        "__STYXTYPE__": "endfor",
2648        "endfor": endfor,
2649    }
2650    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • endfor: -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack Syntax: -foreach commands-list -endfor This command forces the commands between -foreach and -endfor to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_erf_params(erf: str) -> C3dErfParameters: 
2722def c3d_erf_params(
2723    erf: str,
2724) -> C3dErfParameters:
2725    """
2726    Build parameters.
2727    
2728    Args:
2729        erf: -erf: Standard error function\
2730            \
2731            Syntax: `-erf mu sigma`\
2732            \
2733            Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying\
2734            soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma).\
2735            \
2736            c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img.
2737    Returns:
2738        Parameter dictionary
2739    """
2740    params = {
2741        "__STYXTYPE__": "erf",
2742        "erf": erf,
2743    }
2744    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • erf: -erf: Standard error function Syntax: -erf mu sigma Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma). c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_erode_params(erode: str) -> C3dErodeParameters: 
2674def c3d_erode_params(

2682            \

2684            \
2685            Applies erosion [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary\
2686            image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object\
2687            that is to be eroded. The second is the radius of the erosion\
2688            structuring element in 3D.\
2689            \
2690            c3d binary.img -erode 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img.
2691    Returns:
2692        Parameter dictionary
2693    """
2694    params = {
2695        "__STYXTYPE__": "erode",
2696        "erode": erode,
2697    }
2698    return params

  • erode: -erode: Binary erosion Syntax: -erode <label> <radius_vector> Applies erosion [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object that is to be eroded. The second is the radius of the erosion structuring element in 3D. c3d binary.img -erode 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_export_patches_aug_params(export_patches_aug: str) -> C3dExportPatchesAugParameters: 
2899def c3d_export_patches_aug_params(
2900    export_patches_aug: str,
2901) -> C3dExportPatchesAugParameters:
2902    """
2903    Build parameters.
2904    
2905    Args:
2906        export_patches_aug: -export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for\
2907            deep learning\
2908            \
2909            Syntax `-export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>`\
2910            \
2911            This command must precede the `-export-patches (-xp)` command and\
2912            instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image\
2913            axes but to also sample **N** randomly rotated patches. Rotation is\
2914            around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle\
2915            distributed normally with teh standard deviation **sigma_angle**,\
2916            specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data\
2917            augmentation for machine learning algorithms.\
2918            \
2919            c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp\
2920            samples.dat 4x4x4 100.
2921    Returns:
2922        Parameter dictionary
2923    """
2924    params = {
2925        "__STYXTYPE__": "export_patches_aug",
2926        "export_patches_aug": export_patches_aug,
2927    }
2928    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • export_patches_aug: -export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning Syntax -export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle> This command must precede the -export-patches (-xp) command and instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also sample N randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh standard deviation sigma_angle, specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms. c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_export_patches_params(export_patches: str) -> C3dExportPatchesParameters: 
2813def c3d_export_patches_params(
2814    export_patches: str,
2815) -> C3dExportPatchesParameters:
2816    """
2817    Build parameters.
2818    
2819    Args:
2820        export_patches: -export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from\
2821            masked regions\
2822            \
2823            Syntax: `-export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>`\
2824            \
2825            See also: **-export-patches-aug (-xpa)** command, which provides\
2826            data augmentation for deep learning.\
2827            \
2828            This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores\
2829            them into a data file that can be read easily in other software,\
2830            for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for\
2831            machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.\
2832            \
2833            c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4\
2834            100\
2835            \
2836            This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at\
2837            foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region\
2838            are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value\
2839            of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The\
2840            radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated.\
2841            For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented\
2842            as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.\
2843            \
2844            To read these samples in NumPy use the following code\
2845            \
2846            dims = (9,9,9) # Patch dimensions\
2847            k = 3 # Number of channels\
2848            bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1)) # Bytes per sample\
2849            np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps # Number of samples\
2850            arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)\
2851            \
2852            It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP\
2853            by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the\
2854            dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the\
2855            number of samples.\
2856            \
2857            The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For\
2858            example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an\
2859            approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of\
2860            given size centered on this lesion, as follows:\
2861            \
2862            c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat\
2863            50x50x20 1\
2864            \
2865            In the above example, **-centroid-mark** transforms the lesion\
2866            segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from\
2867            the MRI is taken.
2868    Returns:
2869        Parameter dictionary
2870    """
2871    params = {
2872        "__STYXTYPE__": "export_patches",
2873        "export_patches": export_patches,
2874    }
2875    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • export_patches: -export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions Syntax: -export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency> See also: -export-patches-aug (-xpa) command, which provides data augmentation for deep learning. This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled. c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100 This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example. To read these samples in NumPy use the following code dims = (9,9,9) # Patch dimensions k = 3 # Number of channels bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1)) # Bytes per sample np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps # Number of samples arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims) It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples. The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion, as follows: c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1 In the above example, -centroid-mark transforms the lesion segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_extrude_seg_params(extrude_seg: str) -> C3dExtrudeSegParameters: 
2952def c3d_extrude_seg_params(
2953    extrude_seg: str,
2954) -> C3dExtrudeSegParameters:
2955    """
2956    Build parameters.
