2961        Parameter dictionary
2962    """
2963    params = {
2964        "__STYXTYPE__": "extrude_seg",
2965        "extrude_seg": extrude_seg,
2966    }
2967    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • extrude_seg: No description found.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_fft_params(fft: str) -> C3dFftParameters: 
3030def c3d_fft_params(
3031    fft: str,
3032) -> C3dFftParameters:
3033    """
3034    Build parameters.
3035    
3036    Args:
3037        fft: -fft: Fast Fourier transform\
3038            \
3039            Syntax `-fft`\
3040            \
3041            Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of\
3042            the stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary\
3043            components of the FFT. This command is only available if\
3044            **convert3d** is compiled with the FFTW library support.\
3045            \
3046            c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii.
3047    Returns:
3048        Parameter dictionary
3049    """
3050    params = {
3051        "__STYXTYPE__": "fft",
3052        "fft": fft,
3053    }
3054    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • fft: -fft: Fast Fourier transform Syntax -fft Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of the stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary components of the FFT. This command is only available if convert3d is compiled with the FFTW library support. c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

3089            Flips the image around specified axes. The parameter 'axes' may be\

3091            matter.\
3092            \
3093            c3d input.img -flip xy -o output.img.
3094    Returns:

3100    }

def c3d_floor_params(floor: str) -> C3dFloorParameters: 
3125def c3d_floor_params(
3126    floor: str,
3127) -> C3dFloorParameters:
3128    """
3129    Build parameters.
3130    
3131    Args:
3132        floor: -floor: Round down image intensities\
3133            \
3134            Syntax: `-floor `\
3135            \
3136            Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or\
3137            equal to it.\
3138            \
3139            c3d input.img -floor -o output.img\
3140            \
3141            To round each intensity to the closest integer, use\
3142            \
3143            c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor.
3144    Returns:
3145        Parameter dictionary
3146    """
3147    params = {
3148        "__STYXTYPE__": "floor",
3149        "floor": floor,
3150    }
3151    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • floor: -floor: Round down image intensities Syntax: -floor Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to it. c3d input.img -floor -o output.img To round each intensity to the closest integer, use c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_foreach_comp_params(foreach_comp: str) -> C3dForeachCompParameters: 
3223def c3d_foreach_comp_params(
3224    foreach_comp: str,
3225) -> C3dForeachCompParameters:
3226    """
3227    Build parameters.
3228    
3229    Args:
3230        foreach_comp: -foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of\
3231            a multi-component image\
3232            \
3233            Syntax `-foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor`\
3234            \
3235            This command runs the list of commands separately for each\
3236            component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This\
3237            makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on\
3238            multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average\
3239            several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images\
3240            *x1* *y1* *z1* *x2* *y2* *z2*, then the operations will be run on\
3241            *[x1,x2]*, *[y1,y2]*, *[z1,z2]*. For example, if multi_1.nii to\
3242            multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean\
3243            three-component image is given by\
3244            \
3245            c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc\
3246            multi_mean.nii.
3247    Returns:
3248        Parameter dictionary
3249    """
3250    params = {
3251        "__STYXTYPE__": "foreach_comp",
3252        "foreach_comp": foreach_comp,
3253    }
3254    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • foreach_comp: -foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a multi-component image Syntax -foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images x1 y1 z1 x2 y2 z2, then the operations will be run on [x1,x2], [y1,y2], [z1,z2]. For example, if multi_1.nii to multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image is given by c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_foreach_params(foreach: str) -> C3dForeachParameters: 
3175def c3d_foreach_params(
3176    foreach: str,
3177) -> C3dForeachParameters:
3178    """
3179    Build parameters.
3180    
3181    Args:
3182        foreach: -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack\
3183            \
3184            Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`\
3185            \
3186            This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and\
3187            **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use\
3188            of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For\
3189            example,\
3190            \
3191            c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii.
3192    Returns:
3193        Parameter dictionary
3194    """
3195    params = {
3196        "__STYXTYPE__": "foreach",
3197        "foreach": foreach,
3198    }
3199    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • foreach: -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack Syntax: -foreach commands-list -endfor This command forces the commands between -foreach and -endfor to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_glm_params(glm: str) -> C3dGlmParameters: 
3278def c3d_glm_params(
3279    glm: str,
3280) -> C3dGlmParameters:
3281    """
3282    Build parameters.
3283    
3284    Args:
3285        glm: -glm: General linear model\
3286            \
3287            Syntax: `-glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file`\
3288            \
3289            Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More\
3290            precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y\
3291            = X \\beta + \\epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n\
3292            images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation);\
3293            X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors;\
3294            $\\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\\epsilon$\
3295            is the error term. The command will compute the $\\beta$ images and\
3296            return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in\
3297            the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are\
3298            passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list\
3299            of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see\
3300            [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner,\
3301            Friston, Holmes eds., *Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition*][6]. The\
3302            example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of\
3303            longitudinal images and subject's age:\
3304            \
3305            echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt\
3306            echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt\
3307            echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt\
3308            echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt\
3309            echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt\
3310            c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt\
3311            contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img.
3312    Returns:
3313        Parameter dictionary
3314    """
3315    params = {
3316        "__STYXTYPE__": "glm",
3317        "glm": glm,
3318    }
3319    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • glm: -glm: General linear model Syntax: -glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X \beta + \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute the $\beta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds., Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition][6]. The example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's age: echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_gradient_params(gradient: str) -> C3dGradientParameters: 
3343def c3d_gradient_params(
3344    gradient: str,
3345) -> C3dGradientParameters:
3346    """
3347    Build parameters.
3348    
3349    Args:
3350        gradient: -grad, -gradient: Image gradient\
3351            \
3352            Syntax `-grad`\
3353            \
3354            Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient\
3355            is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed\
3356            in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and\
3357            orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical\
3358            space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is\
3359            performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before\
3360            computing the gradient.\
3361            \
3362            c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii.
3363    Returns:
3364        Parameter dictionary
3365    """
3366    params = {
3367        "__STYXTYPE__": "gradient",
3368        "gradient": gradient,
3369    }
3370    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • gradient: -grad, -gradient: Image gradient Syntax -grad Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before computing the gradient. c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_hessian_eigenvalues_params( hessian_eigenvalues: str) -> C3dHessianEigenvaluesParameters: 
3500def c3d_hessian_eigenvalues_params(
3501    hessian_eigenvalues: str,
3502) -> C3dHessianEigenvaluesParameters:
3503    """
3504    Build parameters.
3505    
3506    Args:
3507        hessian_eigenvalues: -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute\
3508            eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix\
3509            \
3510            Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`\
3511            \
3512            Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the\
3513            eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by\
3514            value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture\
3515            features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines\
3516            the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial\
3517            derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.\
3518            \
3519            c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
3520    Returns:
3521        Parameter dictionary
3522    """
3523    params = {
3524        "__STYXTYPE__": "hessian_eigenvalues",
3525        "hessian_eigenvalues": hessian_eigenvalues,
3526    }
3527    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • hessian_eigenvalues: -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix Syntax -hesseig <scale> Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units. c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_hessian_objectness_params(hessian_objectness: str) -> C3dHessianObjectnessParameters: 
3551def c3d_hessian_objectness_params(
3552    hessian_objectness: str,
3553) -> C3dHessianObjectnessParameters:
3554    """
3555    Build parameters.
3556    
3557    Args:
3558        hessian_objectness: -hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness\
3559            filter\
3560            \
3561            Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`\
3562            \
3563            Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used\
3564            to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the\
3565            image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK\
3566            class][HTOMIF].\
3567            \
3568            Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of\
3569            features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for\
3570            pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point\
3571            values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical\
3572            units. Typically, just one scale is used.\
3573            \
3574            # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm\
3575            c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5\
3576            \
3577            [HTOMIF]\
3578            http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html.
3579    Returns:
3580        Parameter dictionary
3581    """
3582    params = {
3583        "__STYXTYPE__": "hessian_objectness",
3584        "hessian_objectness": hessian_objectness,
3585    }
3586    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • hessian_objectness: -hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter Syntax: -hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale> Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF]. Parameter dimension is an integer that determines the kind of features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is used. # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5 [HTOMIF] http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_holefill_params(holefill: str) -> C3dHolefillParameters: 
3445def c3d_holefill_params(
3446    holefill: str,
3447) -> C3dHolefillParameters:
3448    """
3449    Build parameters.
3450    
3451    Args:
3452        holefill: -holefill: Fill holes in binary image\
3453            \
3454            Syntax: `-holefill intensity_value [0|1] `\
3455            \
3456            Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity\
3457            value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or\
3458            a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the\
3459            specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels\
3460            matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies\
3461            what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes.\
3462            The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity)\
3463            and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex\
3464            connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this\
3465            algorithm][7].\
3466            \
3467            c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o\
3468            filledlabel5.nii.gz.
3469    Returns:
3470        Parameter dictionary
3471    """
3472    params = {
3473        "__STYXTYPE__": "holefill",
3474        "holefill": holefill,
3475    }
3476    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • holefill: -holefill: Fill holes in binary image Syntax: -holefill intensity_value [0|1] Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this algorithm][7]. c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_info_full_params(info_full: str) -> C3dInfoFullParameters:

3711            Prints extended information about the last image on the stack, such\
3712            as the metadata dictionary. For example,\
3713            \
3714            c3d image.hdr -info-full.
3715    Returns:
3716        Parameter dictionary
3717    """
3718    params = {
3719        "__STYXTYPE__": "info_full",
3720        "info_full": info_full,
3721    }
3722    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • info_full: -info-full: Display verbose image information Syntax: -info-full Prints extended information about the last image on the stack, such as the metadata dictionary. For example, c3d image.hdr -info-full.

def c3d_info_params(info: str) -> C3dInfoParameters: 
3649def c3d_info_params(
3650    info: str,
3651) -> C3dInfoParameters:
3652    """
3653    Build parameters.
3654    
3655    Args:
3656        info: -info: Display brief image information\
3657            \
3658            Syntax: `-info`\
3659            \
3660            Prints brief information about the last image on the stack. Does\
3661            not affect the stack.\
3662            \
3663            c3d image.hdr -info\
3664            \
3665            Use with the **-foreach** command to get information on multiple\
3666            images\
3667            \
3668            c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor.
3669    Returns:
3670        Parameter dictionary
3671    """
3672    params = {
3673        "__STYXTYPE__": "info",
3674        "info": info,
3675    }
3676    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • info: -info: Display brief image information Syntax: -info Prints brief information about the last image on the stack. Does not affect the stack. c3d image.hdr -info Use with the -foreach command to get information on multiple images c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_insert_params(insert: str) -> C3dInsertParameters: 
3746def c3d_insert_params(
3747    insert: str,
3748) -> C3dInsertParameters:
3749    """
3750    Build parameters.
3751    
3752    Args:
3753        insert: -insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack\
3754            \
3755            Syntax: `-insert var pos`\
3756            \
3757            This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the\
3758            image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting\
3759            from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of\
3760            the stack (same as **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed\
3761            at the next-to-end position, and so on.
3762    Returns:
3763        Parameter dictionary
3764    """
3765    params = {
3766        "__STYXTYPE__": "insert",
3767        "insert": insert,
3768    }
3769    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • insert: -insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack Syntax: -insert var pos This command is similar to -push, but allows you to insert the image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as -push). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end position, and so on.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_interpolation_params(interpolation: str) -> C3dInterpolationParameters: 
3793def c3d_interpolation_params(
3794    interpolation: str,
3795) -> C3dInterpolationParameters:
3796    """
3797    Build parameters.
3798    
3799    Args:
3800        interpolation: -interpolation: Set interpolation mode\
3801            \
3802            Syntax: `-interpolation\
3803            <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]`\
3804            \
3805            Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other\
3806            commands. Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as\
3807            the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g,\
3808            1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first\
3809            smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it\
3810            with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less\
3811            aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with\
3812            small sigmas (a few voxels across).\
3813            \
3814            Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3\
3815            for *Cubic*. For example:\
3816            \
3817            c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii.
3818    Returns:
3819        Parameter dictionary
3820    """
3821    params = {
3822        "__STYXTYPE__": "interpolation",
3823        "interpolation": interpolation,
3824    }
3825    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • interpolation: -interpolation: Set interpolation mode Syntax: -interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param] Specifies the interpolation used with -resample and other commands. Default is Linear. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with small sigmas (a few voxels across). Shorthand 0 can be used for NearestNeighbor, 1 for Linear and 3 for Cubic. For example: c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_iterations_params(iterations: str) -> C3dIterationsParameters:

def c3d_label_statistics_params(label_statistics: str) -> C3dLabelStatisticsParameters: 
3927def c3d_label_statistics_params(
3928    label_statistics: str,
3929) -> C3dLabelStatisticsParameters:
3930    """
3931    Build parameters.
3932    
3933    Args:
3934        label_statistics: -lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation\
3935            volumes and intensity statistics\
3936            \
3937            Syntax: `-lstat`\
3938            \
3939            Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this\
3940            command computes the statistics for every label in the latter,\
3941            including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance,\
3942            if image *mri.nii* is a medical image and *seg.nii* is a multilabel\
3943            segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following\
3944            command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of\
3945            *mri.nii* for each of the labels\
3946            \
3947            c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat\
3948            \
3949            The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity\
3950            and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from\
3951            a multi-label image, use **-dup** command as follows:\
3952            \
3953            c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat.
3954    Returns:
3955        Parameter dictionary
3956    """
3957    params = {
3958        "__STYXTYPE__": "label_statistics",
3959        "label_statistics": label_statistics,
3960    }
3961    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • label_statistics: -lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation volumes and intensity statistics Syntax: -lstat Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this command computes the statistics for every label in the latter, including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance, if image mri.nii is a medical image and seg.nii is a multilabel segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of mri.nii for each of the labels c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from a multi-label image, use -dup command as follows: c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_laplacian_params(laplacian: str) -> C3dLaplacianParameters: 
4024def c3d_laplacian_params(
4025    laplacian: str,
4026) -> C3dLaplacianParameters:
4027    """
4028    Build parameters.
4029    
4030    Args:
4031        laplacian: -laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter\
4032            \
4033            Syntax: `-laplacian`\
4034            \
4035            Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of\
4036            intensity. Typically, used with the **-smooth** option to obtain\
4037            the equivalent of convolving the image with the *Laplacian of the\
4038            Gaussian (LoG)* kernel:\
4039            \
4040            c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img.
4041    Returns:
4042        Parameter dictionary
4043    """
4044    params = {
4045        "__STYXTYPE__": "laplacian",
4046        "laplacian": laplacian,
4047    }
4048    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • laplacian: -laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter Syntax: -laplacian Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of intensity. Typically, used with the -smooth option to obtain the equivalent of convolving the image with the Laplacian of the Gaussian (LoG) kernel: c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_levelset_params(levelset: str) -> C3dLevelsetParameters: 
4072def c3d_levelset_params(
4073    levelset: str,
4074) -> C3dLevelsetParameters:
4075    """
4076    Build parameters.
4077    
4078    Args:
4079        levelset: -levelset: Level set segmentation\
4080            \
4081            Syntax: `-levelset n_iter `\
4082            \
4083            Perform level set segmentation for *n\\_iter* iterations, like in\
4084            ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the\
4085            initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the\
4086            speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1.\
4087            Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted\
4088            \
4089            | | Speed Image | Initialization Image | Output Image |\
4090            | -- | ------------- | -------------------- | ------------ |\
4091            | +1 | Foreground | Outside | Outside |\
4092            | -1 | Background | Inside | Inside |\
4093            \
4094            Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization\
4095            given:\
4096            \
4097            c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o\
4098            seg.img\
4099            \
4100            Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image,\
4101            where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The\
4102            image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the\
4103            initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside).\
4104            \
4105            c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz \\\
4106            -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 \\\
4107            -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz\
4108            \
4109            Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for\
4110            cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive\
4111            inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside\
4112            the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose\
4113            0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the\
4114            smoothed binary object\
4115            \
4116            c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 \\\
4117            -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img \\\
4118            -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img.
4119    Returns:
4120        Parameter dictionary
4121    """
4122    params = {
4123        "__STYXTYPE__": "levelset",
4124        "levelset": levelset,
4125    }
4126    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • levelset: -levelset: Level set segmentation Syntax: -levelset n_iter Perform level set segmentation for n_iter iterations, like in ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1. Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted | | Speed Image | Initialization Image | Output Image | | -- | ------------- | -------------------- | ------------ | | +1 | Foreground | Outside | Outside | | -1 | Background | Inside | Inside | Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization given: c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o seg.img Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image, where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside). c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz \ -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 \ -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose 0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the smoothed binary object c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 \ -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img \ -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_log10_params(log10: str) -> C3dLog10Parameters: 
4272def c3d_log10_params(
4273    log10: str,
4274) -> C3dLog10Parameters:
4275    """
4276    Build parameters.
4277    
4278    Args:

4283            Computes base 10 logarithm of each voxel in the last image on the\
4284            stack.
4285    Returns:
4286        Parameter dictionary
4287    """
4288    params = {
4289        "__STYXTYPE__": "log10",
4290        "log10": log10,
4291    }
4292    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • log10: -log10: Voxelwise base 10 logarithm Syntax: -log10 Computes base 10 logarithm of each voxel in the last image on the stack.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_log_params(log: str) -> C3dLogParameters:

def c3d_match_bounding_box_params(match_bounding_box: str) -> C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters: 
4355def c3d_match_bounding_box_params(
4356    match_bounding_box: str,
4357) -> C3dMatchBoundingBoxParameters:
4358    """
4359    Build parameters.
4360    
4361    Args:
4362        match_bounding_box: -mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of\
4363            one image to another\
4364            \
4365            Syntax: `-mbb`\
4366            \
4367            Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the\
4368            header of the target image so that the two images occupy the same\
4369            physical space. The direction cosines of the target image are set\
4370            to match the reference image. This command is related to\
4371            '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size.\
4372            \
4373            c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii.
4374    Returns:
4375        Parameter dictionary
4376    """
4377    params = {
4378        "__STYXTYPE__": "match_bounding_box",
4379        "match_bounding_box": match_bounding_box,
4380    }
4381    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • match_bounding_box: -mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of one image to another Syntax: -mbb Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the header of the target image so that the two images occupy the same physical space. The direction cosines of the target image are set to match the reference image. This command is related to '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size. c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

4413            \

4415            \
4416            Computes the voxel-wise maximum of two images. Can be used with the\
4417            **-accum** command to compute maximum of all images.\
4418            \
4419            c3d i1.nii i2.nii -max -o max12.nii\
4420            c3d i1.nii i2.nii i3.nii i4.nii -accum -max -endaccum -o\
4421            max1234.nii.
4422    Returns:
4423        Parameter dictionary
4424    """

4426        "__STYXTYPE__": "maximum",

4428    }

def c3d_mean_filter_params(mean_filter: str) -> C3dMeanFilterParameters: 
4648def c3d_mean_filter_params(
4649    mean_filter: str,
4650) -> C3dMeanFilterParameters:
4651    """
4652    Build parameters.
4653    
4654    Args:
4655        mean_filter: -mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter\
4656            \
4657            Syntax: `-mf <radius_vector>`\
4658            \
4659            Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by\
4660            the mean of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified\
4661            by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply\
4662            the mean filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.\
4663            \
4664            c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii.
4665    Returns:
4666        Parameter dictionary
4667    """
4668    params = {
4669        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean_filter",
4670        "mean_filter": mean_filter,
4671    }
4672    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • mean_filter: -mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter Syntax: -mf <radius_vector> Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the mean of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the mean filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_mean_params(mean: str) -> C3dMeanParameters: 
4509def c3d_mean_params(
4510    mean: str,
4511) -> C3dMeanParameters:
4512    """

4514

4516        mean: -mean: Mean of all images on the stack\
4517            \
4518            Syntax: `-mean `\
4519            \
4520            Computes the mean of all the images on the stack. All images on the\
4521            stack are replaced with the mean image.\
4522            \
4523            c3d image_*.nii -mean -o mean.nii.
4524    Returns:
4525        Parameter dictionary
4526    """
4527    params = {
4528        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean",
4529        "mean": mean,
4530    }
4531    return params

Build parameters.

  • mean: -mean: Mean of all images on the stack Syntax: -mean Computes the mean of all the images on the stack. All images on the stack are replaced with the mean image. c3d image_*.nii -mean -o mean.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_mean_square_params(mean_square: str) -> C3dMeanSquareParameters: 
4909def c3d_mean_square_params(
4910    mean_square: str,
4911) -> C3dMeanSquareParameters:
4912    """
4913    Build parameters.
4914    
4915    Args:
4916        mean_square: -msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric\
4917            \
4918            Syntax: `-msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`\
4919            \
4920            Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two\
4921            images on the stack. If an optional *movtransform.mat* file is\
4922            provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the\
4923            moving image. If, in addition to *movtransform.mat*, the optional\
4924            *reftransform.mat* file is also provided -- the moving transform is\
4925            applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the\
4926            reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that\
4927            is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This\
4928            may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms\
4929            are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of\
4930            interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and\
4931            the transform file format are similar to the **-reslice-matrix**\
4932            command.\
4933            \
4934            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii\
4935            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq\
4936            \
4937            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying\
4938            transform to mov.nii\
4939            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat\
4940            \
4941            # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space\
4942            after applying transforms to both\
4943            c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat.
4944    Returns:
4945        Parameter dictionary
4946    """
4947    params = {
4948        "__STYXTYPE__": "mean_square",
4949        "mean_square": mean_square,
4950    }
4951    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • mean_square: -msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric Syntax: -msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat] Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two images on the stack. If an optional movtransform.mat file is provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the moving image. If, in addition to movtransform.mat, the optional reftransform.mat file is also provided -- the moving transform is applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and the transform file format are similar to the -reslice-matrix command. # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying transform to mov.nii c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space after applying transforms to both c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_median_filter_params(median_filter: str) -> C3dMedianFilterParameters:

4567            by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size\
4568            specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code\
4569            will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.\
4570            \
4571            c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii.
4572    Returns:
4573        Parameter dictionary
4574    """
4575    params = {
4576        "__STYXTYPE__": "median_filter",
4577        "median_filter": median_filter,
4578    }
4579    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • median_filter: -median, -median-filter: Median filter Syntax: -median <radius_vector> Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

4623    }

def c3d_multicomponent_split_params( multicomponent_split: str) -> C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters: 
4453def c3d_multicomponent_split_params(
4454    multicomponent_split: str,
4455) -> C3dMulticomponentSplitParameters:
4456    """
4457    Build parameters.
4458    
4459    Args:
4460        multicomponent_split: -mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of\
4461            multi-component images on read\
4462            \
4463            Syntax: `-mcs`\
4464            \
4465            Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a\
4466            multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined\
4467            into a single image. Setting the **-mcs** flag changes this\
4468            behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See\
4469            the section below on multi-component image support.\
4470            \
4471            $ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor\
4472            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1\
4473            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66\
4474            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29\
4475            \
4476            $ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor\
4477            Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198.
4478    Returns:
4479        Parameter dictionary
4480    """
4481    params = {
4482        "__STYXTYPE__": "multicomponent_split",
4483        "multicomponent_split": multicomponent_split,
4484    }
4485    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • multicomponent_split: -mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of multi-component images on read Syntax: -mcs Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined into a single image. Setting the -mcs flag changes this behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See the section below on multi-component image support. $ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1 Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66 Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29 $ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_multiply_params(multiply: str) -> C3dMultiplyParameters: 
4975def c3d_multiply_params(
4976    multiply: str,
4977) -> C3dMultiplyParameters:
4978    """
4979    Build parameters.
4980    
4981    Args:
4982        multiply: -multiply, -times: Multiply two images\
4983            \
4984            Syntax: `-multiply`\
4985            \
4986            Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the\
4987            last two images on the stack.\
4988            \
4989            # Compute x = a * b\
4990            c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img\
4991            \
4992            # Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply\
4993            c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img\
4994            \
4995            Combine with the **-dup** command to compute voxelwise square of\
4996            the image\
4997            \
4998            # Compute x = a^2\
4999            c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img.
5000    Returns:
5001        Parameter dictionary
5002    """
5003    params = {
5004        "__STYXTYPE__": "multiply",
5005        "multiply": multiply,
5006    }
5007    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • multiply: -multiply, -times: Multiply two images Syntax: -multiply Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the last two images on the stack. # Compute x = a * b c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img # Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img Combine with the -dup command to compute voxelwise square of the image # Compute x = a^2 c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_n4_bias_correction_params(n4_bias_correction: str) -> C3dN4BiasCorrectionParameters: 
1430def c3d_n4_bias_correction_params(
1431    n4_bias_correction: str,
1432) -> C3dN4BiasCorrectionParameters:
1433    """
1434    Build parameters.
1435    
1436    Args:
1437        n4_bias_correction: -biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction\
1438            \
1439            Syntax: `-biascorr`\
1440            \
1441            Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This\
1442            feature uses the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4],\
1443            based on the N3 algorithm by Sled et al.\
1444            \
1445            c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz.
1446    Returns:
1447        Parameter dictionary
1448    """
1449    params = {
1450        "__STYXTYPE__": "n4_bias_correction",
1451        "n4_bias_correction": n4_bias_correction,
1452    }
1453    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • n4_bias_correction: -biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction Syntax: -biascorr Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm by Sled et al. c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_no_compress_params(no_compress: str) -> C3dNoCompressParameters: 
1988def c3d_no_compress_params(
1989    no_compress: str,
1990) -> C3dNoCompressParameters:
1991    """
1992    Build parameters.
1993    
1994    Args:
1995        no_compress: -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for\
1996            some image files\
1997            \
1998            Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`\
1999            \
2000            Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For\
2001            some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled\
2002            automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For\
2003            other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to\
2004            enable compression. The following two commands save the image as\
2005            compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:\
2006            \
2007            c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz\
2008            c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha.
2009    Returns:
2010        Parameter dictionary
2011    """
2012    params = {
2013        "__STYXTYPE__": "no_compress",
2014        "no_compress": no_compress,
2015    }
2016    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • no_compress: -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files Syntax: -compress or -no-compress Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files: c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_no_multicomponent_split_params( no_multicomponent_split: str) -> C3dNoMulticomponentSplitParameters:

5355) -> C3dNoMulticomponentSplitParameters:
5356    """
5357    Build parameters.
5358    
5359    Args:

5361            splitting of multi-component images on read\
5362            \
5363            Syntax: `-nomcs`\
5364            \
5365            Used to reverse the effect of previous **-mcs** command.
5366    Returns:
5367        Parameter dictionary
5368    """
5369    params = {
5370        "__STYXTYPE__": "no_multicomponent_split",
5371        "no_multicomponent_split": no_multicomponent_split,
5372    }
5373    return params

  • no_multicomponent_split: -nomcs, -no-multicomponent-split: Disable splitting of multi-component images on read Syntax: -nomcs Used to reverse the effect of previous -mcs command.

def c3d_noise_gaussian_params(noise_gaussian: str) -> C3dNoiseGaussianParameters: 
5169def c3d_noise_gaussian_params(
5170    noise_gaussian: str,
5171) -> C3dNoiseGaussianParameters:
5172    """
5173    Build parameters.
5174    
5175    Args:
5176        noise_gaussian: -noise-gaussian, -noise: Apply additive Gaussian noise\
5177            \
5178            Syntax: `-noise-gaussian <sigma>`\
5179            \
5180            Adds Gaussian noise to an image with zero mean and standard\
5181            deviation sigma. Please see [Noise simulation article][15] by G.\
5182            Lehmann for details.\
5183            \
5184            c3d image.nii -noise-gaussian 5 -o noisy.nii.
5185    Returns:
5186        Parameter dictionary
5187    """
5188    params = {
5189        "__STYXTYPE__": "noise_gaussian",
5190        "noise_gaussian": noise_gaussian,
5191    }
5192    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • noise_gaussian: -noise-gaussian, -noise: Apply additive Gaussian noise Syntax: -noise-gaussian <sigma> Adds Gaussian noise to an image with zero mean and standard deviation sigma. Please see [Noise simulation article][15] by G. Lehmann for details. c3d image.nii -noise-gaussian 5 -o noisy.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_noise_poisson_params(noise_poisson: str) -> C3dNoisePoissonParameters: 
5216def c3d_noise_poisson_params(
5217    noise_poisson: str,
5218) -> C3dNoisePoissonParameters:
5219    """
5220    Build parameters.
5221    
5222    Args:
5223        noise_poisson: -noise-poisson: Apply Poisson noise\
5224            Syntax: `-noise-poisson <scale>`\
5225            \
5226            Applies Poisson (shot) noise to an image with given scale. Please\
5227            see [Noise simulation article][15] by G. Lehmann for details.\
5228            \
5229            c3d image.nii -noise-poisson 5 -o noisy.nii.
5230    Returns:
5231        Parameter dictionary
5232    """
5233    params = {
5234        "__STYXTYPE__": "noise_poisson",
5235        "noise_poisson": noise_poisson,
5236    }
5237    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • noise_poisson: -noise-poisson: Apply Poisson noise Syntax: -noise-poisson <scale> Applies Poisson (shot) noise to an image with given scale. Please see [Noise simulation article][15] by G. Lehmann for details. c3d image.nii -noise-poisson 5 -o noisy.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_normalize_local_window_params( normalize_local_window: str) -> C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters: 
5397def c3d_normalize_local_window_params(
5398    normalize_local_window: str,
5399) -> C3dNormalizeLocalWindowParameters:
5400    """
5401    Build parameters.
5402    
5403    Args:
5404        normalize_local_window: -nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize\
5405            image intensity using local neighborhood\
5406            \
5407            Syntax: `-nlw <radius>`\
5408            \
5409            This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each\
5410            voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the\
5411            result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood.\
5412            The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked\
5413            region. You might also want to multiply by the mask.\
5414            \
5415            c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz.
5416    Returns:
5417        Parameter dictionary
5418    """
5419    params = {
5420        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalize_local_window",
5421        "normalize_local_window": normalize_local_window,
5422    }
5423    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • normalize_local_window: -nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize image intensity using local neighborhood Syntax: -nlw <radius> This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood. The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked region. You might also want to multiply by the mask. c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_normalized_correlation_params( normalized_correlation: str) -> C3dNormalizedCorrelationParameters:

5087            normalized correlation metric\
5088            \
5089            Syntax: `-ncor [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`\
5090            \
5091            : Compute the normalized correlation metric between the last two\
5092            images on the stack. See documentation for **-msq***.
5093    Returns:
5094        Parameter dictionary
5095    """
5096    params = {
5097        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalized_correlation",
5098        "normalized_correlation": normalized_correlation,
5099    }
5100    return params

  • normalized_correlation: -ncor, -normalized-correlation: Compute normalized correlation metric Syntax: -ncor [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat] : Compute the normalized correlation metric between the last two images on the stack. See documentation for -msq*.

def c3d_normalized_cross_correlation_params( normalized_cross_correlation: str) -> C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters: 
5031def c3d_normalized_cross_correlation_params(
5032    normalized_cross_correlation: str,
5033) -> C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelationParameters:
5034    """
5035    Build parameters.
5036    
5037    Args:
5038        normalized_cross_correlation: -ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation:\
5039            Compute normalized cross-correlation image\
5040            \
5041            Syntax: `-ncc <radius_vector>`\
5042            \
5043            Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that\
5044            occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image\
5045            is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the\
5046            voxel in the two input images. This is different from **-ncor**,\
5047            which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.
5048    Returns:
5049        Parameter dictionary
5050    """
5051    params = {
5052        "__STYXTYPE__": "normalized_cross_correlation",
5053        "normalized_cross_correlation": normalized_cross_correlation,
5054    }
5055    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • normalized_cross_correlation: -ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation: Compute normalized cross-correlation image Syntax: -ncc <radius_vector> Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the voxel in the two input images. This is different from -ncor, which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_noround_params(noround: str) -> C3dNoroundParameters: 
5486def c3d_noround_params(
5487    noround: str,
5488) -> C3dNoroundParameters:
5489    """
5490    Build parameters.
5491    
5492    Args:
5493        noround: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior\
5494            \
5495            Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `\
5496            \
5497            By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when\
5498            converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command\
5499            specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to\
5500            avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point\
5501            representation.\
5502            \
5503            c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
5504    Returns:
5505        Parameter dictionary
5506    """
5507    params = {
5508        "__STYXTYPE__": "noround",
5509        "noround": noround,
5510    }
5511    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • noround: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior Syntax: -noround or -round By default, convert3d will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_nospm_params(nospm: str) -> C3dNospmParameters: 
5535def c3d_nospm_params(
5536    nospm: str,
5537) -> C3dNospmParameters:
5538    """
5539    Build parameters.
5540    
5541    Args:
5542        nospm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output\
5543            \
5544            Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `\
5545            \
5546            These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze\
5547            (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored\
5548            by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When\
5549            saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default\
5550            is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue\
5551            altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.\
5552            \
5553            c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
5554    Returns:
5555        Parameter dictionary
5556    """
5557    params = {
5558        "__STYXTYPE__": "nospm",
5559        "nospm": nospm,
5560    }
5561    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • nospm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output Syntax: -spm or -nospm These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later. c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_noverbose_params(noverbose: str) -> C3dNoverboseParameters:
