def c3d_orient_1_params(orient: str) -> C3dOrient1Parameters: 
5918def c3d_orient_1_params(
5919    orient: str,
5920) -> C3dOrient1Parameters:
5921    """
5922    Build parameters.
5923    
5924    Args:
5925        orient: -orient: Change image orientation\
5926            \
5927            Syntax: `-orient CODE`\
5928            \
5929            Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical\
5930            orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel\
5931            coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system\
5932            (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of\
5933            voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of\
5934            voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of\
5935            the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to\
5936            (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to\
5937            (S)uperior.\
5938            \
5939            The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters\
5940            RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction\
5941            corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code\
5942            RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to\
5943            Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.\
5944            \
5945            c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img\
5946            c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img\
5947            \
5948            This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu\
5949            option in ITK-SNAP.
5950    Returns:
5951        Parameter dictionary
5952    """
5953    params = {
5954        "__STYXTYPE__": "orient_1",
5955        "orient": orient,
5956    }
5957    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • orient: -orient: Change image orientation Syntax: -orient CODE Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior. The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior. c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_orient_params(orient: str) -> C3dOrientParameters: 
5792def c3d_orient_params(
5793    orient: str,
5794) -> C3dOrientParameters:
5795    """
5796    Build parameters.
5797    
5798    Args:
5799        orient: -orient: Change image orientation\
5800            \
5801            Syntax: `-orient CODE`\
5802            \
5803            Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical\
5804            orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel\
5805            coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system\
5806            (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of\
5807            voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of\
5808            voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of\
5809            the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to\
5810            (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to\
5811            (S)uperior.\
5812            \
5813            The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters\
5814            RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction\
5815            corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code\
5816            RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to\
5817            Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.\
5818            \
5819            c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img\
5820            c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img\
5821            \
5822            This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu\
5823            option in ITK-SNAP.
5824    Returns:
5825        Parameter dictionary
5826    """
5827    params = {
5828        "__STYXTYPE__": "orient",
5829        "orient": orient,
5830    }
5831    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • orient: -orient: Change image orientation Syntax: -orient CODE Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior. The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior. c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_origin_params(origin: str) -> C3dOriginParameters: 
5981def c3d_origin_params(
5982    origin: str,
5983) -> C3dOriginParameters:
5984    """
5985    Build parameters.
5986    
5987    Args:
5988        origin: -origin: Set image origin\
5989            \
5990            Syntax: `-origin vector `\
5991            \
5992            Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in\
5993            NIfTI coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the\
5994            image. The origin should be specified in millimeters.\
5995            \
5996            c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img.
5997    Returns:
5998        Parameter dictionary
5999    """
6000    params = {
6001        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin",
6002        "origin": origin,
6003    }
6004    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • origin: -origin: Set image origin Syntax: -origin vector Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in NIfTI coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the image. The origin should be specified in millimeters. c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_origin_voxel_coord_params(origin_voxel_coord: str) -> C3dOriginVoxelCoordParameters: 
6077def c3d_origin_voxel_coord_params(
6078    origin_voxel_coord: str,
6079) -> C3dOriginVoxelCoordParameters:
6080    """
6081    Build parameters.
6082    
6083    Args:
6084        origin_voxel_coord: -origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified\
6085            voxel\
6086            \
6087            Syntax: `-origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>`\
6088            \
6089            This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed\
6090            voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the\
6091            command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of\
6092            the center voxel of the image, as follows:\
6093            \
6094            c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii.
6095    Returns:
6096        Parameter dictionary
6097    """
6098    params = {
6099        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin_voxel_coord",
6100        "origin_voxel_coord": origin_voxel_coord,
6101    }
6102    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • origin_voxel_coord: -origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified voxel Syntax: -origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector> This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of the center voxel of the image, as follows: c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_origin_voxel_params(origin_voxel: str) -> C3dOriginVoxelParameters: 
6028def c3d_origin_voxel_params(
6029    origin_voxel: str,
6030) -> C3dOriginVoxelParameters:
6031    """
6032    Build parameters.
6033    
6034    Args:
6035        origin_voxel: -origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel\
6036            \
6037            Syntax: `-origin-voxel vector `\
6038            \
6039            Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of\
6040            the center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector\
6041            should be specified in voxel units.\
6042            \
6043            c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img\
6044            c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img # image centered\
6045            around origin.
6046    Returns:
6047        Parameter dictionary
6048    """
6049    params = {
6050        "__STYXTYPE__": "origin_voxel",
6051        "origin_voxel": origin_voxel,
6052    }
6053    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • origin_voxel: -origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel Syntax: -origin-voxel vector Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of the center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector should be specified in voxel units. c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img # image centered around origin.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_output_multicomponent_params( output_multicomponent: str) -> C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters: 
5669def c3d_output_multicomponent_params(
5670    output_multicomponent: str,
5671) -> C3dOutputMulticomponentParameters:
5672    """
5673    Build parameters.
5674    
5675    Args:
5676        output_multicomponent: -omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple\
5677            images to single file\
5678            \
5679            Syntax: `-omc [number] filename`\
5680            \
5681            Write multiple images on the **Convert3d** stack as a single\
5682            multi-component image file. If the optional number *n* is\
5683            specified, only the last *n* images on the stack will be used. Not\
5684            all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the\
5685            safest bet.\
5686            \
5687            c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha\
5688            \
5689            For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG\
5690            files:\
5691            \
5692            c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc\
5693            colorslice.png.
5694    Returns:
5695        Parameter dictionary
5696    """
5697    params = {
5698        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multicomponent",
5699        "output_multicomponent": output_multicomponent,
5700    }
5701    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • output_multicomponent: -omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple images to single file Syntax: -omc [number] filename Write multiple images on the Convert3d stack as a single multi-component image file. If the optional number n is specified, only the last n images on the stack will be used. Not all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the safest bet. c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG files: c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_output_multiple_multicomponent_params( output_multiple_multicomponent: str) -> C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters: 
5725def c3d_output_multiple_multicomponent_params(
5726    output_multiple_multicomponent: str,
5727) -> C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponentParameters:
5728    """
5729    Build parameters.
5730    
5731    Args:
5732        output_multiple_multicomponent: -oomc: Output multiple multi-component\
5733            images to multiple files\
5734            \
5735            Syntax: `-oomc n_comp image_list` or `-oomc n_comp image_spec`\
5736            \
5737            Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple\
5738            multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the\
5739            **-omc** and **-oo** commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp'\
5740            images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack\
5741            will be written to a separate multi-component image.\
5742            \
5743            ### Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control\
5744            \
5745            These commands are used to manipulate the **convert3d** stack. The\
5746            stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified\
5747            on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the\
5748            stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack,\
5749            apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the\
5750            stack. Certain commands like **-levelset** and **-reslice-matrix**\
5751            take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace\
5752            them with a single output. Some other commands, like **-mean** and\
5753            **-vote** take all images on the stack and replace them with a\
5754            single output.\
5755            \
5756            Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order\
5757            of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the\
5758            same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow\
5759            control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving\
5760            intermediate images to the disk.
5761    Returns:
5762        Parameter dictionary
5763    """
5764    params = {
5765        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multiple_multicomponent",
5766        "output_multiple_multicomponent": output_multiple_multicomponent,
5767    }
5768    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • output_multiple_multicomponent: -oomc: Output multiple multi-component images to multiple files Syntax: -oomc n_comp image_list or -oomc n_comp image_spec Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the -omc and -oo commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp' images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack will be written to a separate multi-component image. ### Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control These commands are used to manipulate the convert3d stack. The stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack, apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the stack. Certain commands like -levelset and -reslice-matrix take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace them with a single output. Some other commands, like -mean and -vote take all images on the stack and replace them with a single output. Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving intermediate images to the disk.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_output_multiple_params(output_multiple: str) -> C3dOutputMultipleParameters: 
5855def c3d_output_multiple_params(
5856    output_multiple: str,
5857) -> C3dOutputMultipleParameters:
5858    """
5859    Build parameters.
5860    
5861    Args:
5862        output_multiple: -oo: Output multiple images to multiple files\
5863            \
5864            Syntax: `-oo image_list` or `-oo image_spec`\
5865            \
5866            Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple files.\
5867            There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a\
5868            list of file names, separated by spaces:\
5869            \
5870            c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii\
5871            \
5872            In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be\
5873            saved as *labelC.nii*, the image next to the end of the stack will\
5874            be saved as *labelB.nii* and so on.\
5875            \
5876            The second way to use the **-oo** command is to supply a pattern\
5877            for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack\
5878            will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the\
5879            [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command\
5880            \
5881            c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii\
5882            \
5883            will generate images *label00.nii*, *label01.nii*, *label02.nii*\
5884            and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest\
5885            number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have\
5886            number 00.
5887    Returns:
5888        Parameter dictionary
5889    """
5890    params = {
5891        "__STYXTYPE__": "output_multiple",
5892        "output_multiple": output_multiple,
5893    }
5894    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • output_multiple: -oo: Output multiple images to multiple files Syntax: -oo image_list or -oo image_spec Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple files. There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a list of file names, separated by spaces: c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be saved as labelC.nii, the image next to the end of the stack will be saved as labelB.nii and so on. The second way to use the -oo command is to supply a pattern for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii will generate images label00.nii, label01.nii, label02.nii and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have number 00.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_output_params(output: str) -> C3dOutputParameters: 
5595def c3d_output_params(
5596    output: str,
5597) -> C3dOutputParameters:
5598    """
5599    Build parameters.
5600    
5601    Args:
5602        output: -o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file\
5603            \
5604            Syntax: `-o filename`\
5605            \
5606            Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the **-o**\
5607            option, **convert3d** will write an image only if it does not\
5608            exist. The **-o** options protects input images from being\
5609            accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format:\
5610            \
5611            c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii\
5612            \
5613            The **-o** option can also be used to save an intermediate image in\
5614            the stack:\
5615            \
5616            c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o\
5617            final.img.
5618    Returns:
5619        Parameter dictionary
5620    """
5621    params = {
5622        "__STYXTYPE__": "output",
5623        "output": output,
5624    }
5625    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • output: -o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file Syntax: -o filename Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the -o option, convert3d will write an image only if it does not exist. The -o options protects input images from being accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format: c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii The -o option can also be used to save an intermediate image in the stack: c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o final.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_overlap_params(overlap: str) -> C3dOverlapParameters: 
6126def c3d_overlap_params(
6127    overlap: str,
6128) -> C3dOverlapParameters:
6129    """
6130    Build parameters.
6131    
6132    Args:
6133        overlap: -overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images\
6134            \
6135            Syntax: `-overlap Z`\
6136            \
6137            Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on\
6138            the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label **Z**, i.e., the\
6139            number of voxels that are equal to **Z** in both images is computed\
6140            and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to **Z**\
6141            in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the\
6142            region where at least one of the images is equal to **Z** (Jaccard\
6143            coefficient).\
6144            \
6145            The command below computes overlap for label 255.\
6146            \
6147            c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255\
6148            \
6149            The output of the command is in the following terse format, with\
6150            the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients,\
6151            respectively.\
6152            \
6153            OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459\
6154            \
6155            Use the flag **-verbose** to get full information.\
6156            \
6157            Matching voxels in first image: 2383\
6158            Matching voxels in second image: 2474\
6159            Size of overlap region: 1807\
6160            Dice similarity coefficient: 0.744081\
6161            Intersection / ratio: 0.592459\
6162            \
6163            This command does not alter the stack.
6164    Returns:
6165        Parameter dictionary
6166    """
6167    params = {
6168        "__STYXTYPE__": "overlap",
6169        "overlap": overlap,
6170    }
6171    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • overlap: -overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images Syntax: -overlap Z Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label Z, i.e., the number of voxels that are equal to Z in both images is computed and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to Z in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the region where at least one of the images is equal to Z (Jaccard coefficient). The command below computes overlap for label 255. c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255 The output of the command is in the following terse format, with the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients, respectively. OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459 Use the flag -verbose to get full information. Matching voxels in first image: 2383 Matching voxels in second image: 2474 Size of overlap region: 1807 Dice similarity coefficient: 0.744081 Intersection / ratio: 0.592459 This command does not alter the stack.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_overlay_label_image_params( overlay_label_image: str) -> C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters: 
6195def c3d_overlay_label_image_params(
6196    overlay_label_image: str,
6197) -> C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters:
6198    """
6199    Build parameters.
6200    
6201    Args:
6202        overlay_label_image: -oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation\
6203            image on grayscale image\
6204            \
6205            Syntax: `-oli lookup_table_file opacity`\
6206            \
6207            This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image\
6208            with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue\
6209            components of a color image. The resulting color image is an\
6210            overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter\
6211            (*lookup\\_table*) is a text file with entries in the format\
6212            \
6213            label_value red green blue alpha\
6214            \
6215            Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values\
6216            should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image\
6217            (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and\
6218            can be generated using the ITK-SNAP `Segmentation->Save Label\
6219            Descriptions` command. The second parameter (*opacity*) is between\
6220            0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of\
6221            this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation\
6222            data on top of grayscale images.\
6223            \
6224            c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli\
6225            labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz\
6226            \
6227            Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the\
6228            lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous\
6229            intensity spectrum.\
6230            \
6231            Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation\
6232            result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and\
6233            segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map\
6234            intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices\
6235            through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on\
6236            the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file.\
6237            \
6238            c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0\
6239            255 -clip 0 255 \\\\\
6240            -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor\
6241            \\\\\
6242            -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png.
6243    Returns:
6244        Parameter dictionary
6245    """
6246    params = {
6247        "__STYXTYPE__": "overlay_label_image",
6248        "overlay_label_image": overlay_label_image,
6249    }
6250    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • overlay_label_image: -oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation image on grayscale image Syntax: -oli lookup_table_file opacity This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue components of a color image. The resulting color image is an overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter (lookup_table) is a text file with entries in the format label_value red green blue alpha Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and can be generated using the ITK-SNAP Segmentation->Save Label Descriptions command. The second parameter (opacity) is between 0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation data on top of grayscale images. c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous intensity spectrum. Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file. c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 \ -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor \ -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_pad_params(pad: str) -> C3dPadParameters: 
6274def c3d_pad_params(
6275    pad: str,
6276) -> C3dPadParameters:
6277    """
6278    Build parameters.
6279    
6280    Args:
6281        pad: -pad: Pad image with constant value\
6282            \
6283            Syntax: `-pad <padlower> <padupper> <value> `\
6284            \
6285            Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The\
6286            *padlower* dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and\
6287            the *padupper* dimension pads along the upper faces of the image.\
6288            For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do\
6289            \
6290            c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii\
6291            \
6292            while\
6293            \
6294            c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii\
6295            \
6296            adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four\
6297            slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument\
6298            changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the\
6299            output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment\
6300            between the padded and original images.\
6301            \
6302            Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any\
6303            constant value, eg :\
6304            \
6305            c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii\
6306            \
6307            Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with\
6308            the value 1.
6309    Returns:
6310        Parameter dictionary
6311    """
6312    params = {
6313        "__STYXTYPE__": "pad",
6314        "pad": pad,
6315    }
6316    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • pad: -pad: Pad image with constant value Syntax: -pad <padlower> <padupper> <value> Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The padlower dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and the padupper dimension pads along the upper faces of the image. For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii while c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment between the padded and original images. Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any constant value, eg : c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with the value 1.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_pad_to_params(pad_to: str) -> C3dPadToParameters: 
6340def c3d_pad_to_params(
6341    pad_to: str,
6342) -> C3dPadToParameters:
6343    """
6344    Build parameters.
6345    
6346    Args:
6347        pad_to: No description found.
6348    Returns:
6349        Parameter dictionary
6350    """
6351    params = {
6352        "__STYXTYPE__": "pad_to",
6353        "pad_to": pad_to,
6354    }
6355    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • pad_to: No description found.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

C3dOverlapParameters, C3dOverlayLabelImageParameters, C3dPadParameters, C3dPadToParameters, C3dPcaParameters, C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters, C3dPixelParameters, C3dPopParameters, C3dPopasParameters, C3dProbeParameters, C3dPushParameters, C3dRankParameters, C3dReciprocalParameters, C3dRegionParameters, C3dReorderParameters, C3dRetainLabelsParameters, C3dRfApplyParameters, C3dRfTrainParameters, C3dRfParamPatchParameters, C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNousexyzParameters, C3dRfParamNtreesParameters, C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters, C3dSetSformParameters, C3dReplaceParameters, C3dResampleParameters, C3dResampleIsoParameters, C3dResampleMmParameters, C3dResliceItkParameters, C3dResliceMatrixParameters, C3dResliceIdentityParameters, C3dRgb2hsvParameters, C3dRmsParameters, C3dRoundParameters, C3dScaleParameters, C3dSetSform1Parameters, C3dSinParameters, C3dSliceParameters, C3dSliceAllParameters, C3dSharpenParameters, C3dShiftParameters, C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters, C3dSmoothParameters, C3dSmoothFastParameters, C3dSpacingParameters, C3dSplitParameters, C3dSqrtParameters, C3dStapleParameters, C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters, C3dSpmParameters, C3dSubtractParameters, C3dSupervoxelParameters, C3dStretchParameters, C3dSwapdimParameters, C3dTestImageParameters, C3dTestProbeParameters, C3dThresholdParameters, C3dTileParameters, C3dTrimParameters, C3dTrimToSizeParameters, C3dTypeParameters, C3dVerboseParameters, C3dNoverboseParameters, C3dVersionParameters, C3dVoteParameters, C3dVoteMrfParameters, C3dVoteLabelParameters, C3dVoxelSumParameters, C3dVoxelIntegralParameters, C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters, C3dWarpParameters, C3dWarpLabelParameters, C3dWrapParameters, C3dWeightedSumParameters, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters]],
 9989    output: str,
 9990) -> C3dParameters:
 9991    """
 9992    Build parameters.
 9993    
 9994    Args:
 9995        input_: The input image to process.
 9996        operations: The operations to perform.
 9997        output: The output image.
 9998    Returns:
 9999        Parameter dictionary
10000    """
10001    params = {
10002        "__STYXTYPE__": "c3d",
10003        "input": input_,
10004        "operations": operations,
10005        "output": output,
10006    }
10007    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • input_: The input image to process.
  • operations: The operations to perform.
  • output: The output image.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_pca_params(pca: str) -> C3dPcaParameters: 
6379def c3d_pca_params(
6380    pca: str,
6381) -> C3dPcaParameters:
6382    """
6383    Build parameters.
6384    
6385    Args:
6386        pca: -pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels\
6387            \
6388            Syntax: `-pca`\
6389            \
6390            Similar to the *-centroid* command, computes the centroid and\
6391            prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For\
6392            example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will\
6393            report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in\
6394            physical NIFTI coordinates.\
6395            \
6396            c3d binaryimage.img -pca // centroid of all non-0 voxels\
6397            c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca // centroid of all voxels\
6398            with label 5\
6399            c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor // centroids of all\
6400            labels (including 0).
6401    Returns:
6402        Parameter dictionary
6403    """
6404    params = {
6405        "__STYXTYPE__": "pca",
6406        "pca": pca,
6407    }
6408    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • pca: -pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels Syntax: -pca Similar to the -centroid command, computes the centroid and prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in physical NIFTI coordinates. c3d binaryimage.img -pca // centroid of all non-0 voxels c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca // centroid of all voxels with label 5 c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor // centroids of all labels (including 0).
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_percent_intensity_mode_params( percent_intensity_mode: str) -> C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters: 
6432def c3d_percent_intensity_mode_params(
6433    percent_intensity_mode: str,
6434) -> C3dPercentIntensityModeParameters:
6435    """
6436    Build parameters.
6437    
6438    Args:
6439        percent_intensity_mode: -pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of\
6440            % specifier\
6441            \
6442            Syntax: `-pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r`\
6443            \
6444            This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when\
6445            specifying intensity values. **Quantile (q)** means that `10%`\
6446            describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image\
6447            (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity).\
6448            **ForegroundQuantile (fq)** is similar, but voxels with background\
6449            intensity (see **-background** option) are excluded from the\
6450            percentile computation. **Range (r)** changes the meaning of\
6451            percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and\
6452            maximum of the image, and `0.1%` becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX -\
6453            MIN). The default is **Quantile**.\
6454            \
6455            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf\
6456            1 0\
6457            Quantile 0.75 maps to 18\
6458            \
6459            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose\
6460            -threshold 75% inf 1 0\
6461            Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58\
6462            \
6463            $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1\
6464            0\
6465            Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25.
6466    Returns:
6467        Parameter dictionary
6468    """
6469    params = {
6470        "__STYXTYPE__": "percent_intensity_mode",
6471        "percent_intensity_mode": percent_intensity_mode,
6472    }
6473    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • percent_intensity_mode: -pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of % specifier Syntax: -pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when specifying intensity values. Quantile (q) means that 10% describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity). ForegroundQuantile (fq) is similar, but voxels with background intensity (see -background option) are excluded from the percentile computation. Range (r) changes the meaning of percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and maximum of the image, and 0.1% becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX - MIN). The default is Quantile. $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Quantile 0.75 maps to 18 $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58 $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_pixel_params(pixel: str) -> C3dPixelParameters:

6498    pixel: str,
6499) -> C3dPixelParameters:

6503    Args:

6505    Returns:
6506        Parameter dictionary
6507    """

6509        "__STYXTYPE__": "pixel",
6510        "pixel": pixel,
6511    }
6512    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • pixel: No description found.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_pop_params(pop_: str) -> C3dPopParameters: 
6536def c3d_pop_params(
6537    pop_: str,
6538) -> C3dPopParameters:
6539    """
6540    Build parameters.
6541    
6542    Args:
6543        pop_: -pop: Remove last image from the stack\
6544            \
6545            Syntax: `-pop`\
6546            \
6547            Removes the last image from the image stack. Images assigned a name\
6548            with the **-as** command will remain in memory.
6549    Returns:
6550        Parameter dictionary
6551    """
6552    params = {
6553        "__STYXTYPE__": "pop",
6554        "pop": pop_,
6555    }
6556    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • pop_: -pop: Remove last image from the stack Syntax: -pop Removes the last image from the image stack. Images assigned a name with the -as command will remain in memory.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_popas_params(popas: str) -> C3dPopasParameters: 
6580def c3d_popas_params(
6581    popas: str,
6582) -> C3dPopasParameters:
6583    """
6584    Build parameters.
6585    
6586    Args:
6587        popas: -popas: Remove last image from the stack and assign to variable\
6588            \
6589            Syntax: `-popas var`\
6590            \
6591            Removes the last image from the stack, but also assigns it the name\
6592            'var', keeping the image in memory. Same as calling **-as** *var*\
6593            followed by **-pop**.
6594    Returns:
6595        Parameter dictionary
6596    """
6597    params = {
6598        "__STYXTYPE__": "popas",
6599        "popas": popas,
6600    }
6601    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • popas: -popas: Remove last image from the stack and assign to variable Syntax: -popas var Removes the last image from the stack, but also assigns it the name 'var', keeping the image in memory. Same as calling -as var followed by -pop.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_probe_params(probe: str) -> C3dProbeParameters: 
6625def c3d_probe_params(
6626    probe: str,
6627) -> C3dProbeParameters:
6628    """
6629    Build parameters.
6630    
6631    Args:
6632        probe: -probe: Report image intensity at a voxel\
6633            \
6634            Syntax: `-probe <point_spec>`\
6635            \
6636            Prints the value of the image at the position specified by the\
6637            parameter `point_spec`, which may be in physical units or voxel\
6638            units:\
6639            \
6640            c3d img1.img -probe 128x120x160vox\
6641            c3d img1.img -interpolation NearestNeighbor -probe 60x60x60mm\
6642            c3d img1.img -probe 50%.
6643    Returns:
6644        Parameter dictionary
6645    """
6646    params = {
6647        "__STYXTYPE__": "probe",
6648        "probe": probe,
6649    }
6650    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • probe: -probe: Report image intensity at a voxel Syntax: -probe <point_spec> Prints the value of the image at the position specified by the parameter point_spec, which may be in physical units or voxel units: c3d img1.img -probe 128x120x160vox c3d img1.img -interpolation NearestNeighbor -probe 60x60x60mm c3d img1.img -probe 50%.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_push_params(push: str) -> C3dPushParameters: 
6674def c3d_push_params(
6675    push: str,
6676) -> C3dPushParameters:
6677    """
6678    Build parameters.
6679    
6680    Args:
6681        push: -push: Place variable at the end of the stack\
6682            \
6683            Syntax: `-push var`\
6684            \
6685            Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the\
6686            image stack. Variable names are assigned using the **-as** command.\
6687            The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use\
6688            a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For\
6689            example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary\
6690            image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image\
6691            region have value 0, you would use the following command:\
6692            \
6693            c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img.
6694    Returns:
6695        Parameter dictionary
6696    """
6697    params = {
6698        "__STYXTYPE__": "push",
6699        "push": push,
6700    }
6701    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • push: -push: Place variable at the end of the stack Syntax: -push var Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the image stack. Variable names are assigned using the -as command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rank_params(rank: str) -> C3dRankParameters: 
6725def c3d_rank_params(
6726    rank: str,
6727) -> C3dRankParameters:
6728    """
6729    Build parameters.
6730    
6731    Args:
6732        rank: -rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values\
6733            \
6734            Syntax: `-rank `\
6735            \
6736            This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the\
6737            stack are used). It also generates N images as the output. For\
6738            voxel k in image j, it assigns it a label based on its rank among\
6739            the values of voxel k in all N images. If the voxel has highest\
6740            intensity in image j, then the j'th output will have value 1.\
6741            \
6742            c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img.
6743    Returns:
6744        Parameter dictionary
6745    """
6746    params = {
6747        "__STYXTYPE__": "rank",
6748        "rank": rank,
6749    }
6750    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rank: -rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values Syntax: -rank This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the stack are used). It also generates N images as the output. For voxel k in image j, it assigns it a label based on its rank among the values of voxel k in all N images. If the voxel has highest intensity in image j, then the j'th output will have value 1. c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_reciprocal_params(reciprocal: str) -> C3dReciprocalParameters:

6775    reciprocal: str,

6779    
6780    Args:
6781        reciprocal: -reciprocal: Image voxelwise reciprocal\
6782            \
6783            Syntax: `-reciprocal `\

6785            Computes the reciprocal of an image. For instance to compute B = 1\
6786            / A, use the command\
6787            \
6788            c3d A.img -reciprocal -o B.img.
6789    Returns:
6790        Parameter dictionary
6791    """
6792    params = {
6793        "__STYXTYPE__": "reciprocal",
6794        "reciprocal": reciprocal,
6795    }
6796    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • reciprocal: -reciprocal: Image voxelwise reciprocal Syntax: -reciprocal Computes the reciprocal of an image. For instance to compute B = 1 / A, use the command c3d A.img -reciprocal -o B.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_region_params(region: str) -> C3dRegionParameters: 
6820def c3d_region_params(
6821    region: str,
6822) -> C3dRegionParameters:
6823    """
6824    Build parameters.
6825    
6826    Args:
6827        region: -region: Extract region from image\
6828            \
6829            Syntax: `-region vOrigin vSize `\
6830            \
6831            Extract a rectangular region from the image. The first parameter is\
6832            the position of the corner of the region, and the second is the\
6833            size of the region.\
6834            \
6835            c3d img1.img -region 20x20x20vox 50x60x70vox -o img2.img\
6836            c3d img1.img -region 25% 50% -o img3.img.
6837    Returns:
6838        Parameter dictionary
6839    """
6840    params = {
6841        "__STYXTYPE__": "region",
6842        "region": region,
6843    }
6844    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • region: -region: Extract region from image Syntax: -region vOrigin vSize Extract a rectangular region from the image. The first parameter is the position of the corner of the region, and the second is the size of the region. c3d img1.img -region 20x20x20vox 50x60x70vox -o img2.img c3d img1.img -region 25% 50% -o img3.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_reorder_params(reorder: str) -> C3dReorderParameters: 
6868def c3d_reorder_params(
6869    reorder: str,
6870) -> C3dReorderParameters:
6871    """
6872    Build parameters.
6873    
6874    Args:
6875        reorder: -reorder: Rearrange images on the stack\
6876            \
6877            Syntax: `-reorder k` or `-reorder fraction`\
6878            \
6879            Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k\
6880            positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other\
6881            words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new\
6882            order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ...,\
6883            k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an\
6884            alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point\
6885            number (i.e., **-reorder** 0.5), in which case k is obtained by\
6886            multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the\
6887            nearest integer.\
6888            \
6889            The following three commands are equivalent:\
6890            \
6891            c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii\
6892            -reorder 4 ...\
6893            c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii\
6894            -reorder 0.5 ...\
6895            c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...\
6896            \
6897            The **-reorder** command us useful when you specify two sets of\
6898            images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations\
6899            on the images. For example\
6900            \
6901            c3d weight*.nii gray*.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o\
6902            wsum.nii\
6903            \
6904            is equivalent to the command\
6905            \
6906            c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ...\
6907            -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii.
6908    Returns:
6909        Parameter dictionary
6910    """
6911    params = {
6912        "__STYXTYPE__": "reorder",
6913        "reorder": reorder,
6914    }
6915    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • reorder: -reorder: Rearrange images on the stack Syntax: -reorder k or -reorder fraction Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ..., k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point number (i.e., -reorder 0.5), in which case k is obtained by multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the nearest integer. The following three commands are equivalent: c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 4 ... c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 0.5 ... c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ... The -reorder command us useful when you specify two sets of images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations on the images. For example c3d weight.nii gray.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii is equivalent to the command c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ... -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_replace_params(replace: str) -> C3dReplaceParameters: 
7390def c3d_replace_params(
7391    replace: str,
7392) -> C3dReplaceParameters:
7393    """
7394    Build parameters.
7395    
7396    Args:
7397        replace: -replace: Replace intensities in image\
7398            \
7399            Syntax: `-replace I1 J1 I2 J2 ... `\
7400            \
7401            Replace intensity I1 by J1, I2 by J2 and so on. Allowed values of\
7402            intensity include **nan**, **inf** and **-inf**.\
7403            \
7404            c3d img1.img -replace 1 128 nan 0.0 -o img2.img.
7405    Returns:
7406        Parameter dictionary
7407    """
7408    params = {
7409        "__STYXTYPE__": "replace",
7410        "replace": replace,
7411    }
7412    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • replace: -replace: Replace intensities in image Syntax: -replace I1 J1 I2 J2 ... Replace intensity I1 by J1, I2 by J2 and so on. Allowed values of intensity include nan, inf and -inf. c3d img1.img -replace 1 128 nan 0.0 -o img2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_resample_iso_params(resample_iso: str) -> C3dResampleIsoParameters: 
7489def c3d_resample_iso_params(
7490    resample_iso: str,
7491) -> C3dResampleIsoParameters:
7492    """
7493    Build parameters.
7494    
7495    Args:
7496        resample_iso: -resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately)\
7497            isotropic resolution\
7498            \
7499            Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`\
7500            \
7501            Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution,\
7502            either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or\
7503            largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls\
7504            **-resample** with appropriately calculated new image dimensions.\
7505            The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved.\
7506            Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual\
7507            voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic.\
7508            \
7509            c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img.
7510    Returns:
7511        Parameter dictionary
7512    """
7513    params = {
7514        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample_iso",
7515        "resample_iso": resample_iso,
7516    }
7517    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • resample_iso: -resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution Syntax: -resample-iso <min|max> Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls -resample with appropriately calculated new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic. c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_resample_mm_params(resample_mm: str) -> C3dResampleMmParameters: 
7541def c3d_resample_mm_params(
7542    resample_mm: str,
7543) -> C3dResampleMmParameters:
7544    """
7545    Build parameters.
7546    
7547    Args:
7548        resample_mm: -resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution\
7549            \
7550            Syntax: `-resample-mm <voxel_size> `\
7551            \
7552            Resamples the image as in **-resample**, but the user specifies the\
7553            new voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so\
7554            the bounding box of the image may change. A warning will be\
7555            generated in that case.\
7556            \
7557            c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img.
7558    Returns:
7559        Parameter dictionary
7560    """
7561    params = {
7562        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample_mm",
7563        "resample_mm": resample_mm,
7564    }
7565    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • resample_mm: -resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution Syntax: -resample-mm <voxel_size> Resamples the image as in -resample, but the user specifies the new voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so the bounding box of the image may change. A warning will be generated in that case. c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_resample_params(resample: str) -> C3dResampleParameters: 
7436def c3d_resample_params(
7437    resample: str,
7438) -> C3dResampleParameters:
7439    """
7440    Build parameters.
7441    
7442    Args:
7443        resample: -resample: Resample image to new dimensions\
7444            \
7445            Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `\
7446            \
7447            Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but\
7448            changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be\
7449            specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of\
7450            voxels in each direction. The **-interpolation** flag affects how\
7451            sampling is performed.\
7452            \
7453            c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img\
7454            c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img\
7455            c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img\
7456            c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample\
7457            123x142x200 -o img2.img.
7458    Returns:
7459        Parameter dictionary
7460    """
7461    params = {
7462        "__STYXTYPE__": "resample",
7463        "resample": resample,
7464    }
7465    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • resample: -resample: Resample image to new dimensions Syntax: -resample <dimensions> Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction. The -interpolation flag affects how sampling is performed. c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_reslice_identity_params(reslice_identity: str) -> C3dResliceIdentityParameters: 
7672def c3d_reslice_identity_params(
7673    reslice_identity: str,
7674) -> C3dResliceIdentityParameters:
7675    """
7676    Build parameters.
7677    
7678    Args:
7679        reslice_identity: -reslice-identity: Resample image using identity\
7680            transform\
7681            \
7682            Syntax: `-reslice-identity `\
7683            \
7684            Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity\
7685            transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same\
7686            subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space\
7687            and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For\
7688            example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate\
7689            frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1\
7690            \
7691            c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii.
7692    Returns:
7693        Parameter dictionary
7694    """
7695    params = {
7696        "__STYXTYPE__": "reslice_identity",
7697        "reslice_identity": reslice_identity,
7698    }
7699    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • reslice_identity: -reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform Syntax: -reslice-identity Applies the -reslice-matrix command with the identity transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1 c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_retain_labels_params(retain_labels: str) -> C3dRetainLabelsParameters: 
6939def c3d_retain_labels_params(
6940    retain_labels: str,
6941) -> C3dRetainLabelsParameters:
6942    """
6943    Build parameters.
6944    
6945    Args:
6946        retain_labels: -retain-labels: Retain labels in a label image\
6947            \
6948            Syntax: `-retain-labels I1 I2 ... IN`\
6949            \
6950            Assuming that the input is a multi-label segmentation image, this\
6951            command keeps all labels specifed in the list and replaces the\
6952            remaining labels with the background value.\
6953            \
6954            c3d seg.nii -retain-labels 2 3 4 8 -o subseg.nii.
6955    Returns:
6956        Parameter dictionary
6957    """
6958    params = {
6959        "__STYXTYPE__": "retain_labels",
6960        "retain_labels": retain_labels,
6961    }
6962    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • retain_labels: -retain-labels: Retain labels in a label image Syntax: -retain-labels I1 I2 ... IN Assuming that the input is a multi-label segmentation image, this command keeps all labels specifed in the list and replaces the remaining labels with the background value. c3d seg.nii -retain-labels 2 3 4 8 -o subseg.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rf_apply_params(rf_apply: str) -> C3dRfApplyParameters: 
6986def c3d_rf_apply_params(
6987    rf_apply: str,
6988) -> C3dRfApplyParameters:
6989    """
6990    Build parameters.
6991    
6992    Args:
6993        rf_apply: -rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier\
6994            \
6995            Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`\
6996            \
6997            This command applies a classifier trained previously by\
6998            **-rf-train**. The stack must contain the same number of feature\
6999            images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack\
7000            and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the\
7001            number of classes during training. See examples under **-rf-train**\
7002            for usage.
7003    Returns:
7004        Parameter dictionary
7005    """
7006    params = {
7007        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_apply",
7008        "rf_apply": rf_apply,
7009    }
7010    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_apply: -rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier Syntax: -rf-apply <classifier_file> This command applies a classifier trained previously by -rf-train. The stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See examples under -rf-train for usage.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary
