def c3d_rf_param_ntrees_params(rf_param_ntrees: str) -> C3dRfParamNtreesParameters: 
7258def c3d_rf_param_ntrees_params(
7259    rf_param_ntrees: str,
7260) -> C3dRfParamNtreesParameters:
7261    """
7262    Build parameters.
7263    
7264    Args:
7265        rf_param_ntrees: -rf-param-ntrees: Random Forest forest size\
7266            \
7267            Syntax: `-rf-param-ntrees <integer>`\
7268            \
7269            Sets the number of trees in the forest. Default value is 50. Larger\
7270            forests are more robust but more time to train and apply.
7271    Returns:
7272        Parameter dictionary
7273    """
7274    params = {
7275        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_ntrees",
7276        "rf_param_ntrees": rf_param_ntrees,
7277    }
7278    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_param_ntrees: -rf-param-ntrees: Random Forest forest size Syntax: -rf-param-ntrees <integer> Sets the number of trees in the forest. Default value is 50. Larger forests are more robust but more time to train and apply.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rf_param_patch_params(rf_param_patch: str) -> C3dRfParamPatchParameters: 
7122def c3d_rf_param_patch_params(
7123    rf_param_patch: str,
7124) -> C3dRfParamPatchParameters:
7125    """
7126    Build parameters.
7127    
7128    Args:
7129        rf_param_patch: -rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size\
7130            \
7131            Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`\
7132            \
7133            Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF\
7134            classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the\
7135            intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to\
7136            non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being\
7137            used as features, and can improve classification in presence of\
7138            complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 *\
7139            radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.\
7140            \
7141            # Set patch size to 5x5x5\
7142            c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf.
7143    Returns:
7144        Parameter dictionary
7145    """
7146    params = {
7147        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_patch",
7148        "rf_param_patch": rf_param_patch,
7149    }
7150    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_param_patch: -rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size Syntax: -rf-param-patch <size_spec> Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See -rf-train command for details. # Set patch size to 5x5x5 c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rf_param_treedepth_params(rf_param_treedepth: str) -> C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters: 
7302def c3d_rf_param_treedepth_params(
7303    rf_param_treedepth: str,
7304) -> C3dRfParamTreedepthParameters:
7305    """
7306    Build parameters.
7307    
7308    Args:
7309        rf_param_treedepth: -rf-param-treedepth: Random Forest tree depth\
7310            \
7311            Syntax: `-rf-param-treedepth <integer>`\
7312            \
7313            Sets the depth of the trees in the classifier. Default value is 30.\
7314            Deeper trees can learn on more complex data but require more time.
7315    Returns:
7316        Parameter dictionary
7317    """
7318    params = {
7319        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_treedepth",
7320        "rf_param_treedepth": rf_param_treedepth,
7321    }
7322    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_param_treedepth: -rf-param-treedepth: Random Forest tree depth Syntax: -rf-param-treedepth <integer> Sets the depth of the trees in the classifier. Default value is 30. Deeper trees can learn on more complex data but require more time.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rf_param_usexyz_params(rf_param_usexyz: str) -> C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters: 
7174def c3d_rf_param_usexyz_params(
7175    rf_param_usexyz: str,
7176) -> C3dRfParamUsexyzParameters:
7177    """
7178    Build parameters.
7179    
7180    Args:
7181        rf_param_usexyz: -rf-param-usexyz: Random Forest coordinate features\
7182            \
7183            Syntax: `-rf-param-usexyz`\
7184            \
7185            Use the coordinates of voxels as additional features. This allows\
7186            some geometric relations between different labels to be learned.\
7187            Equivalent to the corresponding ITK-SNAP option.
7188    Returns:
7189        Parameter dictionary
7190    """
7191    params = {
7192        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_param_usexyz",
7193        "rf_param_usexyz": rf_param_usexyz,
7194    }
7195    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_param_usexyz: -rf-param-usexyz: Random Forest coordinate features Syntax: -rf-param-usexyz Use the coordinates of voxels as additional features. This allows some geometric relations between different labels to be learned. Equivalent to the corresponding ITK-SNAP option.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rf_train_params(rf_train: str) -> C3dRfTrainParameters: 
7034def c3d_rf_train_params(
7035    rf_train: str,
7036) -> C3dRfTrainParameters:
7037    """
7038    Build parameters.
7039    
7040    Args:
7041        rf_train: -rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier\
7042            \
7043            Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`\
7044            \
7045            This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the\
7046            [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with\
7047            modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The\
7048            stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale\
7049            images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at\
7050            least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The\
7051            classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with\
7052            label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier\
7053            is output to a binary file that can later be used by the\
7054            **-rf-apply** command. Multiple parameters can be specified with\
7055            the **-rf-param-xxx** options before calling **-rf-train**. The\
7056            stack is not modified by this command.\
7057            \
7058            # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default\
7059            parameters\
7060            c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf\
7061            \
7062            # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)\
7063            c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train\
7064            myforest2.rf\
7065            \
7066            # Applying the classifier\
7067            c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz\
7068            \
7069            The commands are meant to replicate the "classification"\
7070            pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example\
7071            segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use\
7072            the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple\
7073            subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images\
7074            from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be\
7075            stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:\
7076            \
7077            # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects\
7078            c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \\\
7079            seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \\\
7080            -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \\\
7081            -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf\
7082            \
7083            # Apply using single MRI\
7084            c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii\
7085            \
7086            [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning,\
7087            45(1), 5-32.\
7088            [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for\
7089            computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science &\
7090            Business Media.
7091    Returns:
7092        Parameter dictionary
7093    """
7094    params = {
7095        "__STYXTYPE__": "rf_train",
7096        "rf_train": rf_train,
7097    }
7098    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rf_train: -rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier Syntax: -rf-train <classifier_file> This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with label L are treated as the examples of class L. The classifier is output to a binary file that can later be used by the -rf-apply command. Multiple parameters can be specified with the -rf-param-xxx options before calling -rf-train. The stack is not modified by this command. # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch) c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf # Applying the classifier c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example: # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \ seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \ -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \ -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf # Apply using single MRI c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32. [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rgb2hsv_params(rgb2hsv: str) -> C3dRgb2hsvParameters: 
7723def c3d_rgb2hsv_params(
7724    rgb2hsv: str,
7725) -> C3dRgb2hsvParameters:
7726    """
7727    Build parameters.
7728    
7729    Args:
7730        rgb2hsv: -rgb2hsv: Convert RGB image to HSV image\
7731            \
7732            Syntax `-rgb2hsv`\
7733            \
7734            Takes the last three images on the stack and treats them as red,\
7735            green, and blue channels. Outputs three images corresponding to\
7736            hue, saturation, value. To read color images you need the\
7737            ***-msc*** command.\
7738            \
7739            c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png.
7740    Returns:
7741        Parameter dictionary
7742    """
7743    params = {
7744        "__STYXTYPE__": "rgb2hsv",
7745        "rgb2hsv": rgb2hsv,
7746    }
7747    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rgb2hsv: -rgb2hsv: Convert RGB image to HSV image Syntax -rgb2hsv Takes the last three images on the stack and treats them as red, green, and blue channels. Outputs three images corresponding to hue, saturation, value. To read color images you need the -msc command. c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_rms_params(rms: str) -> C3dRmsParameters: 
7771def c3d_rms_params(
7772    rms: str,
7773) -> C3dRmsParameters:
7774    """
7775    Build parameters.
7776    
7777    Args:
7778        rms: -rms: Voxelwise vector norm\
7779            \
7780            Syntax: `-rms`\
7781            \
7782            Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The\
7783            command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the\
7784            squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is\
7785            very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same\
7786            size.\
7787            \
7788            c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img\
7789            \
7790            The equivalent of this command is\
7791            \
7792            c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times\
7793            -endfor \\\
7794            -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img.
7795    Returns:
7796        Parameter dictionary
7797    """
7798    params = {
7799        "__STYXTYPE__": "rms",
7800        "rms": rms,
7801    }
7802    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • rms: -rms: Voxelwise vector norm Syntax: -rms Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same size. c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img The equivalent of this command is c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor \ -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_round_params(round_: str) -> C3dRoundParameters: 
7826def c3d_round_params(
7827    round_: str,
7828) -> C3dRoundParameters:
7829    """
7830    Build parameters.
7831    
7832    Args:
7833        round_: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior\
7834            \
7835            Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `\
7836            \
7837            By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when\
7838            converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command\
7839            specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to\
7840            avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point\
7841            representation.\
7842            \
7843            c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
7844    Returns:
7845        Parameter dictionary
7846    """
7847    params = {
7848        "__STYXTYPE__": "round",
7849        "round": round_,
7850    }
7851    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • round_: -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior Syntax: -noround or -round By default, convert3d will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_scale_params(scale: str) -> C3dScaleParameters: 
7875def c3d_scale_params(
7876    scale: str,
7877) -> C3dScaleParameters:
7878    """
7879    Build parameters.
7880    
7881    Args:
7882        scale: -scale: Scale intensity by constant factor\
7883            \
7884            Syntax: `-scale <factor>`\
7885            \
7886            Multiplies the intensity of each voxel in the last image on the\
7887            stack by the given factor.\
7888            \
7889            c3d img1.img -scale 0.5 -o img2.img.
7890    Returns:
7891        Parameter dictionary
7892    """
7893    params = {
7894        "__STYXTYPE__": "scale",
7895        "scale": scale,
7896    }
7897    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • scale: -scale: Scale intensity by constant factor Syntax: -scale <factor> Multiplies the intensity of each voxel in the last image on the stack by the given factor. c3d img1.img -scale 0.5 -o img2.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_set_params(set_: str) -> C3dSetParameters: 
1247def c3d_set_params(
1248    set_: str,
1249) -> C3dSetParameters:
1250    """
1251    Build parameters.
1252    
1253    Args:
1254        set_: -as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable\
1255            \
1256            Syntax: `-as var`\
1257            \
1258            Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with\
1259            variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on\
1260            the command line using the **-push** command. The **-as** and\
1261            **-push** commands are useful when you need to use a certain image\
1262            more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you\
1263            want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask\
1264            it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value\
1265            0, you would use the following command:\
1266            \
1267            c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img.
1268    Returns:
1269        Parameter dictionary
1270    """
1271    params = {
1272        "__STYXTYPE__": "set",
1273        "set": set_,
1274    }
1275    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • set_: -as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable Syntax: -as var Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using the -push command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_set_sform_1_params(set_sform: str) -> C3dSetSform1Parameters:

7931            \
7932            Sets the Nifti sform of the last image on the stack to the 4x4\
7933            matrix provided.
7934    Returns:
7935        Parameter dictionary
7936    """
7937    params = {
7938        "__STYXTYPE__": "set_sform_1",
7939        "set_sform": set_sform,
7940    }
7941    return params

Arguments:
  • set_sform: -set-sform: Set the transform to physical space Syntax: -set-sform <sform.mat> Sets the Nifti sform of the last image on the stack to the 4x4 matrix provided.

def c3d_signed_distance_transform_params( signed_distance_transform: str) -> C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters: 
8213def c3d_signed_distance_transform_params(
8214    signed_distance_transform: str,
8215) -> C3dSignedDistanceTransformParameters:
8216    """
8217    Build parameters.
8218    
8219    Args:
8220        signed_distance_transform: -sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed\
8221            distance transform of a binary image\
8222            \
8223            Syntax: `-sdt`\
8224            \
8225            Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels\
8226            where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and\
8227            voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values.\
8228            The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean\
8229            distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary\
8230            image.\
8231            \
8232            c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img.
8233    Returns:
8234        Parameter dictionary
8235    """
8236    params = {
8237        "__STYXTYPE__": "signed_distance_transform",
8238        "signed_distance_transform": signed_distance_transform,
8239    }
8240    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • signed_distance_transform: -sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary image Syntax: -sdt Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary image. c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_sin_params(sin: str) -> C3dSinParameters:

7979        Parameter dictionary
7980    """

7982        "__STYXTYPE__": "sin",

7984    }

def c3d_slice_all_params(slice_all: str) -> C3dSliceAllParameters: 
8073def c3d_slice_all_params(
8074    slice_all: str,
8075) -> C3dSliceAllParameters:
8076    """
8077    Build parameters.
8078    
8079    Args:
8080        slice_all: -slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack\
8081            \
8082            Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`\
8083            \
8084            This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all\
8085            images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved.\
8086            This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if\
8087            you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and\
8088            save the slices as follows:\
8089            \
8090            c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz.
8091    Returns:
8092        Parameter dictionary
8093    """
8094    params = {
8095        "__STYXTYPE__": "slice_all",
8096        "slice_all": slice_all,
8097    }
8098    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • slice_all: -slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack Syntax -slice-all axis position_spec This command behaves identical to the -slice command, but all images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows: c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_slice_params(slice_: str) -> C3dSliceParameters: 
8009def c3d_slice_params(
8010    slice_: str,
8011) -> C3dSliceParameters:
8012    """
8013    Build parameters.
8014    
8015    Args:
8016        slice_: -slice: Extract slices from an image\
8017            \
8018            Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`\
8019            \
8020            Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position\
8021            specifier **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of\
8022            slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a\
8023            percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice\
8024            0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a\
8025            range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on\
8026            the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can\
8027            save the slice as a 2D PNG image.\
8028            \
8029            c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz\
8030            c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz\
8031            c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o\
8032            myslice.png\
8033            c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz\
8034            c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz\
8035            \
8036            With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to\
8037            extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a\
8038            4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the\
8039            command\
8040            \
8041            c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz.
8042    Returns:
8043        Parameter dictionary
8044    """
8045    params = {
8046        "__STYXTYPE__": "slice",
8047        "slice": slice_,
8048    }
8049    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • slice_: -slice: Extract slices from an image Syntax: -slice axis position_spec Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier position_spec can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image. c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz With the new command c4d, the -slice command can be used to extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_smooth_fast_params(smooth_fast: str) -> C3dSmoothFastParameters: 
8311def c3d_smooth_fast_params(
8312    smooth_fast: str,
8313) -> C3dSmoothFastParameters:
8314    """
8315    Build parameters.
8316    
8317    Args:
8318        smooth_fast: -smooth-fast: Fast approximate Gaussian smoothing\
8319            \
8320            Syntax: `-smooth-fast <sigma_vector> `\
8321            \
8322            Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image using the fast [Deriche\
8323            recursive smoothing algorithm][15]. The parameter vector specifies\
8324            the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see [Vector\
8325            Format Specification][10] below.\
8326            \
8327            c3d img1.img -smooth-fast 20x10x10vox -o out.img.
8328    Returns:
8329        Parameter dictionary
8330    """
8331    params = {
8332        "__STYXTYPE__": "smooth_fast",
8333        "smooth_fast": smooth_fast,
8334    }
8335    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • smooth_fast: -smooth-fast: Fast approximate Gaussian smoothing Syntax: -smooth-fast <sigma_vector> Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image using the fast [Deriche recursive smoothing algorithm][15]. The parameter vector specifies the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see [Vector Format Specification][10] below. c3d img1.img -smooth-fast 20x10x10vox -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_smooth_params(smooth: str) -> C3dSmoothParameters: 
8264def c3d_smooth_params(
8265    smooth: str,
8266) -> C3dSmoothParameters:
8267    """
8268    Build parameters.
8269    
8270    Args:
8271        smooth: -smooth: Gaussian smoothing\
8272            \
8273            Syntax: `-smooth <sigma_vector> `\
8274            \
8275            Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image. The parameter vector\
8276            specifies the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see\
8277            [Vector Format Specification][10] below.\
8278            \
8279            c3d img1.img -smooth 2x1x1vox -o out.img.
8280    Returns:
8281        Parameter dictionary
8282    """
8283    params = {
8284        "__STYXTYPE__": "smooth",
8285        "smooth": smooth,
8286    }
8287    return params

Arguments:
  • smooth: -smooth: Gaussian smoothing Syntax: -smooth <sigma_vector> Applies Gaussian smoothing to the image. The parameter vector specifies the standard deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see [Vector Format Specification][10] below. c3d img1.img -smooth 2x1x1vox -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_spacing_params(spacing: str) -> C3dSpacingParameters: 
8359def c3d_spacing_params(
8360    spacing: str,
8361) -> C3dSpacingParameters:
8362    """
8363    Build parameters.
8364    
8365    Args:
8366        spacing: -spacing: Set voxel spacing\
8367            \
8368            Syntax: `-spacing <vector> `\
8369            \
8370            Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector\
8371            with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the\
8372            image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only\
8373            changes the header of the image, not its contents.\
8374            \
8375            c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img.
8376    Returns:
8377        Parameter dictionary
8378    """
8379    params = {
8380        "__STYXTYPE__": "spacing",
8381        "spacing": spacing,
8382    }
8383    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • spacing: -spacing: Set voxel spacing Syntax: -spacing <vector> Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of the image, not its contents. c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_split_params(split: str) -> C3dSplitParameters: 
8407def c3d_split_params(
8408    split: str,
8409) -> C3dSplitParameters:
8410    """
8411    Build parameters.
8412    
8413    Args:
8414        split: -split: Split multi-label image into binary images\
8415            \
8416            Syntax: `-split`\
8417            \
8418            This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of\
8419            discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary\
8420            images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be\
8421            recombined using the **-merge** command. The labels corresponding\
8422            to each binary image are remembered by **convert3d** so that when\
8423            **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The\
8424            **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image, and\
8425            selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The\
8426            example below smooths each label independently, then recombines\
8427            using **-merge**\
8428            \
8429            c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o\
8430            ml_smooth.nii\
8431            \
8432            Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite\
8433            intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the\
8434            labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*,\
8435            for example, using the **-thresh** command.
8436    Returns:
8437        Parameter dictionary
8438    """
8439    params = {
8440        "__STYXTYPE__": "split",
8441        "split": split,
8442    }
8443    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • split: -split: Split multi-label image into binary images Syntax: -split This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the -merge command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by convert3d so that when -merge is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The -merge command treats each input as a probability image, and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using -merge c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o ml_smooth.nii Also of note is that the -split command will disregard infinite intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with inf, for example, using the -thresh command.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_spm_params(spm: str) -> C3dSpmParameters: 
8627def c3d_spm_params(
8628    spm: str,
8629) -> C3dSpmParameters:
8630    """
8631    Build parameters.
8632    
8633    Args:
8634        spm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output\
8635            \
8636            Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `\
8637            \
8638            These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze\
8639            (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored\
8640            by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When\
8641            saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default\
8642            is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue\
8643            altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.\
8644            \
8645            c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
8646    Returns:
8647        Parameter dictionary
8648    """
8649    params = {
8650        "__STYXTYPE__": "spm",
8651        "spm": spm,
8652    }
8653    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • spm: -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output Syntax: -spm or -nospm These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later. c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_sqrt_params(sqrt: str) -> C3dSqrtParameters: 
8467def c3d_sqrt_params(
8468    sqrt: str,
8469) -> C3dSqrtParameters:
8470    """
8471    Build parameters.
8472    
8473    Args:
8474        sqrt: -sqrt: Take square root of image\
8475            \
8476            Syntax: `-sqrt `\
8477            \
8478            Computes square root of each voxel in the image.\
8479            \
8480            c3d input.img -sqrt -o output.img.
8481    Returns:
8482        Parameter dictionary
8483    """
8484    params = {
8485        "__STYXTYPE__": "sqrt",
8486        "sqrt": sqrt,
8487    }
8488    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • sqrt: -sqrt: Take square root of image Syntax: -sqrt Computes square root of each voxel in the image. c3d input.img -sqrt -o output.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_staple_params(staple: str) -> C3dStapleParameters: 
8512def c3d_staple_params(
8513    staple: str,
8514) -> C3dStapleParameters:
8515    """
8516    Build parameters.
8517    
8518    Args:
8519        staple: -staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations\
8520            \
8521            Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `\
8522            \
8523            Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See\
8524            Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true'\
8525            segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by\
8526            different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as\
8527            inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a\
8528            different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the\
8529            label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of\
8530            interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1\
8531            corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the\
8532            hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the\
8533            *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image\
8534            with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each\
8535            voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be\
8536            thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional\
8537            outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each\
8538            rater) are printed out if the **-verbose** command is used before\
8539            the **-staple** command.\
8540            \
8541            c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o\
8542            probmap.img\
8543            c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o\
8544            bin_segm.img.
8545    Returns:
8546        Parameter dictionary
8547    """
8548    params = {
8549        "__STYXTYPE__": "staple",
8550        "staple": staple,
8551    }
8552    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • staple: -staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations Syntax: -staple <intensity_value> Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a different rater. The parameter intensity_value specifies the label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the intensity_value). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the -verbose command is used before the -staple command. c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_stretch_params(stretch: str) -> C3dStretchParameters: 
8755def c3d_stretch_params(
8756    stretch: str,
8757) -> C3dStretchParameters:
8758    """
8759    Build parameters.
8760    
8761    Args:
8762        stretch: -stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly\
8763            \
8764            Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `\
8765            \
8766            Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps\
8767            to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to\
8768            all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For\
8769            example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval\
8770            (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use\
8771            \
8772            c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img.
8773    Returns:
8774        Parameter dictionary
8775    """
8776    params = {
8777        "__STYXTYPE__": "stretch",
8778        "stretch": stretch,
8779    }
8780    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • stretch: -stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly Syntax: -stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_structure_tensor_eigenvalues_params( structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str) -> C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters: 
8576def c3d_structure_tensor_eigenvalues_params(
8577    structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str,
8578) -> C3dStructureTensorEigenvaluesParameters:
8579    """
8580    Build parameters.
8581    
8582    Args:
8583        structure_tensor_eigenvalues: -steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues:\
8584            Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor\
8585            \
8586            Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`\
8587            \
8588            Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the\
8589            eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by\
8590            value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture\
8591            features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines\
8592            the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial\
8593            derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.\
8594            \
8595            c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
8596    Returns:
8597        Parameter dictionary
8598    """
8599    params = {
8600        "__STYXTYPE__": "structure_tensor_eigenvalues",
8601        "structure_tensor_eigenvalues": structure_tensor_eigenvalues,
8602    }
8603    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • structure_tensor_eigenvalues: -steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor Syntax -steig <scale> <radius> Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units. c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_swapdim_params(swapdim: str) -> C3dSwapdimParameters: 
8804def c3d_swapdim_params(
8805    swapdim: str,
8806) -> C3dSwapdimParameters:
8807    """
8808    Build parameters.
8809    
8810    Args:
8811        swapdim: -swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image\
8812            \
8813            Syntax `-swapdim <code>`\
8814            \
8815            This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to\
8816            achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical\
8817            space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but\
8818            the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to\
8819            obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified\
8820            as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.\
8821            \
8822            c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii\
8823            \
8824            \
8825            ### Commands: Image Processing\
8826            \
8827            The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images.\
8828            Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack,\
8829            binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands\
8830            are affected by options, which are listed separately.
8831    Returns:
8832        Parameter dictionary
8833    """
8834    params = {
8835        "__STYXTYPE__": "swapdim",
8836        "swapdim": swapdim,
8837    }
8838    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • swapdim: -swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image Syntax -swapdim <code> This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command. c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii ### Commands: Image Processing The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options, which are listed separately.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_test_image_params(test_image: str) -> C3dTestImageParameters: 
8862def c3d_test_image_params(
8863    test_image: str,
8864) -> C3dTestImageParameters:
8865    """
8866    Build parameters.
8867    
8868    Args:
8869        test_image: -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition\
8870            \
8871            Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value>\
8872            [tolerance]`\
8873            \
8874            These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are\
8875            primarily meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also\
8876            be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell).\
8877            The commands check a certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause\
8878            the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded\
8879            or a non-zero return code if the test failed.\
8880            \
8881            **-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are\
8882            identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the\
8883            images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default\
8884            value 1e-8.\
8885            \
8886            c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image\
8887            \
8888            **-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if\
8889            the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by\
8890            **vector** is equal to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance\
8891            value may be specified, the default is 1e-8.\
8892            \
8893            c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6.
8894    Returns:
8895        Parameter dictionary
8896    """
8897    params = {
8898        "__STYXTYPE__": "test_image",
8899        "test_image": test_image,
8900    }
8901    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • test_image: -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition Syntax: -test-image [tolerance] and -test-probe <vector> <value> [tolerance] These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily meant to allow testing of c3d. However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., bash shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the c3d state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed. -test-image tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8. c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image -test-probe is similar to the -probe command. It tests if the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by vector is equal to the test_value. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the default is 1e-8. c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_test_probe_params(test_probe: str) -> C3dTestProbeParameters:

8939            be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell).\

8947            value 1e-8.\

8950            \

8952            the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by\

8954            value may be specified, the default is 1e-8.\

However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., bash shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the c3d state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed. -test-image tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). def c3d_threshold_params(threshold: str) -> C3dThresholdParameters: 
8988def c3d_threshold_params(
8989    threshold: str,
8990) -> C3dThresholdParameters:
8991    """
8992    Build parameters.
8993    
8994    Args:
8995        threshold: -thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding\
8996            \
8997            Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `\
8998            \
8999            Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the\
9000            range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and\
9001            *u2* are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you\
9002            can supply values **inf** and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a\
9003            one-sided threshold. You can also specify *u1* and *u2* as\
9004            percentiles.\
9005            c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img\
9006            c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img\
9007            c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img.
9008    Returns:
9009        Parameter dictionary
9010    """
9011    params = {
9012        "__STYXTYPE__": "threshold",
9013        "threshold": threshold,
9014    }
9015    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • threshold: -thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding Syntax: -thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values u1 and u2 are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values inf and -inf for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also specify u1 and u2 as percentiles. c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_tile_params(tile: str) -> C3dTileParameters: 
9039def c3d_tile_params(
9040    tile: str,
9041) -> C3dTileParameters:
9042    """
9043    Build parameters.
9044    
9045    Args:
9046        tile: -tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one\
9047            \
9048            Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`\
9049            \
9050            Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking\
9051            slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack\
9052            and produces a single tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can\
9053            either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile\
9054            the images, or a layout vector (e.g., **4x4**) which specifies the\
9055            tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the\
9056            layout vector determines the value based on the number of images\
9057            currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of\
9058            slices, we use\
9059            \
9060            c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz\
9061            \
9062            And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per\
9063            row, we would use the **c2d** command as follows:\
9064            \
9065            c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png.
9066    Returns:
9067        Parameter dictionary
9068    """
9069    params = {
9070        "__STYXTYPE__": "tile",
9071        "tile": tile,
9072    }
9073    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • tile: -tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one Syntax: -tile <tile_spec> Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single tiled image. The tile_spec parameter can either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g., 4x4) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of slices, we use c3d slices.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we would use the c2d command as follows: c2d slices.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_trim_params(trim: str) -> C3dTrimParameters: 
9097def c3d_trim_params(
9098    trim: str,
9099) -> C3dTrimParameters:
9100    """
9101    Build parameters.
9102    
9103    Args:
9104        trim: -trim: Trim background region of image\
9105            \
9106            Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`\
9107            \
9108            Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the\
9109            image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest\
9110            rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels\
9111            in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the\
9112            size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image.\
9113            For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel\
9114            margin of background values on all sides\
9115            \
9116            c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img.
9117    Returns:
9118        Parameter dictionary
9119    """
9120    params = {
9121        "__STYXTYPE__": "trim",
9122        "trim": trim,
9123    }
9124    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • trim: -trim: Trim background region of image Syntax: -trim <margin_vector> Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_trim_to_size_params(trim_to_size: str) -> C3dTrimToSizeParameters: 
9148def c3d_trim_to_size_params(
9149    trim_to_size: str,
9150) -> C3dTrimToSizeParameters:
9151    """
9152    Build parameters.
9153    
9154    Args:
9155        trim_to_size: -trim-to-size: Trim image to given size\
9156            \
9157            Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`\
9158            \
9159            Like **-trim**, this command trims the background in an image.\
9160            However, instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the\
9161            output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified\
9162            region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For\
9163            example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the\
9164            foreground pixels in your image, call\
9165            \
9166            c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img.
9167    Returns:
9168        Parameter dictionary
9169    """
9170    params = {
9171        "__STYXTYPE__": "trim_to_size",
9172        "trim_to_size": trim_to_size,
9173    }
9174    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • trim_to_size: -trim-to-size: Trim image to given size Syntax: -trim-to-size <size_vector> Like -trim, this command trims the background in an image. However, instead of -trim, you specify the target size of the output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_type_params(type_: str) -> C3dTypeParameters: 
9198def c3d_type_params(
9199    type_: str,
9200) -> C3dTypeParameters:
9201    """
9202    Build parameters.
9203    
9204    Args:
9205        type_: -type: Specify pixel type for image output\
9206            \
9207            Syntax: `-type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float\
9208            | double > `\
9209            \
9210            Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images\
9211            are written in floating point (**float**) format. The type does not\
9212            affect how images are processed, only how they are saved.\
9213            \
9214            c3d image1.img -type short image2.img\
9215            \
9216            Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG\
9217            images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.
9218    Returns:
9219        Parameter dictionary
9220    """
9221    params = {
9222        "__STYXTYPE__": "type",
9223        "type": type_,
9224    }
9225    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • type_: -type: Specify pixel type for image output Syntax: -type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float | double > Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images are written in floating point (float) format. The type does not affect how images are processed, only how they are saved. c3d image1.img -type short image2.img Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_vote_mrf_params(vote_mrf: str) -> C3dVoteMrfParameters: 
9430def c3d_vote_mrf_params(
9431    vote_mrf: str,
9432) -> C3dVoteMrfParameters:
9433    """
9434    Build parameters.
9435    
9436    Args:
9437        vote_mrf: -vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization\
9438            \
9439            Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`\
9440            \
9441            This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs\
9442            regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of\
9443            regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in\
9444            the output. It results in more contiguous segments.\
9445            \
9446            The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they\
9447            are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This\
9448            means that voxel **x** in image **k** holds the probability that\
9449            voxel **x** has label **k**. Likelihood images must be between 0\
9450            and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel\
9451            being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label\
9452            0 in the output.\
9453            \
9454            The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization,\
9455            consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term\
9456            encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel\
9457            **x** the label **k**. The parameter **mode** describes how\
9458            likelihood images are mapped to the cost.\
9459            \
9460            * `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is\
9461            being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a\
9462            single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion\
9463            of segmentations that assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term\
9464            equals to the error associated to assining the voxel *k* label *x*.\
9465            This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all\
9466            labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*. Note that the\
9467            likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted\
9468            as missing data for some voxels.\
9469            \
9470            * `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is\
9471            the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign\
9472            infinite cost when the likelihood is zero.\
9473            \
9474            The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total\
9475            number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region\
9476            of the image) that have different labels.\
9477            \
9478            The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph\
9479            cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the\
9480            following papers.\
9481            \
9482            1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate\
9483            Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI,\
9484            vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001.\
9485            \
9486            2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can\
9487            be Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26,\
9488            no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.\
9489            \
9490            3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison\
9491            of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*,\
9492            IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.\
9493            \
9494            As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts\
9495            algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This\
9496            software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite\
9497            the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication. If you wish\
9498            to use this software (or the algorithms described in the\
9499            aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware\
9500            that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System\
9501            and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph\
9502            cuts*, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.\
9503            \
9504            The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a\
9505            user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped\
9506            to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization\
9507            and given 0 label.\
9508            \
9509            c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \\\
9510            -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \\\
9511            -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii.
9512    Returns:
9513        Parameter dictionary
9514    """
9515    params = {
9516        "__STYXTYPE__": "vote_mrf",
9517        "vote_mrf": vote_mrf,
9518    }
9519    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • vote_mrf: -vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization Syntax: -vote-mrf <mode> <lambda> This command is similar to -vote but it performs regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more contiguous segments. The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel x in image k holds the probability that voxel x has label k. Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label 0 in the output. The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel x the label k. The parameter mode describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost. * VOTES_AGAINST or VA. This mode is useful when the command is being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that assign label k to voxel x. The data term equals to the error associated to assining the voxel k label x. This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all labels at x minus the likelihood for k at x. Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted as missing data for some voxels. * LOG_LIKELIHOOD or LL. The cost for label k at voxel x is the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at x. This will assign infinite cost when the likelihood is zero. The regularlization term is encoded as lambda times the total number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that have different labels. The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers. 1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, Efficient Approximate Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001. 2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, What Energy Functions can be Minimized via Graph Cuts?, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004. 3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, An Experimental Comparison of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004. As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication. If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, System and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004. The example below illustrates applying -vote-mrf with a user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label. c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \ -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \ -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_vote_params(vote: str) -> C3dVoteParameters: 
9373def c3d_vote_params(
9374    vote: str,
9375) -> C3dVoteParameters:
9376    """
9377    Build parameters.
9378    
9379    Args:
9380        vote: -vote: Vote among images on the stack\
9381            \
9382            Syntax: `-vote `\
9383            \
9384            This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each\
9385            voxel *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image\
9386            value at *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when\
9387            combining probability maps into a single label image. If images\
9388            prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc.\
9389            over the image domain, the **-vote** command will return the most\
9390            probable label at each voxel.\
9391            \
9392            c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img\
9393            \
9394            The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the\
9395            bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the\
9396            example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where\
9397            prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see\
9398            the related commands **-split** and **-merge**.
9399    Returns:
9400        Parameter dictionary
9401    """
9402    params = {
9403        "__STYXTYPE__": "vote",
9404        "vote": vote,
9405    }
9406    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • vote: -vote: Vote among images on the stack Syntax: -vote This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel (i,j,k) returns the index of the image for which the image value at (i,j,k) is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the -vote command will return the most probable label at each voxel. c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands -split and -merge.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_voxel_integral_params(voxel_integral: str) -> C3dVoxelIntegralParameters: 
9628def c3d_voxel_integral_params(
9629    voxel_integral: str,
9630) -> C3dVoxelIntegralParameters:
9631    """
9632    Build parameters.
9633    
9634    Args:
9635        voxel_integral: -voxel-integral: Print volume integral of all voxel\
9636            intensities\
9637            \
9638            Syntax: `-voxel-integral`\
9639            \
9640            Like **-voxel-sum**, but multiplies the sum of voxel intensities by\
9641            voxel volume. This is useful for computing volumes of objects\
9642            represented by binary images. The result is in 'ml'.\
9643            \
9644            $ c3d image.img -voxel-integral\
9645            Voxel Integral: 2341.
9646    Returns:
9647        Parameter dictionary
9648    """
9649    params = {
9650        "__STYXTYPE__": "voxel_integral",
9651        "voxel_integral": voxel_integral,
9652    }
9653    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • voxel_integral: -voxel-integral: Print volume integral of all voxel intensities Syntax: -voxel-integral Like -voxel-sum, but multiplies the sum of voxel intensities by voxel volume. This is useful for computing volumes of objects represented by binary images. The result is in 'ml'. $ c3d image.img -voxel-integral Voxel Integral: 2341.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_voxelwise_regression_params( voxelwise_regression: str) -> C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters: 
9677def c3d_voxelwise_regression_params(
9678    voxelwise_regression: str,
9679) -> C3dVoxelwiseRegressionParameters:
9680    """
9681    Build parameters.
9682    
9683    Args:
9684        voxelwise_regression: -voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression\
9685            between two images\
9686            \
9687            Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `\
9688            \
9689            Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This\
9690            command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds\
9691            parameters b\\_0, b\\_1, ..., b\\_k, such that Y is best\
9692            approximated by b\\_0 + b\\_1 * X + b\\_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k.\
9693            Here is an example of linear regression.\
9694            \
9695            $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2\
9696            REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935\
9697            REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024\
9698            \
9699            $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2\
9700            REGCOEFF[0] = 0\
9701            REGCOEFF[1] = 1.
9702    Returns:
9703        Parameter dictionary
9704    """
9705    params = {
9706        "__STYXTYPE__": "voxelwise_regression",
9707        "voxelwise_regression": voxelwise_regression,
9708    }
9709    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • voxelwise_regression: -voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images Syntax: -voxreg regression_order Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b_0, b_1, ..., b_k, such that Y is best approximated by b_0 + b_1 * X + b_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression. $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2 REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935 REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024 $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2 REGCOEFF[0] = 0 REGCOEFF[1] = 1.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_weighted_sum_params(weighted_sum: str) -> C3dWeightedSumParameters: 
9868def c3d_weighted_sum_params(
9869    weighted_sum: str,
9870) -> C3dWeightedSumParameters:
9871    """
9872    Build parameters.
9873    
9874    Args:
9875        weighted_sum: -wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant\
9876            weights\
9877            \
9878            Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `\
9879            \
9880            Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack.\
9881            \
9882            c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii\
9883            \
9884            This command is particularly useful for combining components in a\
9885            multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert\
9886            it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows:\
9887            \
9888            c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii.
9889    Returns:
9890        Parameter dictionary
9891    """
9892    params = {
9893        "__STYXTYPE__": "weighted_sum",
9894        "weighted_sum": weighted_sum,
9895    }
9896    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • weighted_sum: -wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights Syntax: -wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack. c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii This command is particularly useful for combining components in a multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows: c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_weighted_sum_voxelwise_params( weighted_sum_voxelwise: str) -> C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters: 
9920def c3d_weighted_sum_voxelwise_params(
9921    weighted_sum_voxelwise: str,
9922) -> C3dWeightedSumVoxelwiseParameters:
9923    """
9924    Build parameters.
9925    
9926    Args:
9927        weighted_sum_voxelwise: -wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of\
9928            images with spatially varying weights\
9929            \
9930            Syntax: `-wsv `\
9931            \
9932            Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The\
9933            images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack\
9934            are used.\
9935            \
9936            c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii\
9937            image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz\
9938            \
9939            The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:\
9940            \
9941            c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz\
9942            \
9943            ### Commands: Image Header Manipulation.
9944    Returns:
9945        Parameter dictionary
9946    """
9947    params = {
9948        "__STYXTYPE__": "weighted_sum_voxelwise",
9949        "weighted_sum_voxelwise": weighted_sum_voxelwise,
9950    }
9951    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • weighted_sum_voxelwise: -wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially varying weights Syntax: -wsv Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used. c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz The -reorder command can simplify loading the images: c3d weight.nii image.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz ### Commands: Image Header Manipulation.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary

def c3d_wrap_params(wrap: str) -> C3dWrapParameters: 
9811def c3d_wrap_params(
9812    wrap: str,
9813) -> C3dWrapParameters:
9814    """
9815    Build parameters.
9816    
9817    Args:
9818        wrap: -wrap: Wrap (rotate) image\
9819            \
9820            Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `\
9821            \
9822            Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is\
9823            typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector\
9824            must have integer components, possibly negative. For example,\
9825            \
9826            c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz\
9827            \
9828            will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels\
9829            (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).\
9830            \
9831            \
9832            ### Commands: Options and Parameters\
9833            \
9834            Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the\
9835            command line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the\
9836            command will have no effect.
9837    Returns:
9838        Parameter dictionary
9839    """
9840    params = {
9841        "__STYXTYPE__": "wrap",
9842        "wrap": wrap,
9843    }
9844    return params

Build parameters.

Arguments:
  • wrap: -wrap: Wrap (rotate) image Syntax: -wrap <vector> Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer components, possibly negative. For example, c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20). ### Commands: Options and Parameters Options change the behavior of commands that appear later on the command line. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will have no effect.
Returns:

Parameter dictionary
